    7340             :         }
    7341             :         else if (n <= (std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::max)())
    7342             :         {
    7343             :             if (add_prefix)
    7344             :             {
    7345             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('U')); // uint8
    7346             :             }
    7347             :             write_number(static_cast<uint8_t>(n));
    7348             :         }
    7349             :         else if (n <=
    7350             :                  static_cast<uint64_t>((std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::max)()))
    7351             :         {
    7352             :             if (add_prefix)
    7353             :             {
    7354             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('I')); // int16
    7355             :             }
    7356             :             write_number(static_cast<int16_t>(n));
    7357             :         }
    7358             :         else if (n <=
    7359             :                  static_cast<uint64_t>((std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::max)()))
    7360             :         {
    7361             :             if (add_prefix)
    7362             :             {
    7363             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('l')); // int32
    7364             :             }
    7365             :             write_number(static_cast<int32_t>(n));
    7366             :         }
    7367             :         else if (n <=
    7368             :                  static_cast<uint64_t>((std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::max)()))
    7369             :         {
    7370             :             if (add_prefix)
    7371             :             {
    7372             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('L')); // int64
    7373             :             }
    7374             :             write_number(static_cast<int64_t>(n));
    7375             :         }
    7376             :         else
    7377             :         {
    7378             :             JSON_THROW(
    7379             :                 out_of_range::create(407, "number overflow serializing " +
    7380             :                                               std::to_string(n)));
    7381             :         }
    7382             :     }
    7383             : 
    7384             :     // UBJSON: write number (signed integer)
    7385             :     template <typename NumberType,
    7386             :               typename std::enable_if<
    7387             :                   std::is_signed<NumberType>::value and
    7388             :                       not std::is_floating_point<NumberType>::value,
    7389             :                   int>::type = 0>
    7390             :     void write_number_with_ubjson_prefix(const NumberType n,
    7391             :                                          const bool add_prefix)
    7392             :     {
    7393             :         if ((std::numeric_limits<int8_t>::min)() <= n and
    7394             :             n <= (std::numeric_limits<int8_t>::max)())
    7395             :         {
    7396             :             if (add_prefix)
    7397             :             {
    7398             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('i')); // int8
    7399             :             }
    7400             :             write_number(static_cast<int8_t>(n));
    7401             :         }
    7402             :         else if (static_cast<int64_t>((std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::min)()) <=
    7403             :                      n and
    7404             :                  n <= static_cast<int64_t>(
    7405             :                           (std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::max)()))
    7406             :         {
    7407             :             if (add_prefix)
    7408             :             {
    7409             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('U')); // uint8
    7410             :             }
    7411             :             write_number(static_cast<uint8_t>(n));
    7412             :         }
    7413             :         else if ((std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::min)() <= n and
    7414             :                  n <= (std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::max)())
    7415             :         {
    7416             :             if (add_prefix)
    7417             :             {
    7418             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('I')); // int16
    7419             :             }
    7420             :             write_number(static_cast<int16_t>(n));
    7421             :         }
    7422             :         else if ((std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::min)() <= n and
    7423             :                  n <= (std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::max)())
    7424             :         {
    7425             :             if (add_prefix)
    7426             :             {
    7427             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('l')); // int32
    7428             :             }
    7429             :             write_number(static_cast<int32_t>(n));
    7430             :         }
    7431             :         else if ((std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::min)() <= n and
    7432             :                  n <= (std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::max)())
    7433             :         {
    7434             :             if (add_prefix)
    7435             :             {
    7436             :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>('L')); // int64
    7437             :             }
    7438             :             write_number(static_cast<int64_t>(n));
    7439             :         }
    7440             :         // LCOV_EXCL_START
    7441             :         else
    7442             :         {
    7443             :             JSON_THROW(
    7444             :                 out_of_range::create(407, "number overflow serializing " +
    7445             :                                               std::to_string(n)));
    7446             :         }
    7447             :         // LCOV_EXCL_STOP
    7448             :     }
    7449             : 
    7450             :     /*!
    7451             :     @brief determine the type prefix of container values
    7452             : 
    7453             :     @note This function does not need to be 100% accurate when it comes to
    7454             :           integer limits. In case a number exceeds the limits of int64_t,
    7455             :           this will be detected by a later call to function
    7456             :           write_number_with_ubjson_prefix. Therefore, we return 'L' for any
    7457             :           value that does not fit the previous limits.
    7458             :     */
    7459             :     char ubjson_prefix(const BasicJsonType& j) const noexcept
    7460             :     {
    7461             :         switch (j.type())
    7462             :         {
    7463             :         case value_t::null:
    7464             :             return 'Z';
    7465             : 
    7466             :         case value_t::boolean:
    7467             :             return j.m_value.boolean ? 'T' : 'F';
    7468             : 
    7469             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    7470             :         {
    7471             :             if ((std::numeric_limits<int8_t>::min)() <=
    7472             :                     j.m_value.number_integer and
    7473             :                 j.m_value.number_integer <=
    7474             :                     (std::numeric_limits<int8_t>::max)())
    7475             :             {
    7476             :                 return 'i';
    7477             :             }
    7478             :             else if ((std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::min)() <=
    7479             :                          j.m_value.number_integer and
    7480             :                      j.m_value.number_integer <=
    7481             :                          (std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::max)())
    7482             :             {
    7483             :                 return 'U';
    7484             :             }
    7485             :             else if ((std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::min)() <=
    7486             :                          j.m_value.number_integer and
    7487             :                      j.m_value.number_integer <=
    7488             :                          (std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::max)())
    7489             :             {
    7490             :                 return 'I';
    7491             :             }
    7492             :             else if ((std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::min)() <=
    7493             :                          j.m_value.number_integer and
    7494             :                      j.m_value.number_integer <=
    7495             :                          (std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::max)())
    7496             :             {
    7497             :                 return 'l';
    7498             :             }
    7499             :             else // no check and assume int64_t (see note above)
    7500             :             {
    7501             :                 return 'L';
    7502             :             }
    7503             :         }
    7504             : 
    7505             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    7506             :         {
    7507             :             if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    7508             :                 (std::numeric_limits<int8_t>::max)())
    7509             :             {
    7510             :                 return 'i';
    7511             :             }
    7512             :             else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    7513             :                      (std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::max)())
    7514             :             {
    7515             :                 return 'U';
    7516             :             }
    7517             :             else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    7518             :                      (std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::max)())
    7519             :             {
    7520             :                 return 'I';
    7521             :             }
    7522             :             else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    7523             :                      (std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::max)())
    7524             :             {
    7525             :                 return 'l';
    7526             :             }
    7527             :             else // no check and assume int64_t (see note above)
    7528             :             {
    7529             :                 return 'L';
    7530             :             }
    7531             :         }
    7532             : 
    7533             :         case value_t::number_float:
    7534             :             return 'D';
    7535             : 
    7536             :         case value_t::string:
    7537             :             return 'S';
    7538             : 
    7539             :         case value_t::array:
    7540             :             return '[';
    7541             : 
    7542             :         case value_t::object:
    7543             :             return '{';
    7544             : 
    7545             :         default: // discarded values
    7546             :             return 'N';
    7547             :         }
    7548             :     }
    7549             : 
    7550             : private:
    7551             :     /// whether we can assume little endianess
    7552             :     const bool is_little_endian =
    7553             :         binary_reader<BasicJsonType>::little_endianess();
    7554             : 
    7555             :     /// the output
    7556             :     output_adapter_t<CharType> oa = nullptr;
    7557             : };
    7558             : }
    7559             : }
    7560             : 
    7561             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/output/serializer.hpp>
    7562             : 
    7563             : #include <algorithm>   // reverse, remove, fill, find, none_of
    7564             : #include <array>       // array
    7565             : #include <cassert>     // assert
    7566             : #include <ciso646>     // and, or
    7567             : #include <clocale>     // localeconv, lconv
    7568             : #include <cmath>       // labs, isfinite, isnan, signbit
    7569             : #include <cstddef>     // size_t, ptrdiff_t
    7570             : #include <cstdint>     // uint8_t
    7571             : #include <cstdio>      // snprintf
    7572             : #include <iomanip>     // setfill
    7573             : #include <iterator>    // next
    7574             : #include <limits>      // numeric_limits

    7576             : #include <string>      // string
    7577             : #include <type_traits> // is_same
    7578             : 
    7579             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/exceptions.hpp>
    7580             : 
    7581             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/conversions/to_chars.hpp>
    7582             : 
    7583             : #include <cassert> // assert
    7584             : #include <ciso646> // or, and, not
    7585             : #include <cmath>   // signbit, isfinite
    7586             : #include <cstdint> // intN_t, uintN_t
    7587             : #include <cstring> // memcpy, memmove
    7588             : 
    7589             : namespace brion_nlohmann
    7590             : {
    7591             : namespace detail
    7592             : {
    7593             : /*!
    7594             : @brief implements the Grisu2 algorithm for binary to decimal floating-point
    7595             : conversion.
    7596             : 
    7597             : This implementation is a slightly modified version of the reference
    7598             : implementation which may be obtained from
    7599             : http://florian.loitsch.com/publications (bench.tar.gz).
    7600             : 
    7601             : The code is distributed under the MIT license, Copyright (c) 2009 Florian
    7602             : Loitsch.
    7603             : 
    7604             : For a detailed description of the algorithm see:
    7605             : 
    7606             : [1] Loitsch, "Printing Floating-Point Numbers Quickly and Accurately with
    7607             :     Integers", Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN 2010 Conference on Programming
    7608             :     Language Design and Implementation, PLDI 2010
    7609             : [2] Burger, Dybvig, "Printing Floating-Point Numbers Quickly and Accurately",
    7610             :     Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN 1996 Conference on Programming Language
    7611             :     Design and Implementation, PLDI 1996
    7612             : */
    7613             : namespace dtoa_impl
    7614             : {
    7615             : template <typename Target, typename Source>
    7616             : Target reinterpret_bits(const Source source)
    7617             : {
    7618             :     static_assert(sizeof(Target) == sizeof(Source), "size mismatch");
    7619             : 
    7620             :     Target target;
    7621             :     std::memcpy(&target, &source, sizeof(Source));
    7622             :     return target;
    7623             : }
    7624             : 
    7625             : struct diyfp // f * 2^e
    7626             : {
    7627             :     static constexpr int kPrecision = 64; // = q
    7628             : 
    7629             :     uint64_t f;
    7630             :     int e;
    7631             : 
    7632             :     constexpr diyfp() noexcept : f(0), e(0) {}
    7633             :     constexpr diyfp(uint64_t f_, int e_) noexcept : f(f_), e(e_) {}
    7634             :     /*!
    7635             :     @brief returns x - y
    7636             :     @pre x.e == y.e and x.f >= y.f
    7637             :     */
    7638             :     static diyfp sub(const diyfp& x, const diyfp& y) noexcept
    7639             :     {
    7640             :         assert(x.e == y.e);
    7641             :         assert(x.f >= y.f);
    7642             : 
    7643             :         return diyfp(x.f - y.f, x.e);
    7644             :     }
    7645             : 
    7646             :     /*!
    7647             :     @brief returns x * y
    7648             :     @note The result is rounded. (Only the upper q bits are returned.)
    7649             :     */
    7650             :     static diyfp mul(const diyfp& x, const diyfp& y) noexcept
    7651             :     {
    7652             :         static_assert(kPrecision == 64, "internal error");
    7653             : 
    7654             :         // Computes:
    7655             :         //  f = round((x.f * y.f) / 2^q)
    7656             :         //  e = x.e + y.e + q
    7657             : 
    7658             :         // Emulate the 64-bit * 64-bit multiplication:
    7659             :         //
    7660             :         // p = u * v
    7661             :         //   = (u_lo + 2^32 u_hi) (v_lo + 2^32 v_hi)
    7662             :         //   = (u_lo v_lo         ) + 2^32 ((u_lo v_hi         ) + (u_hi v_lo
    7663             :         //   )) + 2^64 (u_hi v_hi         )
    7664             :         //   = (p0                ) + 2^32 ((p1                ) + (p2
    7665             :         //   )) + 2^64 (p3                )
    7666             :         //   = (p0_lo + 2^32 p0_hi) + 2^32 ((p1_lo + 2^32 p1_hi) + (p2_lo + 2^32
    7667             :         //   p2_hi)) + 2^64 (p3                )
    7668             :         //   = (p0_lo             ) + 2^32 (p0_hi + p1_lo + p2_lo
    7669             :         //   ) + 2^64 (p1_hi + p2_hi + p3)
    7670             :         //   = (p0_lo             ) + 2^32 (Q ) + 2^64 (H                 )
    7671             :         //   = (p0_lo             ) + 2^32 (Q_lo + 2^32 Q_hi
    7672             :         //   ) + 2^64 (H                 )
    7673             :         //
    7674             :         // (Since Q might be larger than 2^32 - 1)
    7675             :         //
    7676             :         //   = (p0_lo + 2^32 Q_lo) + 2^64 (Q_hi + H)
    7677             :         //
    7678             :         // (Q_hi + H does not overflow a 64-bit int)
    7679             :         //
    7680             :         //   = p_lo + 2^64 p_hi
    7681             : 
    7682             :         const uint64_t u_lo = x.f & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    7683             :         const uint64_t u_hi = x.f >> 32;
    7684             :         const uint64_t v_lo = y.f & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    7685             :         const uint64_t v_hi = y.f >> 32;
    7686             : 
    7687             :         const uint64_t p0 = u_lo * v_lo;
    7688             :         const uint64_t p1 = u_lo * v_hi;
    7689             :         const uint64_t p2 = u_hi * v_lo;
    7690             :         const uint64_t p3 = u_hi * v_hi;
    7691             : 
    7692             :         const uint64_t p0_hi = p0 >> 32;
    7693             :         const uint64_t p1_lo = p1 & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    7694             :         const uint64_t p1_hi = p1 >> 32;
    7695             :         const uint64_t p2_lo = p2 & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    7696             :         const uint64_t p2_hi = p2 >> 32;
    7697             : 
    7698             :         uint64_t Q = p0_hi + p1_lo + p2_lo;
    7699             : 
    7700             :         // The full product might now be computed as
    7701             :         //
    7702             :         // p_hi = p3 + p2_hi + p1_hi + (Q >> 32)
    7703             :         // p_lo = p0_lo + (Q << 32)
    7704             :         //
    7705             :         // But in this particular case here, the full p_lo is not required.
    7706             :         // Effectively we only need to add the highest bit in p_lo to p_hi (and
    7707             :         // Q_hi + 1 does not overflow).
    7708             : 
    7709             :         Q += uint64_t{1} << (64 - 32 - 1); // round, ties up
    7710             : 
    7711             :         const uint64_t h = p3 + p2_hi + p1_hi + (Q >> 32);
    7712             : 
    7713             :         return diyfp(h, x.e + y.e + 64);
    7714             :     }
    7715             : 
    7716             :     /*!
    7717             :     @brief normalize x such that the significand is >= 2^(q-1)
    7718             :     @pre x.f != 0
    7719             :     */
    7720             :     static diyfp normalize(diyfp x) noexcept
    7721             :     {
    7722             :         assert(x.f != 0);
    7723             : 
    7724             :         while ((x.f >> 63) == 0)
    7725             :         {
    7726             :             x.f <<= 1;
    7727             :             x.e--;
    7728             :         }
    7729             : 
    7730             :         return x;
    7731             :     }
    7732             : 
    7733             :     /*!
    7734             :     @brief normalize x such that the result has the exponent E
    7735             :     @pre e >= x.e and the upper e - x.e bits of x.f must be zero.
    7736             :     */
    7737             :     static diyfp normalize_to(const diyfp& x,
    7738             :                               const int target_exponent) noexcept
    7739             :     {
    7740             :         const int delta = x.e - target_exponent;
    7741             : 
    7742             :         assert(delta >= 0);
    7743             :         assert(((x.f << delta) >> delta) == x.f);
    7744             : 
    7745             :         return diyfp(x.f << delta, target_exponent);
    7746             :     }
    7747             : };
    7748             : 
    7749             : struct boundaries
    7750             : {
    7751             :     diyfp w;
    7752             :     diyfp minus;
    7753             :     diyfp plus;
    7754             : };
    7755             : 
    7756             : /*!
    7757             : Compute the (normalized) diyfp representing the input number 'value' and its
    7758             : boundaries.
    7759             : 
    7760             : @pre value must be finite and positive
    7761             : */
    7762             : template <typename FloatType>
    7763             : boundaries compute_boundaries(FloatType value)
    7764             : {
    7765             :     assert(std::isfinite(value));
    7766             :     assert(value > 0);
    7767             : 
    7768             :     // Convert the IEEE representation into a diyfp.
    7769             :     //
    7770             :     // If v is denormal:
    7771             :     //      value = 0.F * 2^(1 - bias) = (          F) * 2^(1 - bias - (p-1))
    7772             :     // If v is normalized:
    7773             :     //      value = 1.F * 2^(E - bias) = (2^(p-1) + F) * 2^(E - bias - (p-1))
    7774             : 
    7775             :     static_assert(std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::is_iec559,
    7776             :                   "internal error: dtoa_short requires an IEEE-754 "
    7777             :                   "floating-point implementation");
    7778             : 
    7779             :     constexpr int kPrecision =
    7780             :         std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::digits; // = p (includes the hidden bit)
    7781             :     constexpr int kBias =
    7782             :         std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_exponent - 1 + (kPrecision - 1);
    7783             :     constexpr int kMinExp = 1 - kBias;
    7784             :     constexpr uint64_t kHiddenBit = uint64_t{1}
    7785             :                                     << (kPrecision - 1); // = 2^(p-1)
    7786             : 
    7787             :     using bits_type =
    7788             :         typename std::conditional<kPrecision == 24, uint32_t, uint64_t>::type;
    7789             : 
    7790             :     const uint64_t bits = reinterpret_bits<bits_type>(value);
    7791             :     const uint64_t E = bits >> (kPrecision - 1);
    7792             :     const uint64_t F = bits & (kHiddenBit - 1);
    7793             : 
    7794             :     const bool is_denormal = (E == 0);
    7795             :     const diyfp v = is_denormal
    7796             :                         ? diyfp(F, kMinExp)
    7797             :                         : diyfp(F + kHiddenBit, static_cast<int>(E) - kBias);
    7798             : 
    7799             :     // Compute the boundaries m- and m+ of the floating-point value
    7800             :     // v = f * 2^e.
    7801             :     //
    7802             :     // Determine v- and v+, the floating-point predecessor and successor if v,
    7803             :     // respectively.
    7804             :     //
    7805             :     //      v- = v - 2^e        if f != 2^(p-1) or e == e_min                (A)
    7806             :     //         = v - 2^(e-1)    if f == 2^(p-1) and e > e_min                (B)
    7807             :     //
    7808             :     //      v+ = v + 2^e
    7809             :     //
    7810             :     // Let m- = (v- + v) / 2 and m+ = (v + v+) / 2. All real numbers _strictly_
    7811             :     // between m- and m+ round to v, regardless of how the input rounding
    7812             :     // algorithm breaks ties.
    7813             :     //
    7814             :     //      ---+-------------+-------------+-------------+-------------+---  (A)
    7815             :     //         v-            m-            v             m+            v+
    7816             :     //
    7817             :     //      -----------------+------+------+-------------+-------------+---  (B)
    7818             :     //                       v-     m-     v             m+            v+
    7819             : 
    7820             :     const bool lower_boundary_is_closer = (F == 0 and E > 1);
    7821             :     const diyfp m_plus = diyfp(2 * v.f + 1, v.e - 1);
    7822             :     const diyfp m_minus = lower_boundary_is_closer
    7823             :                               ? diyfp(4 * v.f - 1, v.e - 2)  // (B)
    7824             :                               : diyfp(2 * v.f - 1, v.e - 1); // (A)
    7825             : 
    7826             :     // Determine the normalized w+ = m+.
    7827             :     const diyfp w_plus = diyfp::normalize(m_plus);
    7828             : 
    7829             :     // Determine w- = m- such that e_(w-) = e_(w+).
    7830             :     const diyfp w_minus = diyfp::normalize_to(m_minus, w_plus.e);
    7831             : 
    7832             :     return {diyfp::normalize(v), w_minus, w_plus};
    7833             : }
    7834             : 
    7835             : // Given normalized diyfp w, Grisu needs to find a (normalized) cached
    7836             : // power-of-ten c, such that the exponent of the product c * w = f * 2^e lies
    7837             : // within a certain range [alpha, gamma] (Definition 3.2 from [1])
    7838             : //
    7839             : //      alpha <= e = e_c + e_w + q <= gamma
    7840             : //
    7841             : // or
    7842             : //
    7843             : //      f_c * f_w * 2^alpha <= f_c 2^(e_c) * f_w 2^(e_w) * 2^q
    7844             : //                          <= f_c * f_w * 2^gamma
    7845             : //
    7846             : // Since c and w are normalized, i.e. 2^(q-1) <= f < 2^q, this implies
    7847             : //
    7848             : //      2^(q-1) * 2^(q-1) * 2^alpha <= c * w * 2^q < 2^q * 2^q * 2^gamma
    7849             : //
    7850             : // or
    7851             : //
    7852             : //      2^(q - 2 + alpha) <= c * w < 2^(q + gamma)
    7853             : //
    7854             : // The choice of (alpha,gamma) determines the size of the table and the form of
    7855             : // the digit generation procedure. Using (alpha,gamma)=(-60,-32) works out well
    7856             : // in practice:
    7857             : //
    7858             : // The idea is to cut the number c * w = f * 2^e into two parts, which can be
    7859             : // processed independently: An integral part p1, and a fractional part p2:
    7860             : //
    7861             : //      f * 2^e = ( (f div 2^-e) * 2^-e + (f mod 2^-e) ) * 2^e
    7862             : //              = (f div 2^-e) + (f mod 2^-e) * 2^e
    7863             : //              = p1 + p2 * 2^e
    7864             : //
    7865             : // The conversion of p1 into decimal form requires a series of divisions and
    7866             : // modulos by (a power of) 10. These operations are faster for 32-bit than for
    7867             : // 64-bit integers, so p1 should ideally fit into a 32-bit integer. This can be
    7868             : // achieved by choosing
    7869             : //
    7870             : //      -e >= 32   or   e <= -32 := gamma
    7871             : //
    7872             : // In order to convert the fractional part
    7873             : //
    7874             : //      p2 * 2^e = p2 / 2^-e = d[-1] / 10^1 + d[-2] / 10^2 + ...
    7875             : //
    7876             : // into decimal form, the fraction is repeatedly multiplied by 10 and the digits
    7877             : // d[-i] are extracted in order:
    7878             : //
    7879             : //      (10 * p2) div 2^-e = d[-1]
    7880             : //      (10 * p2) mod 2^-e = d[-2] / 10^1 + ...
    7881             : //
    7882             : // The multiplication by 10 must not overflow. It is sufficient to choose
    7883             : //
    7884             : //      10 * p2 < 16 * p2 = 2^4 * p2 <= 2^64.
    7885             : //
    7886             : // Since p2 = f mod 2^-e < 2^-e,
    7887             : //
    7888             : //      -e <= 60   or   e >= -60 := alpha
    7889             : 
    7890             : constexpr int kAlpha = -60;
    7891             : constexpr int kGamma = -32;
    7892             : 
    7893             : struct cached_power // c = f * 2^e ~= 10^k
    7894             : {
    7895             :     uint64_t f;
    7896             :     int e;
    7897             :     int k;
    7898             : };
    7899             : 
    7900             : /*!
    7901             : For a normalized diyfp w = f * 2^e, this function returns a (normalized) cached
    7902             : power-of-ten c = f_c * 2^e_c, such that the exponent of the product w * c
    7903             : satisfies (Definition 3.2 from [1])
    7904             : 
    7905             :      alpha <= e_c + e + q <= gamma.
    7906             : */
    7907             : inline cached_power get_cached_power_for_binary_exponent(int e)
    7908             : {
    7909             :     // Now
    7910             :     //
    7911             :     //      alpha <= e_c + e + q <= gamma                                    (1)
    7912             :     //      ==> f_c * 2^alpha <= c * 2^e * 2^q
    7913             :     //
    7914             :     // and since the c's are normalized, 2^(q-1) <= f_c,
    7915             :     //
    7916             :     //      ==> 2^(q - 1 + alpha) <= c * 2^(e + q)
    7917             :     //      ==> 2^(alpha - e - 1) <= c
    7918             :     //
    7919             :     // If c were an exakt power of ten, i.e. c = 10^k, one may determine k as
    7920             :     //
    7921             :     //      k = ceil( log_10( 2^(alpha - e - 1) ) )
    7922             :     //        = ceil( (alpha - e - 1) * log_10(2) )
    7923             :     //
    7924             :     // From the paper:
    7925             :     // "In theory the result of the procedure could be wrong since c is rounded,
    7926             :     //  and the computation itself is approximated [...]. In practice, however,
    7927             :     //  this simple function is sufficient."
    7928             :     //
    7929             :     // For IEEE double precision floating-point numbers converted into
    7930             :     // normalized diyfp's w = f * 2^e, with q = 64,
    7931             :     //
    7932             :     //      e >= -1022      (min IEEE exponent)
    7933             :     //           -52        (p - 1)
    7934             :     //           -52        (p - 1, possibly normalize denormal IEEE numbers)
    7935             :     //           -11        (normalize the diyfp)
    7936             :     //         = -1137
    7937             :     //
    7938             :     // and
    7939             :     //
    7940             :     //      e <= +1023      (max IEEE exponent)
    7941             :     //           -52        (p - 1)
    7942             :     //           -11        (normalize the diyfp)
    7943             :     //         = 960
    7944             :     //
    7945             :     // This binary exponent range [-1137,960] results in a decimal exponent
    7946             :     // range [-307,324]. One does not need to store a cached power for each
    7947             :     // k in this range. For each such k it suffices to find a cached power
    7948             :     // such that the exponent of the product lies in [alpha,gamma].
    7949             :     // This implies that the difference of the decimal exponents of adjacent
    7950             :     // table entries must be less than or equal to
    7951             :     //
    7952             :     //      floor( (gamma - alpha) * log_10(2) ) = 8.
    7953             :     //
    7954             :     // (A smaller distance gamma-alpha would require a larger table.)
    7955             : 
    7956             :     // NB:
    7957             :     // Actually this function returns c, such that -60 <= e_c + e + 64 <= -34.
    7958             : 
    7959             :     constexpr int kCachedPowersSize = 79;
    7960             :     constexpr int kCachedPowersMinDecExp = -300;
    7961             :     constexpr int kCachedPowersDecStep = 8;
    7962             : 
    7963             :     static constexpr cached_power kCachedPowers[] = {
    7964             :         {0xAB70FE17C79AC6CA, -1060, -300}, {0xFF77B1FCBEBCDC4F, -1034, -292},
    7965             :         {0xBE5691EF416BD60C, -1007, -284}, {0x8DD01FAD907FFC3C, -980, -276},
    7966             :         {0xD3515C2831559A83, -954, -268},  {0x9D71AC8FADA6C9B5, -927, -260},
    7967             :         {0xEA9C227723EE8BCB, -901, -252},  {0xAECC49914078536D, -874, -244},
    7968             :         {0x823C12795DB6CE57, -847, -236},  {0xC21094364DFB5637, -821, -228},
    7969             :         {0x9096EA6F3848984F, -794, -220},  {0xD77485CB25823AC7, -768, -212},
    7970             :         {0xA086CFCD97BF97F4, -741, -204},  {0xEF340A98172AACE5, -715, -196},
    7971             :         {0xB23867FB2A35B28E, -688, -188},  {0x84C8D4DFD2C63F3B, -661, -180},
    7972             :         {0xC5DD44271AD3CDBA, -635, -172},  {0x936B9FCEBB25C996, -608, -164},
    7973             :         {0xDBAC6C247D62A584, -582, -156},  {0xA3AB66580D5FDAF6, -555, -148},
    7974             :         {0xF3E2F893DEC3F126, -529, -140},  {0xB5B5ADA8AAFF80B8, -502, -132},
    7975             :         {0x87625F056C7C4A8B, -475, -124},  {0xC9BCFF6034C13053, -449, -116},
    7976             :         {0x964E858C91BA2655, -422, -108},  {0xDFF9772470297EBD, -396, -100},
    7977             :         {0xA6DFBD9FB8E5B88F, -369, -92},   {0xF8A95FCF88747D94, -343, -84},
    7978             :         {0xB94470938FA89BCF, -316, -76},   {0x8A08F0F8BF0F156B, -289, -68},
    7979             :         {0xCDB02555653131B6, -263, -60},   {0x993FE2C6D07B7FAC, -236, -52},
    7980             :         {0xE45C10C42A2B3B06, -210, -44},   {0xAA242499697392D3, -183, -36},
    7981             :         {0xFD87B5F28300CA0E, -157, -28},   {0xBCE5086492111AEB, -130, -20},
    7982             :         {0x8CBCCC096F5088CC, -103, -12},   {0xD1B71758E219652C, -77, -4},
    7983             :         {0x9C40000000000000, -50, 4},      {0xE8D4A51000000000, -24, 12},
    7984             :         {0xAD78EBC5AC620000, 3, 20},       {0x813F3978F8940984, 30, 28},
    7985             :         {0xC097CE7BC90715B3, 56, 36},      {0x8F7E32CE7BEA5C70, 83, 44},
    7986             :         {0xD5D238A4ABE98068, 109, 52},     {0x9F4F2726179A2245, 136, 60},
    7987             :         {0xED63A231D4C4FB27, 162, 68},     {0xB0DE65388CC8ADA8, 189, 76},
    7988             :         {0x83C7088E1AAB65DB, 216, 84},     {0xC45D1DF942711D9A, 242, 92},
    7989             :         {0x924D692CA61BE758, 269, 100},    {0xDA01EE641A708DEA, 295, 108},
    7990             :         {0xA26DA3999AEF774A, 322, 116},    {0xF209787BB47D6B85, 348, 124},
    7991             :         {0xB454E4A179DD1877, 375, 132},    {0x865B86925B9BC5C2, 402, 140},
    7992             :         {0xC83553C5C8965D3D, 428, 148},    {0x952AB45CFA97A0B3, 455, 156},
    7993             :         {0xDE469FBD99A05FE3, 481, 164},    {0xA59BC234DB398C25, 508, 172},
    7994             :         {0xF6C69A72A3989F5C, 534, 180},    {0xB7DCBF5354E9BECE, 561, 188},
    7995             :         {0x88FCF317F22241E2, 588, 196},    {0xCC20CE9BD35C78A5, 614, 204},
    7996             :         {0x98165AF37B2153DF, 641, 212},    {0xE2A0B5DC971F303A, 667, 220},
    7997             :         {0xA8D9D1535CE3B396, 694, 228},    {0xFB9B7CD9A4A7443C, 720, 236},
    7998             :         {0xBB764C4CA7A44410, 747, 244},    {0x8BAB8EEFB6409C1A, 774, 252},
    7999             :         {0xD01FEF10A657842C, 800, 260},    {0x9B10A4E5E9913129, 827, 268},
    8000             :         {0xE7109BFBA19C0C9D, 853, 276},    {0xAC2820D9623BF429, 880, 284},
    8001             :         {0x80444B5E7AA7CF85, 907, 292},    {0xBF21E44003ACDD2D, 933, 300},
    8002             :         {0x8E679C2F5E44FF8F, 960, 308},    {0xD433179D9C8CB841, 986, 316},
    8003             :         {0x9E19DB92B4E31BA9, 1013, 324},
    8004             :     };
    8005             : 
    8006             :     // This computation gives exactly the same results for k as
    8007             :     //      k = ceil((kAlpha - e - 1) * 0.30102999566398114)
    8008             :     // for |e| <= 1500, but doesn't require floating-point operations.
    8009             :     // NB: log_10(2) ~= 78913 / 2^18
    8010             :     assert(e >= -1500);
    8011             :     assert(e <= 1500);
    8012             :     const int f = kAlpha - e - 1;
    8013             :     const int k = (f * 78913) / (1 << 18) + (f > 0);
    8014             : 
    8015             :     const int index =
    8016             :         (-kCachedPowersMinDecExp + k + (kCachedPowersDecStep - 1)) /
    8017             :         kCachedPowersDecStep;
    8018             :     assert(index >= 0);
    8019             :     assert(index < kCachedPowersSize);
    8020             :     static_cast<void>(kCachedPowersSize); // Fix warning.
    8021             : 
    8022             :     const cached_power cached = kCachedPowers[index];
    8023             :     assert(kAlpha <= cached.e + e + 64);
    8024             :     assert(kGamma >= cached.e + e + 64);
    8025             : 
    8026             :     return cached;
    8027             : }
    8028             : 
    8029             : /*!
    8030             : For n != 0, returns k, such that pow10 := 10^(k-1) <= n < 10^k.
    8031             : For n == 0, returns 1 and sets pow10 := 1.
    8032             : */
    8033             : inline int find_largest_pow10(const uint32_t n, uint32_t& pow10)
    8034             : {
    8035             :     // LCOV_EXCL_START
    8036             :     if (n >= 1000000000)
    8037             :     {
    8038             :         pow10 = 1000000000;
    8039             :         return 10;
    8040             :     }
    8041             :     // LCOV_EXCL_STOP
    8042             :     else if (n >= 100000000)
    8043             :     {
    8044             :         pow10 = 100000000;
    8045             :         return 9;
    8046             :     }
    8047             :     else if (n >= 10000000)
    8048             :     {
    8049             :         pow10 = 10000000;
    8050             :         return 8;
    8051             :     }
    8052             :     else if (n >= 1000000)
    8053             :     {
    8054             :         pow10 = 1000000;
    8055             :         return 7;
    8056             :     }
    8057             :     else if (n >= 100000)
    8058             :     {
    8059             :         pow10 = 100000;
    8060             :         return 6;
    8061             :     }
    8062             :     else if (n >= 10000)
    8063             :     {
    8064             :         pow10 = 10000;
    8065             :         return 5;
    8066             :     }
    8067             :     else if (n >= 1000)
    8068             :     {
    8069             :         pow10 = 1000;
    8070             :         return 4;
    8071             :     }
    8072             :     else if (n >= 100)
    8073             :     {
    8074             :         pow10 = 100;
    8075             :         return 3;
    8076             :     }
    8077             :     else if (n >= 10)
    8078             :     {
    8079             :         pow10 = 10;
    8080             :         return 2;
    8081             :     }
    8082             :     else
    8083             :     {
    8084             :         pow10 = 1;
    8085             :         return 1;
    8086             :     }
    8087             : }
    8088             : 
    8089             : inline void grisu2_round(char* buf, int len, uint64_t dist, uint64_t delta,
    8090             :                          uint64_t rest, uint64_t ten_k)
    8091             : {
    8092             :     assert(len >= 1);
    8093             :     assert(dist <= delta);
    8094             :     assert(rest <= delta);
    8095             :     assert(ten_k > 0);
    8096             : 
    8097             :     //               <--------------------------- delta ---->
    8098             :     //                                  <---- dist --------->
    8099             :     // --------------[------------------+-------------------]--------------
    8100             :     //               M-                 w                   M+
    8101             :     //
    8102             :     //                                  ten_k
    8103             :     //                                <------>
    8104             :     //                                       <---- rest ---->
    8105             :     // --------------[------------------+----+--------------]--------------
    8106             :     //                                  w    V
    8107             :     //                                       = buf * 10^k
    8108             :     //
    8109             :     // ten_k represents a unit-in-the-last-place in the decimal representation
    8110             :     // stored in buf.
    8111             :     // Decrement buf by ten_k while this takes buf closer to w.
    8112             : 
    8113             :     // The tests are written in this order to avoid overflow in unsigned
    8114             :     // integer arithmetic.
    8115             : 
    8116             :     while (rest < dist and delta - rest >= ten_k and
    8117             :            (rest + ten_k < dist or dist - rest > rest + ten_k - dist))
    8118             :     {
    8119             :         assert(buf[len - 1] != '0');
    8120             :         buf[len - 1]--;
    8121             :         rest += ten_k;
    8122             :     }
    8123             : }
    8124             : 
    8125             : /*!
    8126             : Generates V = buffer * 10^decimal_exponent, such that M- <= V <= M+.
    8127             : M- and M+ must be normalized and share the same exponent -60 <= e <= -32.
    8128             : */
    8129             : inline void grisu2_digit_gen(char* buffer, int& length, int& decimal_exponent,
    8130             :                              diyfp M_minus, diyfp w, diyfp M_plus)
    8131             : {
    8132             :     static_assert(kAlpha >= -60, "internal error");
    8133             :     static_assert(kGamma <= -32, "internal error");
    8134             : 
    8135             :     // Generates the digits (and the exponent) of a decimal floating-point
    8136             :     // number V = buffer * 10^decimal_exponent in the range [M-, M+]. The
    8137             :     // diyfp's
    8138             :     // w, M- and M+ share the same exponent e, which satisfies alpha <= e <=
    8139             :     // gamma.
    8140             :     //
    8141             :     //               <--------------------------- delta ---->
    8142             :     //                                  <---- dist --------->
    8143             :     // --------------[------------------+-------------------]--------------
    8144             :     //               M-                 w                   M+
    8145             :     //
    8146             :     // Grisu2 generates the digits of M+ from left to right and stops as soon as
    8147             :     // V is in [M-,M+].
    8148             : 
    8149             :     assert(M_plus.e >= kAlpha);
    8150             :     assert(M_plus.e <= kGamma);
    8151             : 
    8152             :     uint64_t delta = diyfp::sub(M_plus, M_minus).f; // (significand of (M+ -
    8153             :                                                     // M-), implicit exponent is
    8154             :                                                     // e)
    8155             :     uint64_t dist = diyfp::sub(M_plus, w).f; // (significand of (M+ - w ),
    8156             :                                              // implicit exponent is e)
    8157             : 
    8158             :     // Split M+ = f * 2^e into two parts p1 and p2 (note: e < 0):
    8159             :     //
    8160             :     //      M+ = f * 2^e
    8161             :     //         = ((f div 2^-e) * 2^-e + (f mod 2^-e)) * 2^e
    8162             :     //         = ((p1        ) * 2^-e + (p2        )) * 2^e
    8163             :     //         = p1 + p2 * 2^e
    8164             : 
    8165             :     const diyfp one(uint64_t{1} << -M_plus.e, M_plus.e);
    8166             : 
    8167             :     uint32_t p1 = static_cast<uint32_t>(M_plus.f >> -one.e); // p1 = f div 2^-e
    8168             :                                                              // (Since -e >= 32,
    8169             :                                                              // p1 fits into a
    8170             :                                                              // 32-bit int.)
    8171             :     uint64_t p2 = M_plus.f & (one.f - 1);                    // p2 = f mod 2^-e
    8172             : 
    8173             :     // 1)
    8174             :     //
    8175             :     // Generate the digits of the integral part p1 = d[n-1]...d[1]d[0]
    8176             : 
    8177             :     assert(p1 > 0);
    8178             : 
    8179             :     uint32_t pow10;
    8180             :     const int k = find_largest_pow10(p1, pow10);
    8181             : 
    8182             :     //      10^(k-1) <= p1 < 10^k, pow10 = 10^(k-1)
    8183             :     //
    8184             :     //      p1 = (p1 div 10^(k-1)) * 10^(k-1) + (p1 mod 10^(k-1))
    8185             :     //         = (d[k-1]         ) * 10^(k-1) + (p1 mod 10^(k-1))
    8186             :     //
    8187             :     //      M+ = p1                                             + p2 * 2^e
    8188             :     //         = d[k-1] * 10^(k-1) + (p1 mod 10^(k-1))          + p2 * 2^e
    8189             :     //         = d[k-1] * 10^(k-1) + ((p1 mod 10^(k-1)) * 2^-e + p2) * 2^e
    8190             :     //         = d[k-1] * 10^(k-1) + (                         rest) * 2^e
    8191             :     //
    8192             :     // Now generate the digits d[n] of p1 from left to right (n = k-1,...,0)
    8193             :     //
    8194             :     //      p1 = d[k-1]...d[n] * 10^n + d[n-1]...d[0]
    8195             :     //
    8196             :     // but stop as soon as
    8197             :     //
    8198             :     //      rest * 2^e = (d[n-1]...d[0] * 2^-e + p2) * 2^e <= delta * 2^e
    8199             : 
    8200             :     int n = k;
    8201             :     while (n > 0)
    8202             :     {
    8203             :         // Invariants:
    8204             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^n + (p1 + p2 * 2^e)    (buffer = 0 for n = k)
    8205             :         //      pow10 = 10^(n-1) <= p1 < 10^n
    8206             :         //
    8207             :         const uint32_t d = p1 / pow10; // d = p1 div 10^(n-1)
    8208             :         const uint32_t r = p1 % pow10; // r = p1 mod 10^(n-1)
    8209             :         //
    8210             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^n + (d * 10^(n-1) + r) + p2 * 2^e
    8211             :         //         = (buffer * 10 + d) * 10^(n-1) + (r + p2 * 2^e)
    8212             :         //
    8213             :         assert(d <= 9);
    8214             :         buffer[length++] =
    8215             :             static_cast<char>('0' + d); // buffer := buffer * 10 + d
    8216             :         //
    8217             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^(n-1) + (r + p2 * 2^e)
    8218             :         //
    8219             :         p1 = r;
    8220             :         n--;
    8221             :         //
    8222             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^n + (p1 + p2 * 2^e)
    8223             :         //      pow10 = 10^n
    8224             :         //
    8225             : 
    8226             :         // Now check if enough digits have been generated.
    8227             :         // Compute
    8228             :         //
    8229             :         //      p1 + p2 * 2^e = (p1 * 2^-e + p2) * 2^e = rest * 2^e
    8230             :         //
    8231             :         // Note:
    8232             :         // Since rest and delta share the same exponent e, it suffices to
    8233             :         // compare the significands.
    8234             :         const uint64_t rest = (uint64_t{p1} << -one.e) + p2;
    8235             :         if (rest <= delta)
    8236             :         {
    8237             :             // V = buffer * 10^n, with M- <= V <= M+.
    8238             : 
    8239             :             decimal_exponent += n;
    8240             : 
    8241             :             // We may now just stop. But instead look if the buffer could be
    8242             :             // decremented to bring V closer to w.
    8243             :             //
    8244             :             // pow10 = 10^n is now 1 ulp in the decimal representation V.
    8245             :             // The rounding procedure works with diyfp's with an implicit
    8246             :             // exponent of e.
    8247             :             //
    8248             :             //      10^n = (10^n * 2^-e) * 2^e = ulp * 2^e
    8249             :             //
    8250             :             const uint64_t ten_n = uint64_t{pow10} << -one.e;
    8251             :             grisu2_round(buffer, length, dist, delta, rest, ten_n);
    8252             : 
    8253             :             return;
    8254             :         }
    8255             : 
    8256             :         pow10 /= 10;
    8257             :         //
    8258             :         //      pow10 = 10^(n-1) <= p1 < 10^n
    8259             :         // Invariants restored.
    8260             :     }
    8261             : 
    8262             :     // 2)
    8263             :     //
    8264             :     // The digits of the integral part have been generated:
    8265             :     //
    8266             :     //      M+ = d[k-1]...d[1]d[0] + p2 * 2^e
    8267             :     //         = buffer            + p2 * 2^e
    8268             :     //
    8269             :     // Now generate the digits of the fractional part p2 * 2^e.
    8270             :     //
    8271             :     // Note:
    8272             :     // No decimal point is generated: the exponent is adjusted instead.
    8273             :     //
    8274             :     // p2 actually represents the fraction
    8275             :     //
    8276             :     //      p2 * 2^e
    8277             :     //          = p2 / 2^-e
    8278             :     //          = d[-1] / 10^1 + d[-2] / 10^2 + ...
    8279             :     //
    8280             :     // Now generate the digits d[-m] of p1 from left to right (m = 1,2,...)
    8281             :     //
    8282             :     //      p2 * 2^e = d[-1]d[-2]...d[-m] * 10^-m
    8283             :     //                      + 10^-m * (d[-m-1] / 10^1 + d[-m-2] / 10^2 + ...)
    8284             :     //
    8285             :     // using
    8286             :     //
    8287             :     //      10^m * p2 = ((10^m * p2) div 2^-e) * 2^-e + ((10^m * p2) mod 2^-e)
    8288             :     //                = (                   d) * 2^-e + (                   r)
    8289             :     //
    8290             :     // or
    8291             :     //      10^m * p2 * 2^e = d + r * 2^e
    8292             :     //
    8293             :     // i.e.
    8294             :     //
    8295             :     //      M+ = buffer + p2 * 2^e
    8296             :     //         = buffer + 10^-m * (d + r * 2^e)
    8297             :     //         = (buffer * 10^m + d) * 10^-m + 10^-m * r * 2^e
    8298             :     //
    8299             :     // and stop as soon as 10^-m * r * 2^e <= delta * 2^e
    8300             : 
    8301             :     assert(p2 > delta);
    8302             : 
    8303             :     int m = 0;
    8304             :     for (;;)
    8305             :     {
    8306             :         // Invariant:
    8307             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (d[-m-1] / 10 + d[-m-2] / 10^2 +
    8308             :         //      ...) * 2^e
    8309             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (p2 ) * 2^e
    8310             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * (10 * p2) ) * 2^e
    8311             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * ((10*p2 div 2^-e) * 2^-e +
    8312             :         //         (10*p2 mod 2^-e)) * 2^e
    8313             :         //
    8314             :         assert(p2 <= UINT64_MAX / 10);
    8315             :         p2 *= 10;
    8316             :         const uint64_t d = p2 >> -one.e;     // d = (10 * p2) div 2^-e
    8317             :         const uint64_t r = p2 & (one.f - 1); // r = (10 * p2) mod 2^-e
    8318             :         //
    8319             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * (d * 2^-e + r) * 2^e
    8320             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * (d + r * 2^e))
    8321             :         //         = (buffer * 10 + d) * 10^(-m-1) + 10^(-m-1) * r * 2^e
    8322             :         //
    8323             :         assert(d <= 9);
    8324             :         buffer[length++] =
    8325             :             static_cast<char>('0' + d); // buffer := buffer * 10 + d
    8326             :         //
    8327             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^(-m-1) + 10^(-m-1) * r * 2^e
    8328             :         //
    8329             :         p2 = r;
    8330             :         m++;
    8331             :         //
    8332             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * p2 * 2^e
    8333             :         // Invariant restored.
    8334             : 
    8335             :         // Check if enough digits have been generated.
    8336             :         //
    8337             :         //      10^-m * p2 * 2^e <= delta * 2^e
    8338             :         //              p2 * 2^e <= 10^m * delta * 2^e
    8339             :         //                    p2 <= 10^m * delta
    8340             :         delta *= 10;
    8341             :         dist *= 10;
    8342             :         if (p2 <= delta)
    8343             :         {
    8344             :             break;
    8345             :         }
    8346             :     }
    8347             : 
    8348             :     // V = buffer * 10^-m, with M- <= V <= M+.
    8349             : 
    8350             :     decimal_exponent -= m;
    8351             : 
    8352             :     // 1 ulp in the decimal representation is now 10^-m.
    8353             :     // Since delta and dist are now scaled by 10^m, we need to do the
    8354             :     // same with ulp in order to keep the units in sync.
    8355             :     //
    8356             :     //      10^m * 10^-m = 1 = 2^-e * 2^e = ten_m * 2^e
    8357             :     //
    8358             :     const uint64_t ten_m = one.f;
    8359             :     grisu2_round(buffer, length, dist, delta, p2, ten_m);
    8360             : 
    8361             :     // By construction this algorithm generates the shortest possible decimal
    8362             :     // number (Loitsch, Theorem 6.2) which rounds back to w.
    8363             :     // For an input number of precision p, at least
    8364             :     //
    8365             :     //      N = 1 + ceil(p * log_10(2))
    8366             :     //
    8367             :     // decimal digits are sufficient to identify all binary floating-point
    8368             :     // numbers (Matula, "In-and-Out conversions").
    8369             :     // This implies that the algorithm does not produce more than N decimal
    8370             :     // digits.
    8371             :     //
    8372             :     //      N = 17 for p = 53 (IEEE double precision)
    8373             :     //      N = 9  for p = 24 (IEEE single precision)
    8374             : }
    8375             : 
    8376             : /*!
    8377             : v = buf * 10^decimal_exponent
    8378             : len is the length of the buffer (number of decimal digits)
    8379             : The buffer must be large enough, i.e. >= max_digits10.
    8380             : */
    8381             : inline void grisu2(char* buf, int& len, int& decimal_exponent, diyfp m_minus,
    8382             :                    diyfp v, diyfp m_plus)
    8383             : {
    8384             :     assert(m_plus.e == m_minus.e);
    8385             :     assert(m_plus.e == v.e);
    8386             : 
    8387             :     //  --------(-----------------------+-----------------------)--------    (A)
    8388             :     //          m-                      v                       m+
    8389             :     //
    8390             :     //  --------------------(-----------+-----------------------)--------    (B)
    8391             :     //                      m-          v                       m+
    8392             :     //
    8393             :     // First scale v (and m- and m+) such that the exponent is in the range
    8394             :     // [alpha, gamma].
    8395             : 
    8396             :     const cached_power cached = get_cached_power_for_binary_exponent(m_plus.e);
    8397             : 
    8398             :     const diyfp c_minus_k(cached.f, cached.e); // = c ~= 10^-k
    8399             : 
    8400             :     // The exponent of the products is = v.e + c_minus_k.e + q and is in the
    8401             :     // range [alpha,gamma]
    8402             :     const diyfp w = diyfp::mul(v, c_minus_k);
    8403             :     const diyfp w_minus = diyfp::mul(m_minus, c_minus_k);
    8404             :     const diyfp w_plus = diyfp::mul(m_plus, c_minus_k);
    8405             : 
    8406             :     //  ----(---+---)---------------(---+---)---------------(---+---)----
    8407             :     //          w-                      w                       w+
    8408             :     //          = c*m-                  = c*v                   = c*m+
    8409             :     //
    8410             :     // diyfp::mul rounds its result and c_minus_k is approximated too. w, w- and
    8411             :     // w+ are now off by a small amount.
    8412             :     // In fact:
    8413             :     //
    8414             :     //      w - v * 10^k < 1 ulp
    8415             :     //
    8416             :     // To account for this inaccuracy, add resp. subtract 1 ulp.
    8417             :     //
    8418             :     //  --------+---[---------------(---+---)---------------]---+--------
    8419             :     //          w-  M-                  w                   M+  w+
    8420             :     //
    8421             :     // Now any number in [M-, M+] (bounds included) will round to w when input,
    8422             :     // regardless of how the input rounding algorithm breaks ties.
    8423             :     //
    8424             :     // And digit_gen generates the shortest possible such number in [M-, M+].
    8425             :     // Note that this does not mean that Grisu2 always generates the shortest
    8426             :     // possible number in the interval (m-, m+).
    8427             :     const diyfp M_minus(w_minus.f + 1, w_minus.e);
    8428             :     const diyfp M_plus(w_plus.f - 1, w_plus.e);
    8429             : 
    8430             :     decimal_exponent = -cached.k; // = -(-k) = k
    8431             : 
    8432             :     grisu2_digit_gen(buf, len, decimal_exponent, M_minus, w, M_plus);
    8433             : }
    8434             : 
    8435             : /*!
    8436             : v = buf * 10^decimal_exponent
    8437             : len is the length of the buffer (number of decimal digits)
    8438             : The buffer must be large enough, i.e. >= max_digits10.
    8439             : */
    8440             : template <typename FloatType>
    8441             : void grisu2(char* buf, int& len, int& decimal_exponent, FloatType value)
    8442             : {
    8443             :     static_assert(diyfp::kPrecision >=
    8444             :                       std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::digits + 3,
    8445             :                   "internal error: not enough precision");
    8446             : 
    8447             :     assert(std::isfinite(value));
    8448             :     assert(value > 0);
    8449             : 
    8450             : // If the neighbors (and boundaries) of 'value' are always computed for
    8451             : // double-precision
    8452             : // numbers, all float's can be recovered using strtod (and strtof). However, the
    8453             : // resulting
    8454             : // decimal representations are not exactly "short".
    8455             : //
    8456             : // The documentation for 'std::to_chars'
    8457             : // (http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/to_chars)
    8458             : // says "value is converted to a string as if by std::sprintf in the default
    8459             : // ("C") locale"
    8460             : // and since sprintf promotes float's to double's, I think this is exactly what
    8461             : // 'std::to_chars'
    8462             : // does.
    8463             : // On the other hand, the documentation for 'std::to_chars' requires that
    8464             : // "parsing the
    8465             : // representation using the corresponding std::from_chars function recovers
    8466             : // value exactly". That
    8467             : // indicates that single precision floating-point numbers should be recovered
    8468             : // using
    8469             : // 'std::strtof'.
    8470             : //
    8471             : // NB: If the neighbors are computed for single-precision numbers, there is a
    8472             : // single float
    8473             : //     (7.0385307e-26f) which can't be recovered using strtod. The resulting
    8474             : //     double precision
    8475             : //     value is off by 1 ulp.
    8476             : #if 0
    8477             :     const boundaries w = compute_boundaries(static_cast<double>(value));
    8478             : #else
    8479             :     const boundaries w = compute_boundaries(value);
    8480             : #endif
    8481             : 
    8482             :     grisu2(buf, len, decimal_exponent, w.minus, w.w, w.plus);
    8483             : }
    8484             : 
    8485             : /*!
    8486             : @brief appends a decimal representation of e to buf
    8487             : @return a pointer to the element following the exponent.
    8488             : @pre -1000 < e < 1000
    8489             : */
    8490             : inline char* append_exponent(char* buf, int e)
    8491             : {
    8492             :     assert(e > -1000);
    8493             :     assert(e < 1000);
    8494             : 
    8495             :     if (e < 0)
    8496             :     {
    8497             :         e = -e;
    8498             :         *buf++ = '-';
    8499             :     }
    8500             :     else
    8501             :     {
    8502             :         *buf++ = '+';
    8503             :     }
    8504             : 
    8505             :     uint32_t k = static_cast<uint32_t>(e);
    8506             :     if (k < 10)
    8507             :     {
    8508             :         // Always print at least two digits in the exponent.
    8509             :         // This is for compatibility with printf("%g").
    8510             :         *buf++ = '0';
    8511             :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k);
    8512             :     }
    8513             :     else if (k < 100)
    8514             :     {
    8515             :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k / 10);
    8516             :         k %= 10;
    8517             :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k);
    8518             :     }
    8519             :     else
    8520             :     {
    8521             :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k / 100);
    8522             :         k %= 100;
    8523             :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k / 10);
    8524             :         k %= 10;
    8525             :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k);
    8526             :     }
    8527             : 
    8528             :     return buf;
    8529             : }
    8530             : 
    8531             : /*!
    8532             : @brief prettify v = buf * 10^decimal_exponent
    8533             : 
    8534             : If v is in the range [10^min_exp, 10^max_exp) it will be printed in fixed-point
    8535             : notation. Otherwise it will be printed in exponential notation.
    8536             : 
    8537             : @pre min_exp < 0
    8538             : @pre max_exp > 0
    8539             : */
    8540             : inline char* format_buffer(char* buf, int len, int decimal_exponent,
    8541             :                            int min_exp, int max_exp)
    8542             : {
    8543             :     assert(min_exp < 0);
    8544             :     assert(max_exp > 0);
    8545             : 
    8546             :     const int k = len;
    8547             :     const int n = len + decimal_exponent;
    8548             : 
    8549             :     // v = buf * 10^(n-k)
    8550             :     // k is the length of the buffer (number of decimal digits)
    8551             :     // n is the position of the decimal point relative to the start of the
    8552             :     // buffer.
    8553             : 
    8554             :     if (k <= n and n <= max_exp)
    8555             :     {
    8556             :         // digits[000]
    8557             :         // len <= max_exp + 2
    8558             : 
    8559             :         std::memset(buf + k, '0', static_cast<size_t>(n - k));
    8560             :         // Make it look like a floating-point number (#362, #378)
    8561             :         buf[n + 0] = '.';
    8562             :         buf[n + 1] = '0';
    8563             :         return buf + (n + 2);
    8564             :     }
    8565             : 
    8566             :     if (0 < n and n <= max_exp)
    8567             :     {
    8568             :         // dig.its
    8569             :         // len <= max_digits10 + 1
    8570             : 
    8571             :         assert(k > n);
    8572             : 
    8573             :         std::memmove(buf + (n + 1), buf + n, static_cast<size_t>(k - n));
    8574             :         buf[n] = '.';
    8575             :         return buf + (k + 1);
    8576             :     }
    8577             : 
    8578             :     if (min_exp < n and n <= 0)
    8579             :     {
    8580             :         // 0.[000]digits
    8581             :         // len <= 2 + (-min_exp - 1) + max_digits10
    8582             : 
    8583             :         std::memmove(buf + (2 + -n), buf, static_cast<size_t>(k));
    8584             :         buf[0] = '0';
    8585             :         buf[1] = '.';
    8586             :         std::memset(buf + 2, '0', static_cast<size_t>(-n));
    8587             :         return buf + (2 + (-n) + k);
    8588             :     }
    8589             : 
    8590             :     if (k == 1)
    8591             :     {
    8592             :         // dE+123
    8593             :         // len <= 1 + 5
    8594             : 
    8595             :         buf += 1;
    8596             :     }
    8597             :     else
    8598             :     {
    8599             :         // d.igitsE+123
    8600             :         // len <= max_digits10 + 1 + 5
    8601             : 
    8602             :         std::memmove(buf + 2, buf + 1, static_cast<size_t>(k - 1));
    8603             :         buf[1] = '.';
    8604             :         buf += 1 + k;
    8605             :     }
    8606             : 
    8607             :     *buf++ = 'e';
    8608             :     return append_exponent(buf, n - 1);
    8609             : }
    8610             : 
    8611             : } // namespace dtoa_impl
    8612             : 
    8613             : /*!
    8614             : @brief generates a decimal representation of the floating-point number value in
    8615             : [first, last).
    8616             : 
    8617             : The format of the resulting decimal representation is similar to printf's %g
    8618             : format. Returns an iterator pointing past-the-end of the decimal representation.
    8619             : 
    8620             : @note The input number must be finite, i.e. NaN's and Inf's are not supported.
    8621             : @note The buffer must be large enough.
    8622             : @note The result is NOT null-terminated.
    8623             : */
    8624             : template <typename FloatType>
    8625             : char* to_chars(char* first, char* last, FloatType value)
    8626             : {
    8627             :     static_cast<void>(last); // maybe unused - fix warning
    8628             :     assert(std::isfinite(value));
    8629             : 
    8630             :     // Use signbit(value) instead of (value < 0) since signbit works for -0.
    8631             :     if (std::signbit(value))
    8632             :     {
    8633             :         value = -value;
    8634             :         *first++ = '-';
    8635             :     }
    8636             : 
    8637             :     if (value == 0) // +-0
    8638             :     {
    8639             :         *first++ = '0';
    8640             :         // Make it look like a floating-point number (#362, #378)
    8641             :         *first++ = '.';
    8642             :         *first++ = '0';
    8643             :         return first;
    8644             :     }
    8645             : 
    8646             :     assert(last - first >= std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_digits10);
    8647             : 
    8648             :     // Compute v = buffer * 10^decimal_exponent.
    8649             :     // The decimal digits are stored in the buffer, which needs to be
    8650             :     // interpreted
    8651             :     // as an unsigned decimal integer.
    8652             :     // len is the length of the buffer, i.e. the number of decimal digits.
    8653             :     int len = 0;
    8654             :     int decimal_exponent = 0;
    8655             :     dtoa_impl::grisu2(first, len, decimal_exponent, value);
    8656             : 
    8657             :     assert(len <= std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_digits10);
    8658             : 
    8659             :     // Format the buffer like printf("%.*g", prec, value)
    8660             :     constexpr int kMinExp = -4;
    8661             :     // Use digits10 here to increase compatibility with version 2.
    8662             :     constexpr int kMaxExp = std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::digits10;
    8663             : 
    8664             :     assert(last - first >= kMaxExp + 2);
    8665             :     assert(last - first >=
    8666             :            2 + (-kMinExp - 1) + std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_digits10);
    8667             :     assert(last - first >= std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_digits10 + 6);
    8668             : 
    8669             :     return dtoa_impl::format_buffer(first, len, decimal_exponent, kMinExp,
    8670             :                                     kMaxExp);
    8671             : }
    8672             : 
    8673             : } // namespace detail
    8674             : } // namespace nlohmann
    8675             : 
    8676             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/macro_scope.hpp>
    8677             : 
    8678             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/meta.hpp>
    8679             : 
    8680             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/output/output_adapters.hpp>
    8681             : 
    8682             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/value_t.hpp>
    8683             : 
    8684             : namespace brion_nlohmann
    8685             : {
    8686             : namespace detail
    8687             : {
    8688             : ///////////////////
    8689             : // serialization //
    8690             : ///////////////////
    8691             : 
    8692             : template <typename BasicJsonType>
    8693             : class serializer
    8694             : {
    8695             :     using string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
    8696             :     using number_float_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t;
    8697             :     using number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
    8698             :     using number_unsigned_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
    8699             :     static constexpr uint8_t UTF8_ACCEPT = 0;
    8700             :     static constexpr uint8_t UTF8_REJECT = 1;
    8701             : 
    8702             : public:
    8703             :     /*!
    8704             :     @param[in] s  output stream to serialize to
    8705             :     @param[in] ichar  indentation character to use
    8706             :     */
    8707             :     serializer(output_adapter_t<char> s, const char ichar)
    8708             :         : o(std::move(s))
    8709             :         , loc(std::localeconv())
    8710             :         , thousands_sep(loc->thousands_sep == nullptr ? '\0'
    8711             :                                                       : *(loc->thousands_sep))
    8712             :         , decimal_point(loc->decimal_point == nullptr ? '\0'
    8713             :                                                       : *(loc->decimal_point))
    8714             :         , indent_char(ichar)
    8715             :         , indent_string(512, indent_char)
    8716             :     {
    8717             :     }
    8718             : 
    8719             :     // delete because of pointer members
    8720             :     serializer(const serializer&) = delete;
    8721             :     serializer& operator=(const serializer&) = delete;
    8722             : 
    8723             :     /*!
    8724             :     @brief internal implementation of the serialization function
    8725             : 
    8726             :     This function is called by the public member function dump and organizes
    8727             :     the serialization internally. The indentation level is propagated as
    8728             :     additional parameter. In case of arrays and objects, the function is
    8729             :     called recursively.
    8730             : 
    8731             :     - strings and object keys are escaped using `escape_string()`
    8732             :     - integer numbers are converted implicitly via `operator<<`
    8733             :     - floating-point numbers are converted to a string using `"%g"` format
    8734             : 
    8735             :     @param[in] val             value to serialize
    8736             :     @param[in] pretty_print    whether the output shall be pretty-printed
    8737             :     @param[in] indent_step     the indent level
    8738             :     @param[in] current_indent  the current indent level (only used internally)
    8739             :     */
    8740             :     void dump(const BasicJsonType& val, const bool pretty_print,
    8741             :               const bool ensure_ascii, const unsigned int indent_step,
    8742             :               const unsigned int current_indent = 0)
    8743             :     {
    8744             :         switch (val.m_type)
    8745             :         {
    8746             :         case value_t::object:
    8747             :         {
    8748             :             if (val.m_value.object->empty())
    8749             :             {
    8750             :                 o->write_characters("{}", 2);
    8751             :                 return;
    8752             :             }
    8753             : 
    8754             :             if (pretty_print)
    8755             :             {
    8756             :                 o->write_characters("{\n", 2);
    8757             : 
    8758             :                 // variable to hold indentation for recursive calls
    8759             :                 const auto new_indent = current_indent + indent_step;
