    9928             : 
    9929             :     /*!
    9930             :     @brief split the string input to reference tokens
    9931             : 
    9932             :     @note This function is only called by the json_pointer constructor.
    9933             :           All exceptions below are documented there.
    9934             : 
    9935             :     @throw parse_error.107  if the pointer is not empty or begins with '/'
    9936             :     @throw parse_error.108  if character '~' is not followed by '0' or '1'
    9937             :     */
    9938         121 :     static std::vector<std::string> split(const std::string& reference_string)
    9939             :     {
    9940         121 :         std::vector<std::string> result;
    9941             : 
    9942             :         // special case: empty reference string -> no reference tokens
    9943         121 :         if (reference_string.empty())
    9944             :         {
    9945           0 :             return result;
    9946             :         }
    9947             : 
    9948             :         // check if nonempty reference string begins with slash
    9949         121 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(reference_string[0] != '/'))
    9950             :         {
    9951           0 :             JSON_THROW(detail::parse_error::create(
    9952             :                 107, 1,
    9953             :                 "JSON pointer must be empty or begin with '/' - was: '" +
    9954             :                     reference_string + "'"));
    9955             :         }
    9956             : 
    9957             :         // extract the reference tokens:
    9958             :         // - slash: position of the last read slash (or end of string)
    9959             :         // - start: position after the previous slash
    9960         363 :         for (
    9961             :             // search for the first slash after the first character
    9962         121 :             std::size_t slash = reference_string.find_first_of('/', 1),
    9963             :                         // set the beginning of the first reference token
    9964         121 :             start = 1;
    9965             :             // we can stop if start == string::npos+1 = 0
    9966         484 :             start != 0;
    9967             :             // set the beginning of the next reference token
    9968             :             // (will eventually be 0 if slash == std::string::npos)
    9969             :             start = slash + 1,
    9970             :                         // find next slash
    9971             :             slash = reference_string.find_first_of('/', start))
    9972             :         {
    9973             :             // use the text between the beginning of the reference token
    9974             :             // (start) and the last slash (slash).
    9975             :             auto reference_token =
    9976         726 :                 reference_string.substr(start, slash - start);
    9977             : 
    9978             :             // check reference tokens are properly escaped
    9979         363 :             for (std::size_t pos = reference_token.find_first_of('~');
    9980         363 :                  pos != std::string::npos;
    9981           0 :                  pos = reference_token.find_first_of('~', pos + 1))
    9982             :             {
    9983           0 :                 assert(reference_token[pos] == '~');
    9984             : 
    9985             :                 // ~ must be followed by 0 or 1
    9986           0 :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos == reference_token.size() - 1 or
    9987             :                                   (reference_token[pos + 1] != '0' and
    9988             :                                    reference_token[pos + 1] != '1')))
    9989             :                 {
    9990           0 :                     JSON_THROW(detail::parse_error::create(108, 0,
    9991             :                                                            "escape character "
    9992             :                                                            "'~' must be "
    9993             :                                                            "followed with '0' "
    9994             :                                                            "or '1'"));
    9995             :                 }
    9996             :             }
    9997             : 
    9998             :             // finally, store the reference token
    9999         363 :             unescape(reference_token);
   10000         363 :             result.push_back(reference_token);
   10001             :         }
   10002             : 
   10003         121 :         return result;
   10004             :     }
   10005             : 
   10006             :     /*!
   10007             :     @brief replace all occurrences of a substring by another string
   10008             : 
   10009             :     @param[in,out] s  the string to manipulate; changed so that all
   10010             :                    occurrences of @a f are replaced with @a t
   10011             :     @param[in]     f  the substring to replace with @a t
   10012             :     @param[in]     t  the string to replace @a f
   10013             : 
   10014             :     @pre The search string @a f must not be empty. **This precondition is
   10015             :     enforced with an assertion.**
   10016             : 
   10017             :     @since version 2.0.0
   10018             :     */
   10019        1078 :     static void replace_substring(std::string& s, const std::string& f,
   10020             :                                   const std::string& t)
   10021             :     {
   10022        1078 :         assert(not f.empty());
   10023        1078 :         for (auto pos = s.find(f);            // find first occurrence of f
   10024        1078 :              pos != std::string::npos;        // make sure f was found
   10025           0 :              s.replace(pos, f.size(), t),     // replace with t, and
   10026           0 :              pos = s.find(f, pos + t.size())) // find next occurrence of f
   10027             :         {
   10028             :         }
   10029        1078 :     }
   10030             : 
   10031             :     /// escape "~"" to "~0" and "/" to "~1"
   10032         176 :     static std::string escape(std::string s)
   10033             :     {
   10034         176 :         replace_substring(s, "~", "~0");
   10035         176 :         replace_substring(s, "/", "~1");
   10036         176 :         return s;
   10037             :     }
   10038             : 
   10039             :     /// unescape "~1" to tilde and "~0" to slash (order is important!)
   10040         363 :     static void unescape(std::string& s)
   10041             :     {
   10042         363 :         replace_substring(s, "~1", "/");
   10043         363 :         replace_substring(s, "~0", "~");
   10044         363 :     }
   10045             : 
   10046             :     /*!
   10047             :     @param[in] reference_string  the reference string to the current value
   10048             :     @param[in] value             the value to consider
   10049             :     @param[in,out] result        the result object to insert values to
   10050             : 
   10051             :     @note Empty objects or arrays are flattened to `null`.
   10052             :     */
   10053         220 :     static void flatten(const std::string& reference_string,
   10054             :                         const BasicJsonType& value, BasicJsonType& result)
   10055             :     {
   10056         220 :         switch (value.m_type)
   10057             :         {
   10058             :         case detail::value_t::array:
   10059             :         {
   10060          22 :             if (value.m_value.array->empty())
   10061             :             {
   10062             :                 // flatten empty array as null
   10063           0 :                 result[reference_string] = nullptr;
   10064             :             }
   10065             :             else
   10066             :             {
   10067             :                 // iterate array and use index as reference string
   10068          55 :                 for (std::size_t i = 0; i < value.m_value.array->size(); ++i)
   10069             :                 {
   10070          33 :                     flatten(reference_string + "/" + std::to_string(i),
   10071          33 :                             value.m_value.array->operator[](i), result);
   10072             :                 }
   10073             :             }
   10074          22 :             break;
   10075             :         }
   10076             : 
   10077             :         case detail::value_t::object:
   10078             :         {
   10079          77 :             if (value.m_value.object->empty())
   10080             :             {
   10081             :                 // flatten empty object as null
   10082           0 :                 result[reference_string] = nullptr;
   10083             :             }
   10084             :             else
   10085             :             {
   10086             :                 // iterate object and use keys as reference string
   10087         253 :                 for (const auto& element : *value.m_value.object)
   10088             :                 {
   10089         176 :                     flatten(reference_string + "/" + escape(element.first),
   10090             :                             element.second, result);
   10091             :                 }
   10092             :             }
   10093          77 :             break;
   10094             :         }
   10095             : 
   10096             :         default:
   10097             :         {
   10098             :             // add primitive value with its reference string
   10099         121 :             result[reference_string] = value;
   10100         121 :             break;
   10101             :         }
   10102             :         }
   10103         220 :     }
   10104             : 
   10105             :     /*!
   10106             :     @param[in] value  flattened JSON
   10107             : 
   10108             :     @return unflattened JSON
   10109             : 
   10110             :     @throw parse_error.109 if array index is not a number
   10111             :     @throw type_error.314  if value is not an object
   10112             :     @throw type_error.315  if object values are not primitive
   10113             :     @throw type_error.313  if value cannot be unflattened
   10114             :     */
   10115          11 :     static BasicJsonType unflatten(const BasicJsonType& value)
   10116             :     {
   10117          11 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not value.is_object()))
   10118             :         {
   10119           0 :             JSON_THROW(
   10120             :                 detail::type_error::create(314,
   10121             :                                            "only objects can be unflattened"));
   10122             :         }
   10123             : 
   10124          11 :         BasicJsonType result;
   10125             : 
   10126             :         // iterate the JSON object values
   10127         132 :         for (const auto& element : *value.m_value.object)
   10128             :         {
   10129         121 :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not element.second.is_primitive()))
   10130             :             {
   10131           0 :                 JSON_THROW(detail::type_error::create(
   10132             :                     315, "values in object must be primitive"));
   10133             :             }
   10134             : 
   10135             :             // assign value to reference pointed to by JSON pointer; Note that
   10136             :             // if
   10137             :             // the JSON pointer is "" (i.e., points to the whole value),
   10138             :             // function
   10139             :             // get_and_create returns a reference to result itself. An
   10140             :             // assignment
   10141             :             // will then create a primitive value.
   10142         121 :             json_pointer(element.first).get_and_create(result) = element.second;
   10143             :         }
   10144             : 
   10145          11 :         return result;
   10146             :     }
   10147             : 
   10148             :     friend bool operator==(json_pointer const& lhs,
   10149             :                            json_pointer const& rhs) noexcept
   10150             :     {
   10151             :         return (lhs.reference_tokens == rhs.reference_tokens);
   10152             :     }
   10153             : 
   10154             :     friend bool operator!=(json_pointer const& lhs,
   10155             :                            json_pointer const& rhs) noexcept
   10156             :     {
   10157             :         return not(lhs == rhs);
   10158             :     }
   10159             : 
   10160             :     /// the reference tokens
   10161             :     std::vector<std::string> reference_tokens;
   10162             : };
   10163             : }
   10164             : 
   10165             : // #include <nlohmann/adl_serializer.hpp>
   10166             : 
   10167             : #include <utility>
   10168             : 
   10169             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/conversions/from_json.hpp>
   10170             : 
   10171             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/conversions/to_json.hpp>
   10172             : 
   10173             : namespace brion_nlohmann
   10174             : {
   10175             : template <typename, typename>
   10176             : struct adl_serializer
   10177             : {
   10178             :     /*!
   10179             :     @brief convert a JSON value to any value type
   10180             : 
   10181             :     This function is usually called by the `get()` function of the
   10182             :     @ref basic_json class (either explicit or via conversion operators).
   10183             : 
   10184             :     @param[in] j         JSON value to read from
   10185             :     @param[in,out] val  value to write to
   10186             :     */
   10187             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename ValueType>
   10188         242 :     static void from_json(BasicJsonType&& j, ValueType& val) noexcept(noexcept(
   10189             :         ::brion_nlohmann::from_json(std::forward<BasicJsonType>(j), val)))
   10190             :     {
   10191         242 :         ::brion_nlohmann::from_json(std::forward<BasicJsonType>(j), val);
   10192         242 :     }
   10193             : 
   10194             :     /*!
   10195             :     @brief convert any value type to a JSON value
   10196             : 
   10197             :     This function is usually called by the constructors of the @ref basic_json
   10198             :     class.
   10199             : 
   10200             :     @param[in,out] j  JSON value to write to
   10201             :     @param[in] val     value to read from
   10202             :     */
   10203             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename ValueType>
   10204          77 :     static void to_json(BasicJsonType& j, ValueType&& val) noexcept(
   10205             :         noexcept(::brion_nlohmann::to_json(j, std::forward<ValueType>(val))))
   10206             :     {
   10207          77 :         ::brion_nlohmann::to_json(j, std::forward<ValueType>(val));
   10208          77 :     }
   10209             : };
   10210             : }
   10211             : 
   10212             : /*!
   10213             : @brief namespace for Niels Lohmann
   10214             : @see https://github.com/nlohmann
   10215             : @since version 1.0.0
   10216             : */
   10217             : namespace brion_nlohmann
   10218             : {
   10219             : /*!
   10220             : @brief a class to store JSON values
   10221             : 
   10222             : @tparam ObjectType type for JSON objects (`std::map` by default; will be used
   10223             : in @ref object_t)
   10224             : @tparam ArrayType type for JSON arrays (`std::vector` by default; will be used
   10225             : in @ref array_t)
   10226             : @tparam StringType type for JSON strings and object keys (`std::string` by
   10227             : default; will be used in @ref string_t)
   10228             : @tparam BooleanType type for JSON booleans (`bool` by default; will be used
   10229             : in @ref boolean_t)
   10230             : @tparam NumberIntegerType type for JSON integer numbers (`int64_t` by
   10231             : default; will be used in @ref number_integer_t)
   10232             : @tparam NumberUnsignedType type for JSON unsigned integer numbers (@c
   10233             : `uint64_t` by default; will be used in @ref number_unsigned_t)
   10234             : @tparam NumberFloatType type for JSON floating-point numbers (`double` by
   10235             : default; will be used in @ref number_float_t)
   10236             : @tparam AllocatorType type of the allocator to use (`std::allocator` by
   10237             : default)
   10238             : @tparam JSONSerializer the serializer to resolve internal calls to `to_json()`
   10239             : and `from_json()` (@ref adl_serializer by default)
   10240             : 
   10241             : @requirement The class satisfies the following concept requirements:
   10242             : - Basic
   10243             :  -
   10244             : [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible):
   10245             :    JSON values can be default constructed. The result will be a JSON null
   10246             :    value.
   10247             :  -
   10248             : [MoveConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveConstructible):
   10249             :    A JSON value can be constructed from an rvalue argument.
   10250             :  -
   10251             : [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible):
   10252             :    A JSON value can be copy-constructed from an lvalue expression.
   10253             :  - [MoveAssignable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveAssignable):
   10254             :    A JSON value van be assigned from an rvalue argument.
   10255             :  - [CopyAssignable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyAssignable):
   10256             :    A JSON value can be copy-assigned from an lvalue expression.
   10257             :  - [Destructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Destructible):
   10258             :    JSON values can be destructed.
   10259             : - Layout
   10260             :  -
   10261             : [StandardLayoutType](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/StandardLayoutType):
   10262             :    JSON values have
   10263             :    [standard
   10264             : layout](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/data_members#Standard_layout):
   10265             :    All non-static data members are private and standard layout types, the
   10266             :    class has no virtual functions or (virtual) base classes.
   10267             : - Library-wide
   10268             :  -
   10269             : [EqualityComparable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/EqualityComparable):
   10270             :    JSON values can be compared with `==`, see @ref
   10271             :    operator==(const_reference,const_reference).
   10272             :  -
   10273             : [LessThanComparable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/LessThanComparable):
   10274             :    JSON values can be compared with `<`, see @ref
   10275             :    operator<(const_reference,const_reference).
   10276             :  - [Swappable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Swappable):
   10277             :    Any JSON lvalue or rvalue of can be swapped with any lvalue or rvalue of
   10278             :    other compatible types, using unqualified function call @ref swap().
   10279             :  - [NullablePointer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/NullablePointer):
   10280             :    JSON values can be compared against `std::nullptr_t` objects which are used
   10281             :    to model the `null` value.
   10282             : - Container
   10283             :  - [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container):
   10284             :    JSON values can be used like STL containers and provide iterator access.
   10285             :  -
   10286             : [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer);
   10287             :    JSON values can be used like STL containers and provide reverse iterator
   10288             :    access.
   10289             : 
   10290             : @invariant The member variables @a m_value and @a m_type have the following
   10291             : relationship:
   10292             : - If `m_type == value_t::object`, then `m_value.object != nullptr`.
   10293             : - If `m_type == value_t::array`, then `m_value.array != nullptr`.
   10294             : - If `m_type == value_t::string`, then `m_value.string != nullptr`.
   10295             : The invariants are checked by member function assert_invariant().
   10296             : 
   10297             : @internal
   10298             : @note ObjectType trick from http://stackoverflow.com/a/9860911
   10299             : @endinternal
   10300             : 
   10301             : @see [RFC 7159: The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) Data Interchange
   10302             : Format](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159)
   10303             : 
   10304             : @since version 1.0.0
   10305             : 
   10306             : @nosubgrouping
   10307             : */
   10308             : NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL_DECLARATION
   10309             : class basic_json
   10310             : {
   10311             : private:
   10312             :     template <detail::value_t>
   10313             :     friend struct detail::external_constructor;
   10314             :     friend ::brion_nlohmann::json_pointer<basic_json>;
   10315             :     friend ::brion_nlohmann::detail::parser<basic_json>;
   10316             :     friend ::brion_nlohmann::detail::serializer<basic_json>;
   10317             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
   10318             :     friend class ::brion_nlohmann::detail::iter_impl;
   10319             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename CharType>
   10320             :     friend class ::brion_nlohmann::detail::binary_writer;
   10321             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
   10322             :     friend class ::brion_nlohmann::detail::binary_reader;
   10323             : 
   10324             :     /// workaround type for MSVC
   10325             :     using basic_json_t = NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL;
   10326             : 
   10327             :     // convenience aliases for types residing in namespace detail;
   10328             :     using lexer = ::brion_nlohmann::detail::lexer<basic_json>;
   10329             :     using parser = ::brion_nlohmann::detail::parser<basic_json>;
   10330             : 
   10331             :     using primitive_iterator_t = ::brion_nlohmann::detail::primitive_iterator_t;
   10332             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
   10333             :     using internal_iterator =
   10334             :         ::brion_nlohmann::detail::internal_iterator<BasicJsonType>;
   10335             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
   10336             :     using iter_impl = ::brion_nlohmann::detail::iter_impl<BasicJsonType>;
   10337             :     template <typename Iterator>
   10338             :     using iteration_proxy = ::brion_nlohmann::detail::iteration_proxy<Iterator>;
   10339             :     template <typename Base>
   10340             :     using json_reverse_iterator =
   10341             :         ::brion_nlohmann::detail::json_reverse_iterator<Base>;
   10342             : 
   10343             :     template <typename CharType>
   10344             :     using output_adapter_t =
   10345             :         ::brion_nlohmann::detail::output_adapter_t<CharType>;
   10346             : 
   10347             :     using binary_reader = ::brion_nlohmann::detail::binary_reader<basic_json>;
   10348             :     template <typename CharType>
   10349             :     using binary_writer =
   10350             :         ::brion_nlohmann::detail::binary_writer<basic_json, CharType>;
   10351             : 
   10352             :     using serializer = ::brion_nlohmann::detail::serializer<basic_json>;
   10353             : 
   10354             : public:
   10355             :     using value_t = detail::value_t;
   10356             :     /// @copydoc nlohmann::json_pointer
   10357             :     using json_pointer = ::brion_nlohmann::json_pointer<basic_json>;
   10358             :     template <typename T, typename SFINAE>
   10359             :     using json_serializer = JSONSerializer<T, SFINAE>;
   10360             :     /// helper type for initializer lists of basic_json values
   10361             :     using initializer_list_t =
   10362             :         std::initializer_list<detail::json_ref<basic_json>>;
   10363             : 
   10364             :     ////////////////
   10365             :     // exceptions //
   10366             :     ////////////////
   10367             : 
   10368             :     /// @name exceptions
   10369             :     /// Classes to implement user-defined exceptions.
   10370             :     /// @{
   10371             : 
   10372             :     /// @copydoc detail::exception
   10373             :     using exception = detail::exception;
   10374             :     /// @copydoc detail::parse_error
   10375             :     using parse_error = detail::parse_error;
   10376             :     /// @copydoc detail::invalid_iterator
   10377             :     using invalid_iterator = detail::invalid_iterator;
   10378             :     /// @copydoc detail::type_error
   10379             :     using type_error = detail::type_error;
   10380             :     /// @copydoc detail::out_of_range
   10381             :     using out_of_range = detail::out_of_range;
   10382             :     /// @copydoc detail::other_error
   10383             :     using other_error = detail::other_error;
   10384             : 
   10385             :     /// @}
   10386             : 
   10387             :     /////////////////////
   10388             :     // container types //
   10389             :     /////////////////////
   10390             : 
   10391             :     /// @name container types
   10392             :     /// The canonic container types to use @ref basic_json like any other STL
   10393             :     /// container.
   10394             :     /// @{
   10395             : 
   10396             :     /// the type of elements in a basic_json container
   10397             :     using value_type = basic_json;
   10398             : 
   10399             :     /// the type of an element reference
   10400             :     using reference = value_type&;
   10401             :     /// the type of an element const reference
   10402             :     using const_reference = const value_type&;
   10403             : 
   10404             :     /// a type to represent differences between iterators
   10405             :     using difference_type = std::ptrdiff_t;
   10406             :     /// a type to represent container sizes
   10407             :     using size_type = std::size_t;
   10408             : 
   10409             :     /// the allocator type
   10410             :     using allocator_type = AllocatorType<basic_json>;
   10411             : 
   10412             :     /// the type of an element pointer
   10413             :     using pointer = typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::pointer;
   10414             :     /// the type of an element const pointer
   10415             :     using const_pointer =
   10416             :         typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::const_pointer;
   10417             : 
   10418             :     /// an iterator for a basic_json container
   10419             :     using iterator = iter_impl<basic_json>;
   10420             :     /// a const iterator for a basic_json container
   10421             :     using const_iterator = iter_impl<const basic_json>;
   10422             :     /// a reverse iterator for a basic_json container
   10423             :     using reverse_iterator =
   10424             :         json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::iterator>;
   10425             :     /// a const reverse iterator for a basic_json container
   10426             :     using const_reverse_iterator =
   10427             :         json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::const_iterator>;
   10428             : 
   10429             :     /// @}
   10430             : 
   10431             :     /*!
   10432             :     @brief returns the allocator associated with the container
   10433             :     */
   10434             :     static allocator_type get_allocator() { return allocator_type(); }
   10435             :     /*!
   10436             :     @brief returns version information on the library
   10437             : 
   10438             :     This function returns a JSON object with information about the library,
   10439             :     including the version number and information on the platform and compiler.
   10440             : 
   10441             :     @return JSON object holding version information
   10442             :     key         | description
   10443             :     ----------- | ---------------
   10444             :     `compiler`  | Information on the used compiler. It is an object with the
   10445             :     following keys: `c++` (the used C++ standard), `family` (the compiler
   10446             :     family; possible values are `clang`, `icc`, `gcc`, `ilecpp`, `msvc`,
   10447             :     `pgcpp`, `sunpro`, and `unknown`), and `version` (the compiler version).
   10448             :     `copyright` | The copyright line for the library as string.
   10449             :     `name`      | The name of the library as string.
   10450             :     `platform`  | The used platform as string. Possible values are `win32`,
   10451             :     `linux`, `apple`, `unix`, and `unknown`.
   10452             :     `url`       | The URL of the project as string.
   10453             :     `version`   | The version of the library. It is an object with the following
   10454             :     keys: `major`, `minor`, and `patch` as defined by [Semantic
   10455             :     Versioning](http://semver.org), and `string` (the version string).
   10456             : 
   10457             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example output of the `meta()`
   10458             :     function.,meta}
   10459             : 
   10460             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   10461             :     changes to any JSON value.
   10462             : 
   10463             :     @complexity Constant.
   10464             : 
   10465             :     @since 2.1.0
   10466             :     */
   10467             :     static basic_json meta()
   10468             :     {
   10469             :         basic_json result;
   10470             : 
   10471             :         result["copyright"] = "(C) 2013-2017 Niels Lohmann";
   10472             :         result["name"] = "JSON for Modern C++";
   10473             :         result["url"] = "https://github.com/nlohmann/json";
   10474             :         result["version"]["string"] =
   10475             :             std::to_string(NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MAJOR) + "." +
   10476             :             std::to_string(NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MINOR) + "." +
   10477             :             std::to_string(NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_PATCH);
   10478             :         result["version"]["major"] = NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MAJOR;
   10479             :         result["version"]["minor"] = NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MINOR;
   10480             :         result["version"]["patch"] = NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_PATCH;
   10481             : 
   10482             : #ifdef _WIN32
   10483             :         result["platform"] = "win32";
   10484             : #elif defined __linux__
   10485             :         result["platform"] = "linux";
   10486             : #elif defined __APPLE__
   10487             :         result["platform"] = "apple";
   10488             : #elif defined __unix__
   10489             :         result["platform"] = "unix";
   10490             : #else
   10491             :         result["platform"] = "unknown";
   10492             : #endif
   10493             : 
   10494             : #if defined(__ICC) || defined(__INTEL_COMPILER)
   10495             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "icc"}, {"version", __INTEL_COMPILER}};
   10496             : #elif defined(__clang__)
   10497             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "clang"},
   10498             :                               {"version", __clang_version__}};
   10499             : #elif defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
   10500             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "gcc"},
   10501             :                               {"version",
   10502             :                                std::to_string(__GNUC__) + "." +
   10503             :                                    std::to_string(__GNUC_MINOR__) + "." +
   10504             :                                    std::to_string(__GNUC_PATCHLEVEL__)}};
   10505             : #elif defined(__HP_cc) || defined(__HP_aCC)
   10506             :         result["compiler"] = "hp"
   10507             : #elif defined(__IBMCPP__)
   10508             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "ilecpp"}, {"version", __IBMCPP__}};
   10509             : #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
   10510             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "msvc"}, {"version", _MSC_VER}};
   10511             : #elif defined(__PGI)
   10512             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "pgcpp"}, {"version", __PGI}};
   10513             : #elif defined(__SUNPRO_CC)
   10514             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "sunpro"}, {"version", __SUNPRO_CC}};
   10515             : #else
   10516             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "unknown"}, {"version", "unknown"}};
   10517             : #endif
   10518             : 
   10519             : #ifdef __cplusplus
   10520             :         result["compiler"]["c++"] = std::to_string(__cplusplus);
   10521             : #else
   10522             :         result["compiler"]["c++"] = "unknown";
   10523             : #endif
   10524             :         return result;
   10525             :     }
   10526             : 
   10527             : ///////////////////////////
   10528             : // JSON value data types //
   10529             : ///////////////////////////
   10530             : 
   10531             : /// @name JSON value data types
   10532             : /// The data types to store a JSON value. These types are derived from
   10533             : /// the template arguments passed to class @ref basic_json.
   10534             : /// @{
   10535             : 
   10536             : #if defined(JSON_HAS_CPP_14)
   10537             :     // Use transparent comparator if possible, combined with perfect forwarding
   10538             :     // on find() and count() calls prevents unnecessary string construction.
   10539             :     using object_comparator_t = std::less<>;
   10540             : #else
   10541             :     using object_comparator_t = std::less<StringType>;
   10542             : #endif
   10543             : 
   10544             :     /*!
   10545             :     @brief a type for an object
   10546             : 
   10547             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON objects as follows:
   10548             :     > An object is an unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs,
   10549             :     > where a name is a string and a value is a string, number, boolean, null,
   10550             :     > object, or array.
   10551             : 
   10552             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters
   10553             :     described below.
   10554             : 
   10555             :     @tparam ObjectType  the container to store objects (e.g., `std::map` or
   10556             :     `std::unordered_map`)
   10557             :     @tparam StringType the type of the keys or names (e.g., `std::string`).
   10558             :     The comparison function `std::less<StringType>` is used to order elements
   10559             :     inside the container.
   10560             :     @tparam AllocatorType the allocator to use for objects (e.g.,
   10561             :     `std::allocator`)
   10562             : 
   10563             :     #### Default type
   10564             : 
   10565             :     With the default values for @a ObjectType (`std::map`), @a StringType
   10566             :     (`std::string`), and @a AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default
   10567             :     value for @a object_t is:
   10568             : 
   10569             :     @code {.cpp}
   10570             :     std::map<
   10571             :       std::string, // key_type
   10572             :       basic_json, // value_type
   10573             :       std::less<std::string>, // key_compare
   10574             :       std::allocator<std::pair<const std::string, basic_json>> // allocator_type
   10575             :     >
   10576             :     @endcode
   10577             : 
   10578             :     #### Behavior
   10579             : 
   10580             :     The choice of @a object_t influences the behavior of the JSON class. With
   10581             :     the default type, objects have the following behavior:
   10582             : 
   10583             :     - When all names are unique, objects will be interoperable in the sense
   10584             :       that all software implementations receiving that object will agree on
   10585             :       the name-value mappings.
   10586             :     - When the names within an object are not unique, it is unspecified which
   10587             :       one of the values for a given key will be chosen. For instance,
   10588             :       `{"key": 2, "key": 1}` could be equal to either `{"key": 1}` or
   10589             :       `{"key": 2}`.
   10590             :     - Internally, name/value pairs are stored in lexicographical order of the
   10591             :       names. Objects will also be serialized (see @ref dump) in this order.
   10592             :       For instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be stored
   10593             :       and serialized as `{"a": 2, "b": 1}`.
   10594             :     - When comparing objects, the order of the name/value pairs is irrelevant.
   10595             :       This makes objects interoperable in the sense that they will not be
   10596             :       affected by these differences. For instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and
   10597             :       `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be treated as equal.
   10598             : 
   10599             :     #### Limits
   10600             : 
   10601             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
   10602             :     > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
   10603             : 
   10604             :     In this class, the object's limit of nesting is not explicitly constrained.
   10605             :     However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
   10606             :     runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the
   10607             :     @ref max_size function of a JSON object.
   10608             : 
   10609             :     #### Storage
   10610             : 
   10611             :     Objects are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is, for any
   10612             :     access to object values, a pointer of type `object_t*` must be
   10613             :     dereferenced.
   10614             : 
   10615             :     @sa @ref array_t -- type for an array value
   10616             : 
   10617             :     @since version 1.0.0
   10618             : 
   10619             :     @note The order name/value pairs are added to the object is *not*
   10620             :     preserved by the library. Therefore, iterating an object may return
   10621             :     name/value pairs in a different order than they were originally stored. In
   10622             :     fact, keys will be traversed in alphabetical order as `std::map` with
   10623             :     `std::less` is used by default. Please note this behavior conforms to [RFC
   10624             :     7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159), because any order implements the
   10625             :     specified "unordered" nature of JSON objects.
   10626             :     */
   10627             :     using object_t =
   10628             :         ObjectType<StringType, basic_json, object_comparator_t,
   10629             :                    AllocatorType<std::pair<const StringType, basic_json>>>;
   10630             : 
   10631             :     /*!
   10632             :     @brief a type for an array
   10633             : 
   10634             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON arrays as follows:
   10635             :     > An array is an ordered sequence of zero or more values.
   10636             : 
   10637             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters
   10638             :     explained below.
   10639             : 
   10640             :     @tparam ArrayType  container type to store arrays (e.g., `std::vector` or
   10641             :     `std::list`)
   10642             :     @tparam AllocatorType allocator to use for arrays (e.g., `std::allocator`)
   10643             : 
   10644             :     #### Default type
   10645             : 
   10646             :     With the default values for @a ArrayType (`std::vector`) and @a
   10647             :     AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default value for @a array_t is:
   10648             : 
   10649             :     @code {.cpp}
   10650             :     std::vector<
   10651             :       basic_json, // value_type
   10652             :       std::allocator<basic_json> // allocator_type
   10653             :     >
   10654             :     @endcode
   10655             : 
   10656             :     #### Limits
   10657             : 
   10658             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
   10659             :     > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
   10660             : 
   10661             :     In this class, the array's limit of nesting is not explicitly constrained.
   10662             :     However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
   10663             :     runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the
   10664             :     @ref max_size function of a JSON array.
   10665             : 
   10666             :     #### Storage
   10667             : 
   10668             :     Arrays are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is, for any
   10669             :     access to array values, a pointer of type `array_t*` must be dereferenced.
   10670             : 
   10671             :     @sa @ref object_t -- type for an object value
   10672             : 
   10673             :     @since version 1.0.0
   10674             :     */
   10675             :     using array_t = ArrayType<basic_json, AllocatorType<basic_json>>;
   10676             : 
   10677             :     /*!
   10678             :     @brief a type for a string
   10679             : 
   10680             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON strings as follows:
   10681             :     > A string is a sequence of zero or more Unicode characters.
   10682             : 
   10683             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameter
   10684             :     described below. Unicode values are split by the JSON class into
   10685             :     byte-sized characters during deserialization.
   10686             : 
   10687             :     @tparam StringType  the container to store strings (e.g., `std::string`).
   10688             :     Note this container is used for keys/names in objects, see @ref object_t.
   10689             : 
   10690             :     #### Default type
   10691             : 
   10692             :     With the default values for @a StringType (`std::string`), the default
   10693             :     value for @a string_t is:
   10694             : 
   10695             :     @code {.cpp}
   10696             :     std::string
   10697             :     @endcode
   10698             : 
   10699             :     #### Encoding
   10700             : 
   10701             :     Strings are stored in UTF-8 encoding. Therefore, functions like
   10702             :     `std::string::size()` or `std::string::length()` return the number of
   10703             :     bytes in the string rather than the number of characters or glyphs.
   10704             : 
   10705             :     #### String comparison
   10706             : 
   10707             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
   10708             :     > Software implementations are typically required to test names of object
   10709             :     > members for equality. Implementations that transform the textual
   10710             :     > representation into sequences of Unicode code units and then perform the
   10711             :     > comparison numerically, code unit by code unit, are interoperable in the
   10712             :     > sense that implementations will agree in all cases on equality or
   10713             :     > inequality of two strings. For example, implementations that compare
   10714             :     > strings with escaped characters unconverted may incorrectly find that
   10715             :     > `"a\\b"` and `"a\u005Cb"` are not equal.
   10716             : 
   10717             :     This implementation is interoperable as it does compare strings code unit
   10718             :     by code unit.
   10719             : 
   10720             :     #### Storage
   10721             : 
   10722             :     String values are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is,
   10723             :     for any access to string values, a pointer of type `string_t*` must be
   10724             :     dereferenced.
   10725             : 
   10726             :     @since version 1.0.0
   10727             :     */
   10728             :     using string_t = StringType;
   10729             : 
   10730             :     /*!
   10731             :     @brief a type for a boolean
   10732             : 
   10733             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) implicitly describes a boolean as a
   10734             :     type which differentiates the two literals `true` and `false`.
   10735             : 
   10736             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameter @a
   10737             :     BooleanType which chooses the type to use.
   10738             : 
   10739             :     #### Default type
   10740             : 
   10741             :     With the default values for @a BooleanType (`bool`), the default value for
   10742             :     @a boolean_t is:
   10743             : 
   10744             :     @code {.cpp}
   10745             :     bool
   10746             :     @endcode
   10747             : 
   10748             :     #### Storage
   10749             : 
   10750             :     Boolean values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
   10751             : 
   10752             :     @since version 1.0.0
   10753             :     */
   10754             :     using boolean_t = BooleanType;
   10755             : 
   10756             :     /*!
   10757             :     @brief a type for a number (integer)
   10758             : 
   10759             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
   10760             :     > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
   10761             :     > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
   10762             :     > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
   10763             :     > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
   10764             :     > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
   10765             :     > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
   10766             :     > are not permitted.
   10767             : 
   10768             :     This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
   10769             :     However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
   10770             :     is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
   10771             :     Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
   10772             :     number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
   10773             : 
   10774             :     To store integer numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
   10775             :     parameter @a NumberIntegerType which chooses the type to use.
   10776             : 
   10777             :     #### Default type
   10778             : 
   10779             :     With the default values for @a NumberIntegerType (`int64_t`), the default
   10780             :     value for @a number_integer_t is:
   10781             : 
   10782             :     @code {.cpp}
   10783             :     int64_t
   10784             :     @endcode
   10785             : 
   10786             :     #### Default behavior
   10787             : 
   10788             :     - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
   10789             :       leading zeros in integer literals lead to an interpretation as octal
   10790             :       number. Internally, the value will be stored as decimal number. For
   10791             :       instance, the C++ integer literal `010` will be serialized to `8`.
   10792             :       During deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
   10793             :     - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
   10794             : 
   10795             :     #### Limits
   10796             : 
   10797             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
   10798             :     > An implementation may set limits on the range and precision of numbers.
   10799             : 
   10800             :     When the default type is used, the maximal integer number that can be
   10801             :     stored is `9223372036854775807` (INT64_MAX) and the minimal integer number
   10802             :     that can be stored is `-9223372036854775808` (INT64_MIN). Integer numbers
   10803             :     that are out of range will yield over/underflow when used in a
   10804             :     constructor. During deserialization, too large or small integer numbers
   10805             :     will be automatically be stored as @ref number_unsigned_t or @ref
   10806             :     number_float_t.
   10807             : 
   10808             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) further states:
   10809             :     > Note that when such software is used, numbers that are integers and are
   10810             :     > in the range \f$[-2^{53}+1, 2^{53}-1]\f$ are interoperable in the sense
   10811             :     > that implementations will agree exactly on their numeric values.
   10812             : 
   10813             :     As this range is a subrange of the exactly supported range [INT64_MIN,
   10814             :     INT64_MAX], this class's integer type is interoperable.
   10815             : 
   10816             :     #### Storage
   10817             : 
   10818             :     Integer number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
   10819             : 
   10820             :     @sa @ref number_float_t -- type for number values (floating-point)
   10821             : 
   10822             :     @sa @ref number_unsigned_t -- type for number values (unsigned integer)
   10823             : 
   10824             :     @since version 1.0.0
   10825             :     */
   10826             :     using number_integer_t = NumberIntegerType;
   10827             : 
   10828             :     /*!
   10829             :     @brief a type for a number (unsigned)
   10830             : 
   10831             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
   10832             :     > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
   10833             :     > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
   10834             :     > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
   10835             :     > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
   10836             :     > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
   10837             :     > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
   10838             :     > are not permitted.
   10839             : 
   10840             :     This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
   10841             :     However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
   10842             :     is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
   10843             :     Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
   10844             :     number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
   10845             : 
   10846             :     To store unsigned integer numbers in C++, a type is defined by the
   10847             :     template parameter @a NumberUnsignedType which chooses the type to use.
   10848             : 
   10849             :     #### Default type
   10850             : 
   10851             :     With the default values for @a NumberUnsignedType (`uint64_t`), the
   10852             :     default value for @a number_unsigned_t is:
   10853             : 
   10854             :     @code {.cpp}
   10855             :     uint64_t
   10856             :     @endcode
   10857             : 
   10858             :     #### Default behavior
   10859             : 
   10860             :     - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
   10861             :       leading zeros in integer literals lead to an interpretation as octal
   10862             :       number. Internally, the value will be stored as decimal number. For
   10863             :       instance, the C++ integer literal `010` will be serialized to `8`.
   10864             :       During deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
   10865             :     - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
   10866             : 
   10867             :     #### Limits
   10868             : 
   10869             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
   10870             :     > An implementation may set limits on the range and precision of numbers.
   10871             : 
   10872             :     When the default type is used, the maximal integer number that can be
   10873             :     stored is `18446744073709551615` (UINT64_MAX) and the minimal integer
   10874             :     number that can be stored is `0`. Integer numbers that are out of range
   10875             :     will yield over/underflow when used in a constructor. During
   10876             :     deserialization, too large or small integer numbers will be automatically
   10877             :     be stored as @ref number_integer_t or @ref number_float_t.
   10878             : 
   10879             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) further states:
   10880             :     > Note that when such software is used, numbers that are integers and are
   10881             :     > in the range \f$[-2^{53}+1, 2^{53}-1]\f$ are interoperable in the sense
   10882             :     > that implementations will agree exactly on their numeric values.
   10883             : 
   10884             :     As this range is a subrange (when considered in conjunction with the
   10885             :     number_integer_t type) of the exactly supported range [0, UINT64_MAX],
   10886             :     this class's integer type is interoperable.
   10887             : 
   10888             :     #### Storage
   10889             : 
   10890             :     Integer number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
   10891             : 
   10892             :     @sa @ref number_float_t -- type for number values (floating-point)
   10893             :     @sa @ref number_integer_t -- type for number values (integer)
   10894             : 
   10895             :     @since version 2.0.0
   10896             :     */
   10897             :     using number_unsigned_t = NumberUnsignedType;
   10898             : 
   10899             :     /*!
   10900             :     @brief a type for a number (floating-point)
   10901             : 
   10902             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
   10903             :     > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
   10904             :     > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
   10905             :     > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
   10906             :     > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
   10907             :     > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
   10908             :     > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
   10909             :     > are not permitted.
   10910             : 
   10911             :     This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
   10912             :     However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
   10913             :     is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
   10914             :     Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
   10915             :     number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
   10916             : 
   10917             :     To store floating-point numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
   10918             :     parameter @a NumberFloatType which chooses the type to use.
   10919             : 
   10920             :     #### Default type
   10921             : 
   10922             :     With the default values for @a NumberFloatType (`double`), the default
   10923             :     value for @a number_float_t is:
   10924             : 
   10925             :     @code {.cpp}
   10926             :     double
   10927             :     @endcode
   10928             : 
   10929             :     #### Default behavior
   10930             : 
   10931             :     - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
   10932             :       leading zeros in floating-point literals will be ignored. Internally,
   10933             :       the value will be stored as decimal number. For instance, the C++
   10934             :       floating-point literal `01.2` will be serialized to `1.2`. During
   10935             :       deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
   10936             :     - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
   10937             : 
   10938             :     #### Limits
   10939             : 
   10940             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
   10941             :     > This specification allows implementations to set limits on the range and
   10942             :     > precision of numbers accepted. Since software that implements IEEE
   10943             :     > 754-2008 binary64 (double precision) numbers is generally available and
   10944             :     > widely used, good interoperability can be achieved by implementations
   10945             :     > that expect no more precision or range than these provide, in the sense
   10946             :     > that implementations will approximate JSON numbers within the expected
   10947             :     > precision.
   10948             : 
   10949             :     This implementation does exactly follow this approach, as it uses double
   10950             :     precision floating-point numbers. Note values smaller than
   10951             :     `-1.79769313486232e+308` and values greater than `1.79769313486232e+308`
   10952             :     will be stored as NaN internally and be serialized to `null`.
   10953             : 
   10954             :     #### Storage
   10955             : 
   10956             :     Floating-point number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json
   10957             :     type.
   10958             : 
   10959             :     @sa @ref number_integer_t -- type for number values (integer)
   10960             : 
   10961             :     @sa @ref number_unsigned_t -- type for number values (unsigned integer)
   10962             : 
   10963             :     @since version 1.0.0
   10964             :     */
   10965             :     using number_float_t = NumberFloatType;
   10966             : 
   10967             :     /// @}
   10968             : 
   10969             : private:
   10970             :     /// helper for exception-safe object creation
   10971             :     template <typename T, typename... Args>
   10972         836 :     static T* create(Args&&... args)
   10973             :     {
   10974        1672 :         AllocatorType<T> alloc;
   10975             :         using AllocatorTraits = std::allocator_traits<AllocatorType<T>>;
   10976             : 
   10977           0 :         auto deleter = [&](T* object) {
   10978           0 :             AllocatorTraits::deallocate(alloc, object, 1);
   10979         836 :         };
   10980             :         std::unique_ptr<T, decltype(deleter)> object(
   10981        1672 :             AllocatorTraits::allocate(alloc, 1), deleter);
   10982         836 :         AllocatorTraits::construct(alloc, object.get(),
   10983             :                                    std::forward<Args>(args)...);
   10984         836 :         assert(object != nullptr);
   10985        1672 :         return object.release();
   10986             :     }
   10987             : 
   10988             :     /// helper for insertion of an iterator (supports GCC 4.8+)
   10989             :     template<typename... Args>
   10990             :     iterator insert_iterator(const_iterator pos, Args&& ... args)
   10991             :     {
   10992             :         iterator result(this);
   10993             :         assert(m_value.array != nullptr);
   10994             : 
   10995             :         auto insert_pos = std::distance(m_value.array->begin(), pos.m_it.array_iterator);
   10996             :         m_value.array->insert(pos.m_it.array_iterator, std::forward<Args>(args)...);
   10997             :         result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->begin() + insert_pos;
   10998             : 
   10999             :         // For GCC 4.9+ only, this could become:
   11000             :         // result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->insert(pos.m_it.array_iterator, cnt, val);
   11001             : 
   11002             :         return result;
   11003             :     }
   11004             : 
   11005             :     ////////////////////////
   11006             :     // JSON value storage //
   11007             :     ////////////////////////
   11008             : 
   11009             :     /*!
   11010             :     @brief a JSON value
   11011             : 
   11012             :     The actual storage for a JSON value of the @ref basic_json class. This
   11013             :     union combines the different storage types for the JSON value types
   11014             :     defined in @ref value_t.
   11015             : 
   11016             :     JSON type | value_t type    | used type
   11017             :     --------- | --------------- | ------------------------
   11018             :     object    | object          | pointer to @ref object_t
   11019             :     array     | array           | pointer to @ref array_t
   11020             :     string    | string          | pointer to @ref string_t
   11021             :     boolean   | boolean         | @ref boolean_t
   11022             :     number    | number_integer  | @ref number_integer_t
   11023             :     number    | number_unsigned | @ref number_unsigned_t
   11024             :     number    | number_float    | @ref number_float_t
   11025             :     null      | null            | *no value is stored*
   11026             : 
   11027             :     @note Variable-length types (objects, arrays, and strings) are stored as
   11028             :     pointers. The size of the union should not exceed 64 bits if the default
   11029             :     value types are used.
   11030             : 
   11031             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11032             :     */
   11033             :     union json_value {
   11034             :         /// object (stored with pointer to save storage)
   11035             :         object_t* object;
   11036             :         /// array (stored with pointer to save storage)
   11037             :         array_t* array;
   11038             :         /// string (stored with pointer to save storage)
   11039             :         string_t* string;
   11040             :         /// boolean
   11041             :         boolean_t boolean;
   11042             :         /// number (integer)
   11043             :         number_integer_t number_integer;
   11044             :         /// number (unsigned integer)
   11045             :         number_unsigned_t number_unsigned;
   11046             :         /// number (floating-point)
   11047             :         number_float_t number_float;
   11048             : 
   11049             :         /// default constructor (for null values)
   11050             :         json_value() = default;
   11051             :         /// constructor for booleans
   11052           0 :         json_value(boolean_t v) noexcept : boolean(v) {}
   11053             :         /// constructor for numbers (integer)
   11054           0 :         json_value(number_integer_t v) noexcept : number_integer(v) {}
   11055             :         /// constructor for numbers (unsigned)
   11056           0 :         json_value(number_unsigned_t v) noexcept : number_unsigned(v) {}
   11057             :         /// constructor for numbers (floating-point)
   11058           0 :         json_value(number_float_t v) noexcept : number_float(v) {}
   11059             :         /// constructor for empty values of a given type
   11060         561 :         json_value(value_t t)
   11061             :         {
   11062         561 :             switch (t)
   11063             :             {
   11064             :             case value_t::object:
   11065             :             {
   11066          88 :                 object = create<object_t>();
   11067          88 :                 break;
   11068             :             }
   11069             : 
   11070             :             case value_t::array:
   11071             :             {
   11072          22 :                 array = create<array_t>();
   11073          22 :                 break;
   11074             :             }
   11075             : 
   11076             :             case value_t::string:
   11077             :             {
   11078           0 :                 string = create<string_t>("");
   11079           0 :                 break;
   11080             :             }
   11081             : 
   11082             :             case value_t::boolean:
   11083             :             {
   11084           0 :                 boolean = boolean_t(false);
   11085           0 :                 break;
   11086             :             }
   11087             : 
   11088             :             case value_t::number_integer:
   11089             :             {
   11090           0 :                 number_integer = number_integer_t(0);
   11091           0 :                 break;
   11092             :             }
   11093             : 
   11094             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   11095             :             {
   11096           0 :                 number_unsigned = number_unsigned_t(0);
   11097           0 :                 break;

   11100             :             case value_t::number_float:
   11101             :             {
   11102           0 :                 number_float = number_float_t(0.0);
   11103           0 :                 break;
   11104             :             }

   11107             :             {

   11109         451 :                 break;

   11112             :             default:
   11113             :             {
   11114           0 :                 object = nullptr; // silence warning, see #821
   11115           0 :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(t == value_t::null))
   11116             :                 {
   11117           0 :                     JSON_THROW(
   11118             :                         other_error::create(500,
   11119             :                                             "961c151d2e87f2686a955a9be24d316f13"
   11120             :                                             "62bf21 3.1.2")); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
   11121             :                 }
   11122           0 :                 break;
   11123             :             }
   11124             :             }
