   11126             : 
   11127             :         /// constructor for strings
   11128         429 :         json_value(const string_t& value) { string = create<string_t>(value); }
   11129             :         /// constructor for rvalue strings
   11130         121 :         json_value(string_t&& value)
   11131             :         {
   11132         121 :             string = create<string_t>(std::move(value));
   11133         121 :         }
   11134             : 
   11135             :         /// constructor for objects
   11136          55 :         json_value(const object_t& value) { object = create<object_t>(value); }
   11137             :         /// constructor for rvalue objects
   11138             :         json_value(object_t&& value)
   11139             :         {
   11140             :             object = create<object_t>(std::move(value));
   11141             :         }
   11142             : 
   11143             :         /// constructor for arrays
   11144          22 :         json_value(const array_t& value) { array = create<array_t>(value); }
   11145             :         /// constructor for rvalue arrays
   11146             :         json_value(array_t&& value)
   11147             :         {
   11148             :             array = create<array_t>(std::move(value));
   11149             :         }
   11150             : 
   11151        1452 :         void destroy(value_t t) noexcept
   11152             :         {
   11153        1452 :             switch (t)
   11154             :             {
   11155             :             case value_t::object:
   11156             :             {
   11157         440 :                 AllocatorType<object_t> alloc;
   11158         220 :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, object);
   11159         220 :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc,
   11160             :                                                                    object, 1);
   11161         220 :                 break;
   11162             :             }
   11163             : 
   11164             :             case value_t::array:
   11165             :             {
   11166         132 :                 AllocatorType<array_t> alloc;
   11167          66 :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, array);
   11168          66 :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, array,
   11169             :                                                                    1);
   11170          66 :                 break;
   11171             :             }
   11172             : 
   11173             :             case value_t::string:
   11174             :             {
   11175        1100 :                 AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
   11176         550 :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, string);
   11177         550 :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc,
   11178             :                                                                    string, 1);
   11179         550 :                 break;
   11180             :             }
   11181             : 
   11182             :             default:
   11183             :             {
   11184         616 :                 break;
   11185             :             }
   11186             :             }
   11187        1452 :         }
   11188             :     };
   11189             : 
   11190             :     /*!
   11191             :     @brief checks the class invariants
   11192             : 
   11193             :     This function asserts the class invariants. It needs to be called at the
   11194             :     end of every constructor to make sure that created objects respect the
   11195             :     invariant. Furthermore, it has to be called each time the type of a JSON
   11196             :     value is changed, because the invariant expresses a relationship between
   11197             :     @a m_type and @a m_value.
   11198             :     */
   11199        4433 :     void assert_invariant() const noexcept
   11200             :     {
   11201        4433 :         assert(m_type != value_t::object or m_value.object != nullptr);
   11202        4433 :         assert(m_type != value_t::array or m_value.array != nullptr);
   11203        4433 :         assert(m_type != value_t::string or m_value.string != nullptr);
   11204        4433 :     }
   11205             : 
   11206             : public:
   11207             :     //////////////////////////
   11208             :     // JSON parser callback //
   11209             :     //////////////////////////
   11210             : 
   11211             :     /*!
   11212             :     @brief parser event types
   11213             : 
   11214             :     The parser callback distinguishes the following events:
   11215             :     - `object_start`: the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object
   11216             :     - `key`: the parser read a key of a value in an object
   11217             :     - `object_end`: the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object
   11218             :     - `array_start`: the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array
   11219             :     - `array_end`: the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array
   11220             :     - `value`: the parser finished reading a JSON value
   11221             : 
   11222             :     @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are
   11223             :     triggered"
   11224             : 
   11225             :     @sa @ref parser_callback_t for more information and examples
   11226             :     */
   11227             :     using parse_event_t = typename parser::parse_event_t;
   11228             : 
   11229             :     /*!
   11230             :     @brief per-element parser callback type
   11231             : 
   11232             :     With a parser callback function, the result of parsing a JSON text can be
   11233             :     influenced. When passed to @ref parse, it is called on certain events
   11234             :     (passed as @ref parse_event_t via parameter @a event) with a set recursion
   11235             :     depth @a depth and context JSON value @a parsed. The return value of the
   11236             :     callback function is a boolean indicating whether the element that emitted
   11237             :     the callback shall be kept or not.
   11238             : 
   11239             :     We distinguish six scenarios (determined by the event type) in which the
   11240             :     callback function can be called. The following table describes the values
   11241             :     of the parameters @a depth, @a event, and @a parsed.
   11242             : 
   11243             :     parameter @a event | description | parameter @a depth | parameter @a parsed
   11244             :     ------------------ | ----------- | ------------------ | -------------------
   11245             :     parse_event_t::object_start | the parser read `{` and started to process a
   11246             :     JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | a JSON value with
   11247             :     type discarded
   11248             :     parse_event_t::key | the parser read a key of a value in an object | depth
   11249             :     of the currently parsed JSON object | a JSON string containing the key
   11250             :     parse_event_t::object_end | the parser read `}` and finished processing a
   11251             :     JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | the parsed JSON
   11252             :     object
   11253             :     parse_event_t::array_start | the parser read `[` and started to process a
   11254             :     JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | a JSON value with type
   11255             :     discarded
   11256             :     parse_event_t::array_end | the parser read `]` and finished processing a
   11257             :     JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | the parsed JSON array
   11258             :     parse_event_t::value | the parser finished reading a JSON value | depth of
   11259             :     the value | the parsed JSON value
   11260             : 
   11261             :     @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are
   11262             :     triggered"
   11263             : 
   11264             :     Discarding a value (i.e., returning `false`) has different effects
   11265             :     depending on the context in which function was called:
   11266             : 
   11267             :     - Discarded values in structured types are skipped. That is, the parser
   11268             :       will behave as if the discarded value was never read.
   11269             :     - In case a value outside a structured type is skipped, it is replaced
   11270             :       with `null`. This case happens if the top-level element is skipped.
   11271             : 
   11272             :     @param[in] depth  the depth of the recursion during parsing
   11273             : 
   11274             :     @param[in] event  an event of type parse_event_t indicating the context in
   11275             :     the callback function has been called
   11276             : 
   11277             :     @param[in,out] parsed  the current intermediate parse result; note that
   11278             :     writing to this value has no effect for parse_event_t::key events
   11279             : 
   11280             :     @return Whether the JSON value which called the function during parsing
   11281             :     should be kept (`true`) or not (`false`). In the latter case, it is either
   11282             :     skipped completely or replaced by an empty discarded object.
   11283             : 
   11284             :     @sa @ref parse for examples
   11285             : 
   11286             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11287             :     */
   11288             :     using parser_callback_t = typename parser::parser_callback_t;
   11289             : 
   11290             :     //////////////////
   11291             :     // constructors //
   11292             :     //////////////////
   11293             : 
   11294             :     /// @name constructors and destructors
   11295             :     /// Constructors of class @ref basic_json, copy/move constructor, copy
   11296             :     /// assignment, static functions creating objects, and the destructor.
   11297             :     /// @{
   11298             : 
   11299             :     /*!
   11300             :     @brief create an empty value with a given type
   11301             : 
   11302             :     Create an empty JSON value with a given type. The value will be default
   11303             :     initialized with an empty value which depends on the type:
   11304             : 
   11305             :     Value type  | initial value
   11306             :     ----------- | -------------
   11307             :     null        | `null`
   11308             :     boolean     | `false`
   11309             :     string      | `""`
   11310             :     number      | `0`
   11311             :     object      | `{}`
   11312             :     array       | `[]`
   11313             : 
   11314             :     @param[in] v  the type of the value to create
   11315             : 
   11316             :     @complexity Constant.
   11317             : 
   11318             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11319             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11320             : 
   11321             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor for different @ref
   11322             :     value_t values,basic_json__value_t}
   11323             : 
   11324             :     @sa @ref clear() -- restores the postcondition of this constructor
   11325             : 
   11326             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11327             :     */
   11328         462 :     basic_json(const value_t v)
   11329             :         : m_type(v)
   11330         462 :         , m_value(v)
   11331             :     {
   11332         462 :         assert_invariant();
   11333         462 :     }
   11334             : 
   11335             :     /*!
   11336             :     @brief create a null object
   11337             : 
   11338             :     Create a `null` JSON value. It either takes a null pointer as parameter
   11339             :     (explicitly creating `null`) or no parameter (implicitly creating `null`).
   11340             :     The passed null pointer itself is not read -- it is only used to choose
   11341             :     the right constructor.
   11342             : 
   11343             :     @complexity Constant.
   11344             : 
   11345             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this constructor never throws
   11346             :     exceptions.
   11347             : 
   11348             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with and without a
   11349             :     null pointer parameter.,basic_json__nullptr_t}
   11350             : 
   11351             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11352             :     */
   11353         451 :     basic_json(std::nullptr_t = nullptr) noexcept : basic_json(value_t::null)
   11354             :     {
   11355         451 :         assert_invariant();
   11356         451 :     }
   11357             : 
   11358             :     /*!
   11359             :     @brief create a JSON value
   11360             : 
   11361             :     This is a "catch all" constructor for all compatible JSON types; that is,
   11362             :     types for which a `to_json()` method exists. The constructor forwards the
   11363             :     parameter @a val to that method (to `json_serializer<U>::to_json` method
   11364             :     with `U = uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`, to be exact).
   11365             : 
   11366             :     Template type @a CompatibleType includes, but is not limited to, the
   11367             :     following types:
   11368             :     - **arrays**: @ref array_t and all kinds of compatible containers such as
   11369             :       `std::vector`, `std::deque`, `std::list`, `std::forward_list`,
   11370             :       `std::array`, `std::valarray`, `std::set`, `std::unordered_set`,
   11371             :       `std::multiset`, and `std::unordered_multiset` with a `value_type` from
   11372             :       which a @ref basic_json value can be constructed.
   11373             :     - **objects**: @ref object_t and all kinds of compatible associative
   11374             :       containers such as `std::map`, `std::unordered_map`, `std::multimap`,
   11375             :       and `std::unordered_multimap` with a `key_type` compatible to
   11376             :       @ref string_t and a `value_type` from which a @ref basic_json value can
   11377             :       be constructed.
   11378             :     - **strings**: @ref string_t, string literals, and all compatible string
   11379             :       containers can be used.
   11380             :     - **numbers**: @ref number_integer_t, @ref number_unsigned_t,
   11381             :       @ref number_float_t, and all convertible number types such as `int`,
   11382             :       `size_t`, `int64_t`, `float` or `double` can be used.
   11383             :     - **boolean**: @ref boolean_t / `bool` can be used.
   11384             : 
   11385             :     See the examples below.
   11386             : 
   11387             :     @tparam CompatibleType a type such that:
   11388             :     - @a CompatibleType is not derived from `std::istream`,
   11389             :     - @a CompatibleType is not @ref basic_json (to avoid hijacking copy/move
   11390             :          constructors),
   11391             :     - @a CompatibleType is not a different @ref basic_json type (i.e. with
   11392             :     different template arguments)
   11393             :     - @a CompatibleType is not a @ref basic_json nested type (e.g.,
   11394             :          @ref json_pointer, @ref iterator, etc ...)
   11395             :     - @ref @ref json_serializer<U> has a
   11396             :          `to_json(basic_json_t&, CompatibleType&&)` method
   11397             : 
   11398             :     @tparam U = `uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`
   11399             : 
   11400             :     @param[in] val the value to be forwarded to the respective constructor
   11401             : 
   11402             :     @complexity Usually linear in the size of the passed @a val, also
   11403             :                 depending on the implementation of the called `to_json()`
   11404             :                 method.
   11405             : 
   11406             :     @exceptionsafety Depends on the called constructor. For types directly
   11407             :     supported by the library (i.e., all types for which no `to_json()` function
   11408             :     was provided), strong guarantee holds: if an exception is thrown, there are
   11409             :     no changes to any JSON value.
   11410             : 
   11411             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with several
   11412             :     compatible types.,basic_json__CompatibleType}
   11413             : 
   11414             :     @since version 2.1.0
   11415             :     */
   11416             :     template <typename CompatibleType,
   11417             :               typename U = detail::uncvref_t<CompatibleType>,
   11418             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   11419             :                   detail::is_compatible_type<basic_json_t, U>::value, int> = 0>
   11420          77 :     basic_json(CompatibleType&& val) noexcept(
   11421             :         noexcept(JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(std::declval<basic_json_t&>(),
   11422             :                                             std::forward<CompatibleType>(val))))
   11423          77 :     {
   11424          77 :         JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(*this, std::forward<CompatibleType>(val));
   11425          77 :         assert_invariant();
   11426          77 :     }
   11427             : 
   11428             :     /*!
   11429             :     @brief create a JSON value from an existing one
   11430             : 
   11431             :     This is a constructor for existing @ref basic_json types.
   11432             :     It does not hijack copy/move constructors, since the parameter has different
   11433             :     template arguments than the current ones.
   11434             : 
   11435             :     The constructor tries to convert the internal @ref m_value of the parameter.
   11436             : 
   11437             :     @tparam BasicJsonType a type such that:
   11438             :     - @a BasicJsonType is a @ref basic_json type.
   11439             :     - @a BasicJsonType has different template arguments than @ref basic_json_t.
   11440             : 
   11441             :     @param[in] val the @ref basic_json value to be converted.
   11442             : 
   11443             :     @complexity Usually linear in the size of the passed @a val, also
   11444             :                 depending on the implementation of the called `to_json()`
   11445             :                 method.
   11446             : 
   11447             :     @exceptionsafety Depends on the called constructor. For types directly
   11448             :     supported by the library (i.e., all types for which no `to_json()` function
   11449             :     was provided), strong guarantee holds: if an exception is thrown, there are
   11450             :     no changes to any JSON value.
   11451             : 
   11452             :     @since version 3.1.2
   11453             :     */
   11454             :     template <typename BasicJsonType,
   11455             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   11456             :                   detail::is_basic_json<BasicJsonType>::value and
   11457             :                       not std::is_same<basic_json, BasicJsonType>::value,
   11458             :                   int> = 0>
   11459             :     basic_json(const BasicJsonType& val)
   11460             :     {
   11461             :         using other_boolean_t = typename BasicJsonType::boolean_t;
   11462             :         using other_number_float_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t;
   11463             :         using other_number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
   11464             :         using other_number_unsigned_t =
   11465             :             typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
   11466             :         using other_string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
   11467             :         using other_object_t = typename BasicJsonType::object_t;
   11468             :         using other_array_t = typename BasicJsonType::array_t;
   11469             : 
   11470             :         switch (val.type())
   11471             :         {
   11472             :         case value_t::boolean:
   11473             :             JSONSerializer<other_boolean_t>::to_json(
   11474             :                 *this, val.template get<other_boolean_t>());
   11475             :             break;
   11476             :         case value_t::number_float:
   11477             :             JSONSerializer<other_number_float_t>::to_json(
   11478             :                 *this, val.template get<other_number_float_t>());
   11479             :             break;
   11480             :         case value_t::number_integer:
   11481             :             JSONSerializer<other_number_integer_t>::to_json(
   11482             :                 *this, val.template get<other_number_integer_t>());
   11483             :             break;
   11484             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
   11485             :             JSONSerializer<other_number_unsigned_t>::to_json(
   11486             :                 *this, val.template get<other_number_unsigned_t>());
   11487             :             break;
   11488             :         case value_t::string:
   11489             :             JSONSerializer<other_string_t>::to_json(
   11490             :                 *this, val.template get_ref<const other_string_t&>());
   11491             :             break;
   11492             :         case value_t::object:
   11493             :             JSONSerializer<other_object_t>::to_json(
   11494             :                 *this, val.template get_ref<const other_object_t&>());
   11495             :             break;
   11496             :         case value_t::array:
   11497             :             JSONSerializer<other_array_t>::to_json(
   11498             :                 *this, val.template get_ref<const other_array_t&>());
   11499             :             break;
   11500             :         case value_t::null:
   11501             :             *this = nullptr;
   11502             :             break;
   11503             :         case value_t::discarded:
   11504             :             m_type = value_t::discarded;
   11505             :             break;
   11506             :         }
   11507             :         assert_invariant();
   11508             :     }
   11509             : 
   11510             :     /*!
   11511             :     @brief create a container (array or object) from an initializer list
   11512             : 
   11513             :     Creates a JSON value of type array or object from the passed initializer
   11514             :     list @a init. In case @a type_deduction is `true` (default), the type of
   11515             :     the JSON value to be created is deducted from the initializer list @a init
   11516             :     according to the following rules:
   11517             : 
   11518             :     1. If the list is empty, an empty JSON object value `{}` is created.
   11519             :     2. If the list consists of pairs whose first element is a string, a JSON
   11520             :        object value is created where the first elements of the pairs are
   11521             :        treated as keys and the second elements are as values.
   11522             :     3. In all other cases, an array is created.
   11523             : 
   11524             :     The rules aim to create the best fit between a C++ initializer list and
   11525             :     JSON values. The rationale is as follows:
   11526             : 
   11527             :     1. The empty initializer list is written as `{}` which is exactly an empty
   11528             :        JSON object.
   11529             :     2. C++ has no way of describing mapped types other than to list a list of
   11530             :        pairs. As JSON requires that keys must be of type string, rule 2 is the
   11531             :        weakest constraint one can pose on initializer lists to interpret them
   11532             :        as an object.
   11533             :     3. In all other cases, the initializer list could not be interpreted as
   11534             :        JSON object type, so interpreting it as JSON array type is safe.
   11535             : 
   11536             :     With the rules described above, the following JSON values cannot be
   11537             :     expressed by an initializer list:
   11538             : 
   11539             :     - the empty array (`[]`): use @ref array(initializer_list_t)
   11540             :       with an empty initializer list in this case
   11541             :     - arrays whose elements satisfy rule 2: use @ref
   11542             :       array(initializer_list_t) with the same initializer list
   11543             :       in this case
   11544             : 
   11545             :     @note When used without parentheses around an empty initializer list, @ref
   11546             :     basic_json() is called instead of this function, yielding the JSON null
   11547             :     value.
   11548             : 
   11549             :     @param[in] init  initializer list with JSON values
   11550             : 
   11551             :     @param[in] type_deduction internal parameter; when set to `true`, the type
   11552             :     of the JSON value is deducted from the initializer list @a init; when set
   11553             :     to `false`, the type provided via @a manual_type is forced. This mode is
   11554             :     used by the functions @ref array(initializer_list_t) and
   11555             :     @ref object(initializer_list_t).
   11556             : 
   11557             :     @param[in] manual_type internal parameter; when @a type_deduction is set
   11558             :     to `false`, the created JSON value will use the provided type (only @ref
   11559             :     value_t::array and @ref value_t::object are valid); when @a type_deduction
   11560             :     is set to `true`, this parameter has no effect
   11561             : 
   11562             :     @throw type_error.301 if @a type_deduction is `false`, @a manual_type is
   11563             :     `value_t::object`, but @a init contains an element which is not a pair
   11564             :     whose first element is a string. In this case, the constructor could not
   11565             :     create an object. If @a type_deduction would have be `true`, an array
   11566             :     would have been created. See @ref object(initializer_list_t)
   11567             :     for an example.
   11568             : 
   11569             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
   11570             : 
   11571             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11572             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11573             : 
   11574             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values are created from
   11575             :     initializer lists.,basic_json__list_init_t}
   11576             : 
   11577             :     @sa @ref array(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON array
   11578             :     value from an initializer list
   11579             :     @sa @ref object(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON object
   11580             :     value from an initializer list
   11581             : 
   11582             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11583             :     */
   11584             :     basic_json(initializer_list_t init, bool type_deduction = true,
   11585             :                value_t manual_type = value_t::array)
   11586             :     {
   11587             :         // check if each element is an array with two elements whose first
   11588             :         // element is a string
   11589             :         bool is_an_object =
   11590             :             std::all_of(init.begin(), init.end(),
   11591             :                         [](const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& element_ref) {
   11592             :                             return (element_ref->is_array() and
   11593             :                                     element_ref->size() == 2 and
   11594             :                                     (*element_ref)[0].is_string());
   11595             :                         });
   11596             : 
   11597             :         // adjust type if type deduction is not wanted
   11598             :         if (not type_deduction)
   11599             :         {
   11600             :             // if array is wanted, do not create an object though possible
   11601             :             if (manual_type == value_t::array)
   11602             :             {
   11603             :                 is_an_object = false;
   11604             :             }
   11605             : 
   11606             :             // if object is wanted but impossible, throw an exception
   11607             :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(manual_type == value_t::object and
   11608             :                               not is_an_object))
   11609             :             {
   11610             :                 JSON_THROW(type_error::create(
   11611             :                     301, "cannot create object from initializer list"));
   11612             :             }
   11613             :         }
   11614             : 
   11615             :         if (is_an_object)
   11616             :         {
   11617             :             // the initializer list is a list of pairs -> create object
   11618             :             m_type = value_t::object;
   11619             :             m_value = value_t::object;
   11620             : 
   11621             :             std::for_each(
   11622             :                 init.begin(), init.end(),
   11623             :                 [this](const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& element_ref) {
   11624             :                     auto element = element_ref.moved_or_copied();
   11625             :                     m_value.object->emplace(
   11626             :                         std::move(
   11627             :                             *((*element.m_value.array)[0].m_value.string)),
   11628             :                         std::move((*element.m_value.array)[1]));
   11629             :                 });
   11630             :         }
   11631             :         else
   11632             :         {
   11633             :             // the initializer list describes an array -> create array
   11634             :             m_type = value_t::array;
   11635             :             m_value.array = create<array_t>(init.begin(), init.end());
   11636             :         }
   11637             : 
   11638             :         assert_invariant();
   11639             :     }
   11640             : 
   11641             :     /*!
   11642             :     @brief explicitly create an array from an initializer list
   11643             : 
   11644             :     Creates a JSON array value from a given initializer list. That is, given a
   11645             :     list of values `a, b, c`, creates the JSON value `[a, b, c]`. If the
   11646             :     initializer list is empty, the empty array `[]` is created.
   11647             : 
   11648             :     @note This function is only needed to express two edge cases that cannot
   11649             :     be realized with the initializer list constructor (@ref
   11650             :     basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t)). These cases
   11651             :     are:
   11652             :     1. creating an array whose elements are all pairs whose first element is a
   11653             :     string -- in this case, the initializer list constructor would create an
   11654             :     object, taking the first elements as keys
   11655             :     2. creating an empty array -- passing the empty initializer list to the
   11656             :     initializer list constructor yields an empty object
   11657             : 
   11658             :     @param[in] init  initializer list with JSON values to create an array from
   11659             :     (optional)
   11660             : 
   11661             :     @return JSON array value
   11662             : 
   11663             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
   11664             : 
   11665             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11666             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11667             : 
   11668             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `array`
   11669             :     function.,array}
   11670             : 
   11671             :     @sa @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t) --
   11672             :     create a JSON value from an initializer list
   11673             :     @sa @ref object(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON object
   11674             :     value from an initializer list
   11675             : 
   11676             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11677             :     */
   11678             :     static basic_json array(initializer_list_t init = {})
   11679             :     {
   11680             :         return basic_json(init, false, value_t::array);
   11681             :     }
   11682             : 
   11683             :     /*!
   11684             :     @brief explicitly create an object from an initializer list
   11685             : 
   11686             :     Creates a JSON object value from a given initializer list. The initializer
   11687             :     lists elements must be pairs, and their first elements must be strings. If
   11688             :     the initializer list is empty, the empty object `{}` is created.
   11689             : 
   11690             :     @note This function is only added for symmetry reasons. In contrast to the
   11691             :     related function @ref array(initializer_list_t), there are
   11692             :     no cases which can only be expressed by this function. That is, any
   11693             :     initializer list @a init can also be passed to the initializer list
   11694             :     constructor @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t).
   11695             : 
   11696             :     @param[in] init  initializer list to create an object from (optional)
   11697             : 
   11698             :     @return JSON object value
   11699             : 
   11700             :     @throw type_error.301 if @a init is not a list of pairs whose first
   11701             :     elements are strings. In this case, no object can be created. When such a
   11702             :     value is passed to @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t),
   11703             :     an array would have been created from the passed initializer list @a init.
   11704             :     See example below.
   11705             : 
   11706             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
   11707             : 
   11708             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11709             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11710             : 
   11711             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `object`
   11712             :     function.,object}
   11713             : 
   11714             :     @sa @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t) --
   11715             :     create a JSON value from an initializer list
   11716             :     @sa @ref array(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON array
   11717             :     value from an initializer list
   11718             : 
   11719             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11720             :     */
   11721             :     static basic_json object(initializer_list_t init = {})
   11722             :     {
   11723             :         return basic_json(init, false, value_t::object);
   11724             :     }
   11725             : 
   11726             :     /*!
   11727             :     @brief construct an array with count copies of given value
   11728             : 
   11729             :     Constructs a JSON array value by creating @a cnt copies of a passed value.
   11730             :     In case @a cnt is `0`, an empty array is created.
   11731             : 
   11732             :     @param[in] cnt  the number of JSON copies of @a val to create
   11733             :     @param[in] val  the JSON value to copy
   11734             : 
   11735             :     @post `std::distance(begin(),end()) == cnt` holds.
   11736             : 
   11737             :     @complexity Linear in @a cnt.
   11738             : 
   11739             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11740             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11741             : 
   11742             :     @liveexample{The following code shows examples for the @ref
   11743             :     basic_json(size_type\, const basic_json&)
   11744             :     constructor.,basic_json__size_type_basic_json}
   11745             : 
   11746             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11747             :     */
   11748             :     basic_json(size_type cnt, const basic_json& val)
   11749             :         : m_type(value_t::array)
   11750             :     {
   11751             :         m_value.array = create<array_t>(cnt, val);
   11752             :         assert_invariant();
   11753             :     }
   11754             : 
   11755             :     /*!
   11756             :     @brief construct a JSON container given an iterator range
   11757             : 
   11758             :     Constructs the JSON value with the contents of the range `[first, last)`.
   11759             :     The semantics depends on the different types a JSON value can have:
   11760             :     - In case of a null type, invalid_iterator.206 is thrown.
   11761             :     - In case of other primitive types (number, boolean, or string), @a first
   11762             :       must be `begin()` and @a last must be `end()`. In this case, the value is
   11763             :       copied. Otherwise, invalid_iterator.204 is thrown.
   11764             :     - In case of structured types (array, object), the constructor behaves as
   11765             :       similar versions for `std::vector` or `std::map`; that is, a JSON array
   11766             :       or object is constructed from the values in the range.
   11767             : 
   11768             :     @tparam InputIT an input iterator type (@ref iterator or @ref
   11769             :     const_iterator)
   11770             : 
   11771             :     @param[in] first begin of the range to copy from (included)
   11772             :     @param[in] last end of the range to copy from (excluded)
   11773             : 
   11774             :     @pre Iterators @a first and @a last must be initialized. **This
   11775             :          precondition is enforced with an assertion (see warning).** If
   11776             :          assertions are switched off, a violation of this precondition yields
   11777             :          undefined behavior.
   11778             : 
   11779             :     @pre Range `[first, last)` is valid. Usually, this precondition cannot be
   11780             :          checked efficiently. Only certain edge cases are detected; see the
   11781             :          description of the exceptions below. A violation of this precondition
   11782             :          yields undefined behavior.
   11783             : 
   11784             :     @warning A precondition is enforced with a runtime assertion that will
   11785             :              result in calling `std::abort` if this precondition is not met.
   11786             :              Assertions can be disabled by defining `NDEBUG` at compile time.
   11787             :              See http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/error/assert for more
   11788             :              information.
   11789             : 
   11790             :     @throw invalid_iterator.201 if iterators @a first and @a last are not
   11791             :     compatible (i.e., do not belong to the same JSON value). In this case,
   11792             :     the range `[first, last)` is undefined.
   11793             :     @throw invalid_iterator.204 if iterators @a first and @a last belong to a
   11794             :     primitive type (number, boolean, or string), but @a first does not point
   11795             :     to the first element any more. In this case, the range `[first, last)` is
   11796             :     undefined. See example code below.
   11797             :     @throw invalid_iterator.206 if iterators @a first and @a last belong to a
   11798             :     null value. In this case, the range `[first, last)` is undefined.
   11799             : 
   11800             :     @complexity Linear in distance between @a first and @a last.
   11801             : 
   11802             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11803             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11804             : 
   11805             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several ways to create JSON values by
   11806             :     specifying a subrange with iterators.,basic_json__InputIt_InputIt}
   11807             : 
   11808             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11809             :     */
   11810             :     template <
   11811             :         class InputIT,
   11812             :         typename std::enable_if<
   11813             :             std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
   11814             :                 std::is_same<InputIT,
   11815             :                              typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value,
   11816             :             int>::type = 0>
   11817             :     basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last)
   11818             :     {
   11819             :         assert(first.m_object != nullptr);
   11820             :         assert(last.m_object != nullptr);
   11821             : 
   11822             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
   11823             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
   11824             :         {
   11825             :             JSON_THROW(
   11826             :                 invalid_iterator::create(201, "iterators are not compatible"));
   11827             :         }
   11828             : 
   11829             :         // copy type from first iterator
   11830             :         m_type = first.m_object->m_type;
   11831             : 
   11832             :         // check if iterator range is complete for primitive values
   11833             :         switch (m_type)
   11834             :         {
   11835             :         case value_t::boolean:
   11836             :         case value_t::number_float:
   11837             :         case value_t::number_integer:
   11838             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
   11839             :         case value_t::string:
   11840             :         {
   11841             :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin() or
   11842             :                               not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end()))
   11843             :             {
   11844             :                 JSON_THROW(
   11845             :                     invalid_iterator::create(204, "iterators out of range"));
   11846             :             }
   11847             :             break;
   11848             :         }
   11849             : 
   11850             :         default:
   11851             :             break;
   11852             :         }
   11853             : 
   11854             :         switch (m_type)
   11855             :         {
   11856             :         case value_t::number_integer:
   11857             :         {
   11858             :             m_value.number_integer = first.m_object->m_value.number_integer;
   11859             :             break;
   11860             :         }
   11861             : 
   11862             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
   11863             :         {
   11864             :             m_value.number_unsigned = first.m_object->m_value.number_unsigned;
   11865             :             break;
   11866             :         }
   11867             : 
   11868             :         case value_t::number_float:
   11869             :         {
   11870             :             m_value.number_float = first.m_object->m_value.number_float;
   11871             :             break;
   11872             :         }
   11873             : 
   11874             :         case value_t::boolean:
   11875             :         {
   11876             :             m_value.boolean = first.m_object->m_value.boolean;
   11877             :             break;
   11878             :         }
   11879             : 
   11880             :         case value_t::string:
   11881             :         {
   11882             :             m_value = *first.m_object->m_value.string;
   11883             :             break;
   11884             :         }
   11885             : 
   11886             :         case value_t::object:
   11887             :         {
   11888             :             m_value.object = create<object_t>(first.m_it.object_iterator,
   11889             :                                               last.m_it.object_iterator);
   11890             :             break;
   11891             :         }
   11892             : 
   11893             :         case value_t::array:
   11894             :         {
   11895             :             m_value.array = create<array_t>(first.m_it.array_iterator,
   11896             :                                             last.m_it.array_iterator);
   11897             :             break;
   11898             :         }
   11899             : 
   11900             :         default:
   11901             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   11902             :                 206, "cannot construct with iterators from " +
   11903             :                          std::string(first.m_object->type_name())));
   11904             :         }
   11905             : 
   11906             :         assert_invariant();
   11907             :     }
   11908             : 
   11909             :     ///////////////////////////////////////
   11910             :     // other constructors and destructor //
   11911             :     ///////////////////////////////////////
   11912             : 
   11913             :     /// @private
   11914             :     basic_json(const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& ref)
   11915             :         : basic_json(ref.moved_or_copied())
   11916             :     {
   11917             :     }
   11918             : 
   11919             :     /*!
   11920             :     @brief copy constructor
   11921             : 
   11922             :     Creates a copy of a given JSON value.
   11923             : 
   11924             :     @param[in] other  the JSON value to copy
   11925             : 
   11926             :     @post `*this == other`
   11927             : 
   11928             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a other.
   11929             : 
   11930             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11931             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11932             : 
   11933             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   11934             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   11935             :     requirements:
   11936             :     - The complexity is linear.
   11937             :     - As postcondition, it holds: `other == basic_json(other)`.
   11938             : 
   11939             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the copy
   11940             :     constructor.,basic_json__basic_json}
   11941             : 
   11942             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11943             :     */
   11944         462 :     basic_json(const basic_json& other)
   11945         462 :         : m_type(other.m_type)
   11946             :     {
   11947             :         // check of passed value is valid
   11948         462 :         other.assert_invariant();
   11949             : 
   11950         462 :         switch (m_type)
   11951             :         {
   11952             :         case value_t::object:
   11953             :         {
   11954          55 :             m_value = *other.m_value.object;
   11955          55 :             break;
   11956             :         }
   11957             : 
   11958             :         case value_t::array:
   11959             :         {
   11960          22 :             m_value = *other.m_value.array;
   11961          22 :             break;
   11962             :         }
   11963             : 
   11964             :         case value_t::string:
   11965             :         {
   11966         352 :             m_value = *other.m_value.string;
   11967         352 :             break;
   11968             :         }
   11969             : 
   11970             :         case value_t::boolean:
   11971             :         {
   11972           0 :             m_value = other.m_value.boolean;
   11973           0 :             break;
   11974             :         }
   11975             : 
   11976             :         case value_t::number_integer:
   11977             :         {
   11978           0 :             m_value = other.m_value.number_integer;
   11979           0 :             break;
   11980             :         }
   11981             : 
   11982             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
   11983             :         {
   11984           0 :             m_value = other.m_value.number_unsigned;
   11985           0 :             break;
   11986             :         }
   11987             : 
   11988             :         case value_t::number_float:
   11989             :         {
   11990           0 :             m_value = other.m_value.number_float;
   11991           0 :             break;
   11992             :         }
   11993             : 
   11994             :         default:
   11995          33 :             break;
   11996             :         }
   11997             : 
   11998         462 :         assert_invariant();
   11999         462 :     }
   12000             : 
   12001             :     /*!
   12002             :     @brief move constructor
   12003             : 
   12004             :     Move constructor. Constructs a JSON value with the contents of the given
   12005             :     value @a other using move semantics. It "steals" the resources from @a
   12006             :     other and leaves it as JSON null value.
   12007             : 
   12008             :     @param[in,out] other  value to move to this object
   12009             : 
   12010             :     @post `*this` has the same value as @a other before the call.
   12011             :     @post @a other is a JSON null value.
   12012             : 
   12013             :     @complexity Constant.
   12014             : 
   12015             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this constructor never throws
   12016             :     exceptions.
   12017             : 
   12018             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   12019             :     [MoveConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveConstructible)
   12020             :     requirements.
   12021             : 
   12022             :     @liveexample{The code below shows the move constructor explicitly called
   12023             :     via std::move.,basic_json__moveconstructor}
   12024             : 
   12025             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12026             :     */
   12027         231 :     basic_json(basic_json&& other) noexcept : m_type(std::move(other.m_type)),
   12028         231 :                                               m_value(std::move(other.m_value))
   12029             :     {
   12030             :         // check that passed value is valid
   12031         231 :         other.assert_invariant();
   12032             : 
   12033             :         // invalidate payload
   12034         231 :         other.m_type = value_t::null;
   12035         231 :         other.m_value = {};
   12036             : 
   12037         231 :         assert_invariant();
   12038         231 :     }
   12039             : 
   12040             :     /*!
   12041             :     @brief copy assignment
   12042             : 
   12043             :     Copy assignment operator. Copies a JSON value via the "copy and swap"
   12044             :     strategy: It is expressed in terms of the copy constructor, destructor,
   12045             :     and the `swap()` member function.
   12046             : 
   12047             :     @param[in] other  value to copy from
   12048             : 
   12049             :     @complexity Linear.
   12050             : 
   12051             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   12052             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   12053             :     requirements:
   12054             :     - The complexity is linear.
   12055             : 
   12056             :     @liveexample{The code below shows and example for the copy assignment. It
   12057             :     creates a copy of value `a` which is then swapped with `b`. Finally\, the
   12058             :     copy of `a` (which is the null value after the swap) is
   12059             :     destroyed.,basic_json__copyassignment}
   12060             : 
   12061             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12062             :     */
   12063         319 :     reference& operator=(basic_json other) noexcept(
   12064             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
   12065             :             std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
   12066             :                 std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
   12067             :                     std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value)
   12068             :     {
   12069             :         // check that passed value is valid
   12070         319 :         other.assert_invariant();
   12071             : 
   12072             :         using std::swap;
   12073         319 :         swap(m_type, other.m_type);
   12074         319 :         swap(m_value, other.m_value);
   12075             : 
   12076         319 :         assert_invariant();
   12077         319 :         return *this;
   12078             :     }
   12079             : 
   12080             :     /*!
   12081             :     @brief destructor
   12082             : 
   12083             :     Destroys the JSON value and frees all allocated memory.
   12084             : 
   12085             :     @complexity Linear.
   12086             : 
   12087             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   12088             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   12089             :     requirements:
   12090             :     - The complexity is linear.
   12091             :     - All stored elements are destroyed and all memory is freed.
   12092             : 
   12093             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12094             :     */
   12095        1232 :     ~basic_json() noexcept
   12096             :     {
   12097        1232 :         assert_invariant();
   12098        1232 :         m_value.destroy(m_type);
   12099        1232 :     }
   12100             : 
   12101             :     /// @}
   12102             : 
   12103             : public:
   12104             :     ///////////////////////
   12105             :     // object inspection //
   12106             :     ///////////////////////
   12107             : 
   12108             :     /// @name object inspection
   12109             :     /// Functions to inspect the type of a JSON value.
   12110             :     /// @{
   12111             : 
   12112             :     /*!
   12113             :     @brief serialization
   12114             : 
   12115             :     Serialization function for JSON values. The function tries to mimic
   12116             :     Python's `json.dumps()` function, and currently supports its @a indent
   12117             :     and @a ensure_ascii parameters.
   12118             : 
   12119             :     @param[in] indent If indent is nonnegative, then array elements and object
   12120             :     members will be pretty-printed with that indent level. An indent level of
   12121             :     `0` will only insert newlines. `-1` (the default) selects the most compact
   12122             :     representation.
   12123             :     @param[in] indent_char The character to use for indentation if @a indent is
   12124             :     greater than `0`. The default is ` ` (space).
   12125             :     @param[in] ensure_ascii If @a ensure_ascii is true, all non-ASCII characters
   12126             :     in the output are escaped with `\uXXXX` sequences, and the result consists
   12127             :     of ASCII characters only.
   12128             : 
   12129             :     @return string containing the serialization of the JSON value
   12130             : 
   12131             :     @throw type_error.316 if a string stored inside the JSON value is not
   12132             :                           UTF-8 encoded
   12133             : 
   12134             :     @complexity Linear.
   12135             : 
   12136             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12137             :     changes in the JSON value.
   12138             : 
   12139             :     @liveexample{The following example shows the effect of different @a indent\,
   12140             :     @a indent_char\, and @a ensure_ascii parameters to the result of the
   12141             :     serialization.,dump}
   12142             : 
   12143             :     @see https://docs.python.org/2/library/json.html#json.dump
   12144             : 
   12145             :     @since version 1.0.0; indentation character @a indent_char, option
   12146             :            @a ensure_ascii and exceptions added in version 3.0.0
   12147             :     */
   12148             :     string_t dump(const int indent = -1, const char indent_char = ' ',
   12149             :                   const bool ensure_ascii = false) const
   12150             :     {
   12151             :         string_t result;
   12152             :         serializer s(detail::output_adapter<char, string_t>(result),
   12153             :                      indent_char);
   12154             : 
   12155             :         if (indent >= 0)
   12156             :         {
   12157             :             s.dump(*this, true, ensure_ascii,
   12158             :                    static_cast<unsigned int>(indent));
   12159             :         }
   12160             :         else
   12161             :         {
   12162             :             s.dump(*this, false, ensure_ascii, 0);
   12163             :         }
   12164             : 
   12165             :         return result;
   12166             :     }
   12167             : 
   12168             :     /*!
   12169             :     @brief return the type of the JSON value (explicit)
   12170             : 
   12171             :     Return the type of the JSON value as a value from the @ref value_t
   12172             :     enumeration.
   12173             : 
   12174             :     @return the type of the JSON value
   12175             :             Value type                | return value
   12176             :             ------------------------- | -------------------------
   12177             :             null                      | value_t::null
   12178             :             boolean                   | value_t::boolean
   12179             :             string                    | value_t::string
   12180             :             number (integer)          | value_t::number_integer
   12181             :             number (unsigned integer) | value_t::number_unsigned
   12182             :             number (floating-point)   | value_t::number_float
   12183             :             object                    | value_t::object
   12184             :             array                     | value_t::array
   12185             :             discarded                 | value_t::discarded
   12186             : 
   12187             :     @complexity Constant.
   12188             : 
   12189             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12190             :     exceptions.
   12191             : 
   12192             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `type()` for all JSON
   12193             :     types.,type}
   12194             : 
   12195             :     @sa @ref operator value_t() -- return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
   12196             :     @sa @ref type_name() -- return the type as string
   12197             : 
   12198             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12199             :     */
   12200             :     constexpr value_t type() const noexcept { return m_type; }
   12201             :     /*!
   12202             :     @brief return whether type is primitive
   12203             : 
   12204             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON type is primitive
   12205             :     (string, number, boolean, or null).
   12206             : 
   12207             :     @return `true` if type is primitive (string, number, boolean, or null),
   12208             :     `false` otherwise.
   12209             : 
   12210             :     @complexity Constant.
   12211             : 
   12212             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12213             :     exceptions.
   12214             : 
   12215             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_primitive()` for all JSON
   12216             :     types.,is_primitive}
   12217             : 
   12218             :     @sa @ref is_structured() -- returns whether JSON value is structured
   12219             :     @sa @ref is_null() -- returns whether JSON value is `null`
   12220             :     @sa @ref is_string() -- returns whether JSON value is a string
   12221             :     @sa @ref is_boolean() -- returns whether JSON value is a boolean
   12222             :     @sa @ref is_number() -- returns whether JSON value is a number
   12223             : 
   12224             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12225             :     */
   12226         121 :     constexpr bool is_primitive() const noexcept
   12227             :     {
   12228         121 :         return is_null() or is_string() or is_boolean() or is_number();
   12229             :     }
   12230             : 
   12231             :     /*!
   12232             :     @brief return whether type is structured
   12233             : 
   12234             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON type is structured
   12235             :     (array or object).
   12236             : 
   12237             :     @return `true` if type is structured (array or object), `false` otherwise.
   12238             : 
   12239             :     @complexity Constant.
   12240             : 
   12241             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12242             :     exceptions.
   12243             : 
   12244             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_structured()` for all JSON
   12245             :     types.,is_structured}
   12246             : 
   12247             :     @sa @ref is_primitive() -- returns whether value is primitive
   12248             :     @sa @ref is_array() -- returns whether value is an array
   12249             :     @sa @ref is_object() -- returns whether value is an object
   12250             : 
   12251             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12252             :     */
   12253             :     constexpr bool is_structured() const noexcept
   12254             :     {
   12255             :         return is_array() or is_object();
   12256             :     }
   12257             : 
   12258             :     /*!
   12259             :     @brief return whether value is null
   12260             : 
   12261             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is null.
   12262             : 
   12263             :     @return `true` if type is null, `false` otherwise.
   12264             : 
   12265             :     @complexity Constant.
   12266             : 
   12267             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12268             :     exceptions.
   12269             : 
   12270             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_null()` for all JSON
   12271             :     types.,is_null}
   12272             : 
   12273             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12274             :     */
   12275         605 :     constexpr bool is_null() const noexcept
   12276             :     {
   12277         605 :         return (m_type == value_t::null);
   12278             :     }
   12279             : 
   12280             :     /*!
   12281             :     @brief return whether value is a boolean
   12282             : 
   12283             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a boolean.
   12284             : 
   12285             :     @return `true` if type is boolean, `false` otherwise.
   12286             : 
   12287             :     @complexity Constant.
   12288             : 
   12289             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12290             :     exceptions.
   12291             : 
   12292             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_boolean()` for all JSON
   12293             :     types.,is_boolean}
   12294             : 
   12295             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12296             :     */
   12297           0 :     constexpr bool is_boolean() const noexcept
   12298             :     {
   12299           0 :         return (m_type == value_t::boolean);
   12300             :     }
   12301             : 
   12302             :     /*!
   12303             :     @brief return whether value is a number
   12304             : 
   12305             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a number. This
   12306             :     includes both integer (signed and unsigned) and floating-point values.
   12307             : 
   12308             :     @return `true` if type is number (regardless whether integer, unsigned
   12309             :     integer or floating-type), `false` otherwise.
   12310             : 
   12311             :     @complexity Constant.
   12312             : 
   12313             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12314             :     exceptions.
   12315             : 
   12316             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number()` for all JSON
   12317             :     types.,is_number}
   12318             : 
   12319             :     @sa @ref is_number_integer() -- check if value is an integer or unsigned
   12320             :     integer number
   12321             :     @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
   12322             :     number
   12323             :     @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
   12324             : 
   12325             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12326             :     */
   12327           0 :     constexpr bool is_number() const noexcept
   12328             :     {
   12329           0 :         return is_number_integer() or is_number_float();
   12330             :     }
   12331             : 
   12332             :     /*!
   12333             :     @brief return whether value is an integer number
   12334             : 
   12335             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a signed or
   12336             :     unsigned integer number. This excludes floating-point values.
   12337             : 
   12338             :     @return `true` if type is an integer or unsigned integer number, `false`
   12339             :     otherwise.
   12340             : 
   12341             :     @complexity Constant.
   12342             : 
   12343             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12344             :     exceptions.
   12345             : 
   12346             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number_integer()` for all
   12347             :     JSON types.,is_number_integer}
   12348             : 
   12349             :     @sa @ref is_number() -- check if value is a number
   12350             :     @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
   12351             :     number
   12352             :     @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
   12353             : 
   12354             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12355             :     */
   12356           0 :     constexpr bool is_number_integer() const noexcept
   12357             :     {
   12358           0 :         return (m_type == value_t::number_integer or
   12359           0 :                 m_type == value_t::number_unsigned);
   12360             :     }
   12361             : 
   12362             :     /*!
   12363             :     @brief return whether value is an unsigned integer number
   12364             : 
   12365             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is an unsigned
   12366             :     integer number. This excludes floating-point and signed integer values.
   12367             : 
   12368             :     @return `true` if type is an unsigned integer number, `false` otherwise.
   12369             : 
   12370             :     @complexity Constant.
   12371             : 
   12372             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12373             :     exceptions.
   12374             : 
   12375             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number_unsigned()` for all
   12376             :     JSON types.,is_number_unsigned}
   12377             : 
   12378             :     @sa @ref is_number() -- check if value is a number
   12379             :     @sa @ref is_number_integer() -- check if value is an integer or unsigned
   12380             :     integer number
   12381             :     @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
   12382             : 
   12383             :     @since version 2.0.0
   12384             :     */
   12385             :     constexpr bool is_number_unsigned() const noexcept
   12386             :     {
   12387             :         return (m_type == value_t::number_unsigned);
   12388             :     }
   12389             : 
   12390             :     /*!
   12391             :     @brief return whether value is a floating-point number
   12392             : 
   12393             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a
   12394             :     floating-point number. This excludes signed and unsigned integer values.
   12395             : 
   12396             :     @return `true` if type is a floating-point number, `false` otherwise.
   12397             : 
   12398             :     @complexity Constant.
   12399             : 
   12400             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12401             :     exceptions.
   12402             : 
   12403             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number_float()` for all
   12404             :     JSON types.,is_number_float}
   12405             : 
   12406             :     @sa @ref is_number() -- check if value is number
   12407             :     @sa @ref is_number_integer() -- check if value is an integer number
   12408             :     @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
   12409             :     number
   12410             : 
   12411             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12412             :     */
   12413           0 :     constexpr bool is_number_float() const noexcept
   12414             :     {
   12415           0 :         return (m_type == value_t::number_float);
   12416             :     }
   12417             : 
   12418             :     /*!
   12419             :     @brief return whether value is an object
   12420             : 
   12421             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is an object.
   12422             : 
   12423             :     @return `true` if type is object, `false` otherwise.
   12424             : 
   12425             :     @complexity Constant.
   12426             : 
   12427             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12428             :     exceptions.
   12429             :

   12431             :     types.,is_object}
   12432             : 
   12433             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12434             :     */
   12435         616 :     constexpr bool is_object() const noexcept
   12436             :     {
   12437         616 :         return (m_type == value_t::object);
   12438             :     }
   12439             : 
   12440             :     /*!
   12441             :     @brief return whether value is an array
   12442             :

   12444             :

   12450             :     exceptions.

   12460             :     }
   12461             : 
   12462             :     /*!
   12463             :     @brief return whether value is a string
   12464             :

   12466             :

   12470             :

   12472             :     exceptions.

   12475             :     types.,is_string}
