   12479         726 :     constexpr bool is_string() const noexcept
   12480             :     {
   12481         726 :         return (m_type == value_t::string);
   12482             :     }
   12483             : 
   12484             :     /*!
   12485             :     @brief return whether value is discarded
   12486             : 
   12487             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value was discarded
   12488             :     during parsing with a callback function (see @ref parser_callback_t).
   12489             : 
   12490             :     @note This function will always be `false` for JSON values after parsing.
   12491             :     That is, discarded values can only occur during parsing, but will be
   12492             :     removed when inside a structured value or replaced by null in other cases.
   12493             : 
   12494             :     @return `true` if type is discarded, `false` otherwise.
   12495             : 
   12496             :     @complexity Constant.
   12497             : 
   12498             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12499             :     exceptions.
   12500             : 
   12501             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_discarded()` for all JSON
   12502             :     types.,is_discarded}
   12503             : 
   12504             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12505             :     */
   12506         440 :     constexpr bool is_discarded() const noexcept
   12507             :     {
   12508         440 :         return (m_type == value_t::discarded);
   12509             :     }
   12510             : 
   12511             :     /*!
   12512             :     @brief return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
   12513             : 
   12514             :     Implicitly return the type of the JSON value as a value from the @ref
   12515             :     value_t enumeration.
   12516             : 
   12517             :     @return the type of the JSON value
   12518             : 
   12519             :     @complexity Constant.
   12520             : 
   12521             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12522             :     exceptions.
   12523             : 
   12524             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies the @ref value_t operator for
   12525             :     all JSON types.,operator__value_t}
   12526             : 
   12527             :     @sa @ref type() -- return the type of the JSON value (explicit)
   12528             :     @sa @ref type_name() -- return the type as string
   12529             : 
   12530             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12531             :     */
   12532             :     constexpr operator value_t() const noexcept { return m_type; }
   12533             :     /// @}
   12534             : 
   12535             : private:
   12536             :     //////////////////
   12537             :     // value access //
   12538             :     //////////////////
   12539             : 
   12540             :     /// get a boolean (explicit)
   12541             :     boolean_t get_impl(boolean_t* /*unused*/) const
   12542             :     {
   12543             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_boolean()))
   12544             :         {
   12545             :             return m_value.boolean;
   12546             :         }
   12547             : 
   12548             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(302, "type must be boolean, but is " +
   12549             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   12550             :     }
   12551             : 
   12552             :     /// get a pointer to the value (object)
   12553             :     object_t* get_impl_ptr(object_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
   12554             :     {
   12555             :         return is_object() ? m_value.object : nullptr;
   12556             :     }
   12557             : 
   12558             :     /// get a pointer to the value (object)
   12559             :     constexpr const object_t* get_impl_ptr(const object_t* /*unused*/) const
   12560             :         noexcept
   12561             :     {
   12562             :         return is_object() ? m_value.object : nullptr;
   12563             :     }
   12564             : 
   12565             :     /// get a pointer to the value (array)
   12566             :     array_t* get_impl_ptr(array_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
   12567             :     {
   12568             :         return is_array() ? m_value.array : nullptr;
   12569             :     }
   12570             : 
   12571             :     /// get a pointer to the value (array)
   12572             :     constexpr const array_t* get_impl_ptr(const array_t* /*unused*/) const
   12573             :         noexcept
   12574             :     {
   12575             :         return is_array() ? m_value.array : nullptr;
   12576             :     }
   12577             : 
   12578             :     /// get a pointer to the value (string)
   12579             :     string_t* get_impl_ptr(string_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
   12580             :     {
   12581             :         return is_string() ? m_value.string : nullptr;
   12582             :     }
   12583             : 
   12584             :     /// get a pointer to the value (string)
   12585         242 :     constexpr const string_t* get_impl_ptr(const string_t* /*unused*/) const
   12586             :         noexcept
   12587             :     {
   12588         242 :         return is_string() ? m_value.string : nullptr;
   12589             :     }
   12590             : 
   12591             :     /// get a pointer to the value (boolean)
   12592             :     boolean_t* get_impl_ptr(boolean_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
   12593             :     {
   12594             :         return is_boolean() ? &m_value.boolean : nullptr;
   12595             :     }
   12596             : 
   12597             :     /// get a pointer to the value (boolean)
   12598             :     constexpr const boolean_t* get_impl_ptr(const boolean_t* /*unused*/) const
   12599             :         noexcept
   12600             :     {
   12601             :         return is_boolean() ? &m_value.boolean : nullptr;
   12602             :     }
   12603             : 
   12604             :     /// get a pointer to the value (integer number)
   12605             :     number_integer_t* get_impl_ptr(number_integer_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
   12606             :     {
   12607             :         return is_number_integer() ? &m_value.number_integer : nullptr;
   12608             :     }
   12609             : 
   12610             :     /// get a pointer to the value (integer number)
   12611             :     constexpr const number_integer_t* get_impl_ptr(
   12612             :         const number_integer_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
   12613             :     {
   12614             :         return is_number_integer() ? &m_value.number_integer : nullptr;
   12615             :     }
   12616             : 
   12617             :     /// get a pointer to the value (unsigned number)
   12618             :     number_unsigned_t* get_impl_ptr(number_unsigned_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
   12619             :     {
   12620             :         return is_number_unsigned() ? &m_value.number_unsigned : nullptr;
   12621             :     }
   12622             : 
   12623             :     /// get a pointer to the value (unsigned number)
   12624             :     constexpr const number_unsigned_t* get_impl_ptr(
   12625             :         const number_unsigned_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
   12626             :     {
   12627             :         return is_number_unsigned() ? &m_value.number_unsigned : nullptr;
   12628             :     }
   12629             : 
   12630             :     /// get a pointer to the value (floating-point number)
   12631             :     number_float_t* get_impl_ptr(number_float_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
   12632             :     {
   12633             :         return is_number_float() ? &m_value.number_float : nullptr;
   12634             :     }
   12635             : 
   12636             :     /// get a pointer to the value (floating-point number)
   12637             :     constexpr const number_float_t* get_impl_ptr(
   12638             :         const number_float_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
   12639             :     {
   12640             :         return is_number_float() ? &m_value.number_float : nullptr;
   12641             :     }
   12642             : 
   12643             :     /*!
   12644             :     @brief helper function to implement get_ref()
   12645             : 
   12646             :     This function helps to implement get_ref() without code duplication for
   12647             :     const and non-const overloads
   12648             : 
   12649             :     @tparam ThisType will be deduced as `basic_json` or `const basic_json`
   12650             : 
   12651             :     @throw type_error.303 if ReferenceType does not match underlying value
   12652             :     type of the current JSON
   12653             :     */
   12654             :     template <typename ReferenceType, typename ThisType>
   12655             :     static ReferenceType get_ref_impl(ThisType& obj)
   12656             :     {
   12657             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr<>()
   12658             :         auto ptr = obj.template get_ptr<
   12659             :             typename std::add_pointer<ReferenceType>::type>();
   12660             : 
   12661             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(ptr != nullptr))
   12662             :         {
   12663             :             return *ptr;
   12664             :         }
   12665             : 
   12666             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(
   12667             :             303, "incompatible ReferenceType for get_ref, actual type is " +
   12668             :                      std::string(obj.type_name())));
   12669             :     }
   12670             : 
   12671             : public:
   12672             :     /// @name value access
   12673             :     /// Direct access to the stored value of a JSON value.
   12674             :     /// @{
   12675             : 
   12676             :     /*!
   12677             :     @brief get special-case overload
   12678             : 
   12679             :     This overloads avoids a lot of template boilerplate, it can be seen as the
   12680             :     identity method
   12681             : 
   12682             :     @tparam BasicJsonType == @ref basic_json
   12683             : 
   12684             :     @return a copy of *this
   12685             : 
   12686             :     @complexity Constant.
   12687             : 
   12688             :     @since version 2.1.0
   12689             :     */
   12690             :     template <typename BasicJsonType,
   12691             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   12692             :                   std::is_same<typename std::remove_const<BasicJsonType>::type,
   12693             :                                basic_json_t>::value,
   12694             :                   int> = 0>
   12695             :     basic_json get() const
   12696             :     {
   12697             :         return *this;
   12698             :     }
   12699             : 
   12700             :     /*!
   12701             :     @brief get special-case overload
   12702             : 
   12703             :     This overloads converts the current @ref basic_json in a different
   12704             :     @ref basic_json type
   12705             : 
   12706             :     @tparam BasicJsonType == @ref basic_json
   12707             : 
   12708             :     @return a copy of *this, converted into @tparam BasicJsonType
   12709             : 
   12710             :     @complexity Depending on the implementation of the called `from_json()`
   12711             :                 method.
   12712             : 
   12713             :     @since version 3.1.2
   12714             :     */
   12715             :     template <typename BasicJsonType,
   12716             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   12717             :                   not std::is_same<BasicJsonType, basic_json>::value and
   12718             :                       detail::is_basic_json<BasicJsonType>::value,
   12719             :                   int> = 0>
   12720             :     BasicJsonType get() const
   12721             :     {
   12722             :         return *this;
   12723             :     }
   12724             : 
   12725             :     /*!
   12726             :     @brief get a value (explicit)
   12727             : 
   12728             :     Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
   12729             :     which is
   12730             :     [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible)
   12731             :     and
   12732             :     [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible).
   12733             :     The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
   12734             :     `from_json()` method.
   12735             : 
   12736             :     The function is equivalent to executing
   12737             :     @code {.cpp}
   12738             :     ValueType ret;
   12739             :     JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
   12740             :     return ret;
   12741             :     @endcode
   12742             : 
   12743             :     This overloads is chosen if:
   12744             :     - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json,
   12745             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
   12746             :       `void from_json(const basic_json&, ValueType&)`, and
   12747             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> does not have a `from_json()` method of
   12748             :       the form `ValueType from_json(const basic_json&)`
   12749             : 
   12750             :     @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
   12751             :     @tparam ValueType the returned value type
   12752             : 
   12753             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
   12754             : 
   12755             :     @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
   12756             : 
   12757             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
   12758             :     to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
   12759             :     be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
   12760             :     `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
   12761             :     associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
   12762             :     json>`.,get__ValueType_const}
   12763             : 
   12764             :     @since version 2.1.0
   12765             :     */
   12766             :     template <typename ValueTypeCV,
   12767             :               typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
   12768             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   12769             :                   not detail::is_basic_json<ValueType>::value and
   12770             :                       detail::has_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
   12771             :                       not detail::has_non_default_from_json<basic_json_t,
   12772             :                                                             ValueType>::value,
   12773             :                   int> = 0>
   12774         242 :     ValueType get() const
   12775             :         noexcept(noexcept(JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(
   12776             :             std::declval<const basic_json_t&>(), std::declval<ValueType&>())))
   12777             :     {
   12778             :         // we cannot static_assert on ValueTypeCV being non-const, because
   12779             :         // there is support for get<const basic_json_t>(), which is why we
   12780             :         // still need the uncvref
   12781             :         static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
   12782             :                       "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might "
   12783             :                       "want to use get_ref()");
   12784             :         static_assert(
   12785             :             std::is_default_constructible<ValueType>::value,
   12786             :             "types must be DefaultConstructible when used with get()");
   12787             : 
   12788         242 :         ValueType ret;
   12789         242 :         JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
   12790         242 :         return ret;
   12791             :     }
   12792             : 
   12793             :     /*!
   12794             :     @brief get a value (explicit); special case
   12795             : 
   12796             :     Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
   12797             :     which is **not**
   12798             :     [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible)
   12799             :     and **not**
   12800             :     [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible).
   12801             :     The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
   12802             :     `from_json()` method.
   12803             : 
   12804             :     The function is equivalent to executing
   12805             :     @code {.cpp}
   12806             :     return JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(*this);
   12807             :     @endcode
   12808             : 
   12809             :     This overloads is chosen if:
   12810             :     - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json and
   12811             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
   12812             :       `ValueType from_json(const basic_json&)`
   12813             : 
   12814             :     @note If @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has both overloads of
   12815             :     `from_json()`, this one is chosen.
   12816             : 
   12817             :     @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
   12818             :     @tparam ValueType the returned value type
   12819             : 
   12820             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
   12821             : 
   12822             :     @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
   12823             : 
   12824             :     @since version 2.1.0
   12825             :     */
   12826             :     template <
   12827             :         typename ValueTypeCV,
   12828             :         typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
   12829             :         detail::enable_if_t<not std::is_same<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
   12830             :                                 detail::has_non_default_from_json<
   12831             :                                     basic_json_t, ValueType>::value,
   12832             :                             int> = 0>
   12833             :     ValueType get() const
   12834             :         noexcept(noexcept(JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(
   12835             :             std::declval<const basic_json_t&>())))
   12836             :     {
   12837             :         static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
   12838             :                       "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might "
   12839             :                       "want to use get_ref()");
   12840             :         return JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(*this);
   12841             :     }
   12842             : 
   12843             :     /*!
   12844             :     @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
   12845             : 
   12846             :     Explicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
   12847             :     made.
   12848             : 
   12849             :     @warning The pointer becomes invalid if the underlying JSON object
   12850             :     changes.
   12851             : 
   12852             :     @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
   12853             :     object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
   12854             :     @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t.
   12855             : 
   12856             :     @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
   12857             :     pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
   12858             : 
   12859             :     @complexity Constant.
   12860             : 
   12861             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
   12862             :     JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
   12863             :     `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
   12864             :     match.,get__PointerType}
   12865             : 
   12866             :     @sa @ref get_ptr() for explicit pointer-member access
   12867             : 
   12868             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12869             :     */
   12870             :     template <typename PointerType,
   12871             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value,
   12872             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   12873             :     PointerType get() noexcept
   12874             :     {
   12875             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr
   12876             :         return get_ptr<PointerType>();
   12877             :     }
   12878             : 
   12879             :     /*!
   12880             :     @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
   12881             :     @copydoc get()
   12882             :     */
   12883             :     template <typename PointerType,
   12884             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value,
   12885             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   12886             :     constexpr const PointerType get() const noexcept
   12887             :     {
   12888             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr
   12889             :         return get_ptr<PointerType>();
   12890             :     }
   12891             : 
   12892             :     /*!
   12893             :     @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
   12894             : 
   12895             :     Implicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
   12896             :     made.
   12897             : 
   12898             :     @warning Writing data to the pointee of the result yields an undefined
   12899             :     state.
   12900             : 
   12901             :     @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
   12902             :     object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
   12903             :     @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t. Enforced by a static
   12904             :     assertion.
   12905             : 
   12906             :     @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
   12907             :     pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
   12908             : 
   12909             :     @complexity Constant.
   12910             : 
   12911             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
   12912             :     JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
   12913             :     `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
   12914             :     match.,get_ptr}
   12915             : 
   12916             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12917             :     */
   12918             :     template <typename PointerType,
   12919             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value,
   12920             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   12921             :     PointerType get_ptr() noexcept
   12922             :     {
   12923             :         // get the type of the PointerType (remove pointer and const)
   12924             :         using pointee_t =
   12925             :             typename std::remove_const<typename std::remove_pointer<
   12926             :                 typename std::remove_const<PointerType>::type>::type>::type;
   12927             :         // make sure the type matches the allowed types
   12928             :         static_assert(std::is_same<object_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12929             :                           std::is_same<array_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12930             :                           std::is_same<string_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12931             :                           std::is_same<boolean_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12932             :                           std::is_same<number_integer_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12933             :                           std::is_same<number_unsigned_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12934             :                           std::is_same<number_float_t, pointee_t>::value,
   12935             :                       "incompatible pointer type");
   12936             : 
   12937             :         // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>()
   12938             :         return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<PointerType>(nullptr));
   12939             :     }
   12940             : 
   12941             :     /*!
   12942             :     @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
   12943             :     @copydoc get_ptr()
   12944             :     */
   12945             :     template <
   12946             :         typename PointerType,
   12947             :         typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value and
   12948             :                                     std::is_const<typename std::remove_pointer<
   12949             :                                         PointerType>::type>::value,
   12950             :                                 int>::type = 0>
   12951         242 :     constexpr const PointerType get_ptr() const noexcept
   12952             :     {
   12953             :         // get the type of the PointerType (remove pointer and const)
   12954             :         using pointee_t =
   12955             :             typename std::remove_const<typename std::remove_pointer<
   12956             :                 typename std::remove_const<PointerType>::type>::type>::type;
   12957             :         // make sure the type matches the allowed types
   12958             :         static_assert(std::is_same<object_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12959             :                           std::is_same<array_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12960             :                           std::is_same<string_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12961             :                           std::is_same<boolean_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12962             :                           std::is_same<number_integer_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12963             :                           std::is_same<number_unsigned_t, pointee_t>::value or
   12964             :                           std::is_same<number_float_t, pointee_t>::value,
   12965             :                       "incompatible pointer type");

   12967             :         // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>() const
   12968         242 :         return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<PointerType>(nullptr));
   12969             :     }
   12970             : 
   12971             :     /*!
   12972             :     @brief get a reference value (implicit)
   12973             : 
   12974             :     Implicit reference access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies
   12975             :     are made.
   12976             : 
   12977             :     @warning Writing data to the referee of the result yields an undefined
   12978             :     state.
   12979             : 
   12980             :     @tparam ReferenceType reference type; must be a reference to @ref array_t,
   12981             :     @ref object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t, or
   12982             :     @ref number_float_t. Enforced by static assertion.
   12983             : 
   12984             :     @return reference to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
   12985             :     reference type @a ReferenceType fits to the JSON value; throws
   12986             :     type_error.303 otherwise
   12987             : 
   12988             :     @throw type_error.303 in case passed type @a ReferenceType is incompatible
   12989             :     with the stored JSON value; see example below
   12990             : 
   12991             :     @complexity Constant.
   12992             : 
   12993             :     @liveexample{The example shows several calls to `get_ref()`.,get_ref}
   12994             : 
   12995             :     @since version 1.1.0
   12996             :     */
   12997             :     template <typename ReferenceType,
   12998             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_reference<ReferenceType>::value,
   12999             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   13000             :     ReferenceType get_ref()
   13001             :     {
   13002             :         // delegate call to get_ref_impl
   13003             :         return get_ref_impl<ReferenceType>(*this);
   13004             :     }
   13005             : 
   13006             :     /*!
   13007             :     @brief get a reference value (implicit)
   13008             :     @copydoc get_ref()
   13009             :     */
   13010             :     template <typename ReferenceType,
   13011             :               typename std::enable_if<
   13012             :                   std::is_reference<ReferenceType>::value and
   13013             :                       std::is_const<typename std::remove_reference<
   13014             :                           ReferenceType>::type>::value,
   13015             :                   int>::type = 0>
   13016             :     ReferenceType get_ref() const
   13017             :     {
   13018             :         // delegate call to get_ref_impl
   13019             :         return get_ref_impl<ReferenceType>(*this);
   13020             :     }
   13021             : 
   13022             :     /*!
   13023             :     @brief get a value (implicit)
   13024             : 
   13025             :     Implicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value.
   13026             :     The call is realized by calling @ref get() const.
   13027             : 
   13028             :     @tparam ValueType non-pointer type compatible to the JSON value, for
   13029             :     instance `int` for JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or
   13030             :     `std::vector` types for JSON arrays. The character type of @ref string_t
   13031             :     as well as an initializer list of this type is excluded to avoid
   13032             :     ambiguities as these types implicitly convert to `std::string`.
   13033             : 
   13034             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to type @a ValueType
   13035             : 
   13036             :     @throw type_error.302 in case passed type @a ValueType is incompatible
   13037             :     to the JSON value type (e.g., the JSON value is of type boolean, but a
   13038             :     string is requested); see example below
   13039             : 
   13040             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
   13041             : 
   13042             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
   13043             :     to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
   13044             :     be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
   13045             :     `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
   13046             :     associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
   13047             :     json>`.,operator__ValueType}
   13048             : 
   13049             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13050             :     */
   13051             :     template <
   13052             :         typename ValueType,
   13053             :         typename std::enable_if<
   13054             :             not std::is_pointer<ValueType>::value and
   13055             :                 not std::is_same<ValueType,
   13056             :                                  detail::json_ref<basic_json>>::value and
   13057             :                 not std::is_same<ValueType,
   13058             :                                  typename string_t::value_type>::value and
   13059             :                 not detail::is_basic_json<ValueType>::value
   13060             : #ifndef _MSC_VER // fix for issue #167 operator<< ambiguity under VS2015
   13061             :                 and
   13062             :                 not std::is_same<
   13063             :                     ValueType,
   13064             :                     std::initializer_list<typename string_t::value_type>>::value
   13065             : #endif
   13066             : #if defined(JSON_HAS_CPP_17)
   13067             :                 and
   13068             :                 not std::is_same<ValueType, typename std::string_view>::value
   13069             : #endif
   13070             :             ,
   13071             :             int>::type = 0>
   13072         121 :     operator ValueType() const
   13073             :     {
   13074             :         // delegate the call to get<>() const
   13075         121 :         return get<ValueType>();
   13076             :     }
   13077             : 
   13078             :     /// @}
   13079             : 
   13080             :     ////////////////////
   13081             :     // element access //
   13082             :     ////////////////////
   13083             : 
   13084             :     /// @name element access
   13085             :     /// Access to the JSON value.
   13086             :     /// @{
   13087             : 
   13088             :     /*!
   13089             :     @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
   13090             : 
   13091             :     Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx, with
   13092             :     bounds checking.
   13093             : 
   13094             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
   13095             : 
   13096             :     @return reference to the element at index @a idx
   13097             : 
   13098             :     @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an array; in this case,
   13099             :     calling `at` with an index makes no sense. See example below.
   13100             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
   13101             :     that is, `idx >= size()`. See example below.
   13102             : 
   13103             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   13104             :     changes in the JSON value.
   13105             : 
   13106             :     @complexity Constant.
   13107             : 
   13108             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13109             : 
   13110             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
   13111             :     written using `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that
   13112             :     can be thrown.,at__size_type}
   13113             :     */
   13114             :     reference at(size_type idx)
   13115             :     {
   13116             :         // at only works for arrays
   13117             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   13118             :         {
   13119             :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.array->at(idx); }
   13120             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
   13121             :             {
   13122             :                 // create better exception explanation
   13123             :                 JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " +
   13124             :                                                          std::to_string(idx) +
   13125             :                                                          " is out of range"));
   13126             :             }
   13127             :         }
   13128             :         else
   13129             :         {
   13130             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " +
   13131             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   13132             :         }
   13133             :     }
   13134             : 
   13135             :     /*!
   13136             :     @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
   13137             : 
   13138             :     Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx,
   13139             :     with bounds checking.
   13140             : 
   13141             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
   13142             : 
   13143             :     @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
   13144             : 
   13145             :     @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an array; in this case,
   13146             :     calling `at` with an index makes no sense. See example below.
   13147             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
   13148             :     that is, `idx >= size()`. See example below.
   13149             : 
   13150             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   13151             :     changes in the JSON value.
   13152             : 
   13153             :     @complexity Constant.
   13154             : 
   13155             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13156             : 
   13157             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
   13158             :     `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that can be thrown.,
   13159             :     at__size_type_const}
   13160             :     */
   13161             :     const_reference at(size_type idx) const
   13162             :     {
   13163             :         // at only works for arrays
   13164             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   13165             :         {
   13166             :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.array->at(idx); }
   13167             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
   13168             :             {
   13169             :                 // create better exception explanation
   13170             :                 JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " +
   13171             :                                                          std::to_string(idx) +
   13172             :                                                          " is out of range"));
   13173             :             }
   13174             :         }
   13175             :         else
   13176             :         {
   13177             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " +
   13178             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   13179             :         }
   13180             :     }
   13181             : 
   13182             :     /*!
   13183             :     @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
   13184             : 
   13185             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key, with
   13186             :     bounds checking.
   13187             : 
   13188             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13189             : 
   13190             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
   13191             : 
   13192             :     @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an object; in this case,
   13193             :     calling `at` with a key makes no sense. See example below.
   13194             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
   13195             :     that is, `find(key) == end()`. See example below.
   13196             : 
   13197             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   13198             :     changes in the JSON value.
   13199             : 
   13200             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13201             : 
   13202             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
   13203             :     access by reference
   13204             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
   13205             : 
   13206             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13207             : 
   13208             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
   13209             :     written using `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that
   13210             :     can be thrown.,at__object_t_key_type}
   13211             :     */
   13212             :     reference at(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
   13213             :     {
   13214             :         // at only works for objects
   13215             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   13216             :         {
   13217             :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.object->at(key); }
   13218             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
   13219             :             {
   13220             :                 // create better exception explanation
   13221             :                 JSON_THROW(
   13222             :                     out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + key + "' not found"));
   13223             :             }
   13224             :         }
   13225             :         else
   13226             :         {
   13227             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " +
   13228             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   13229             :         }
   13230             :     }
   13231             : 
   13232             :     /*!
   13233             :     @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
   13234             : 
   13235             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key,
   13236             :     with bounds checking.
   13237             : 
   13238             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13239             : 
   13240             :     @return const reference to the element at key @a key
   13241             : 
   13242             :     @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an object; in this case,
   13243             :     calling `at` with a key makes no sense. See example below.
   13244             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
   13245             :     that is, `find(key) == end()`. See example below.
   13246             : 
   13247             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   13248             :     changes in the JSON value.
   13249             : 
   13250             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13251             : 
   13252             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
   13253             :     access by reference
   13254             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
   13255             : 
   13256             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13257             : 
   13258             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
   13259             :     `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that can be thrown.,
   13260             :     at__object_t_key_type_const}
   13261             :     */
   13262          66 :     const_reference at(const typename object_t::key_type& key) const
   13263             :     {
   13264             :         // at only works for objects
   13265          66 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   13266             :         {
   13267         132 :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.object->at(key); }
   13268           0 :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
   13269             :             {
   13270             :                 // create better exception explanation
   13271           0 :                 JSON_THROW(
   13272             :                     out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + key + "' not found"));
   13273             :             }
   13274             :         }
   13275             :         else
   13276             :         {
   13277           0 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " +
   13278             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   13279             :         }
   13280             :     }
   13281             : 
   13282             :     /*!
   13283             :     @brief access specified array element
   13284             : 
   13285             :     Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
   13286             : 
   13287             :     @note If @a idx is beyond the range of the array (i.e., `idx >= size()`),
   13288             :     then the array is silently filled up with `null` values to make `idx` a
   13289             :     valid reference to the last stored element.
   13290             : 
   13291             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
   13292             : 
   13293             :     @return reference to the element at index @a idx
   13294             : 
   13295             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an array or null; in that
   13296             :     cases, using the [] operator with an index makes no sense.
   13297             : 
   13298             :     @complexity Constant if @a idx is in the range of the array. Otherwise
   13299             :     linear in `idx - size()`.
   13300             : 
   13301             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
   13302             :     written using `[]` operator. Note the addition of `null`
   13303             :     values.,operatorarray__size_type}
   13304             : 
   13305             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13306             :     */
   13307          66 :     reference operator[](size_type idx)
   13308             :     {
   13309             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty array
   13310          66 :         if (is_null())
   13311             :         {
   13312          22 :             m_type = value_t::array;
   13313          22 :             m_value.array = create<array_t>();
   13314          22 :             assert_invariant();
   13315             :         }
   13316             : 
   13317             :         // operator[] only works for arrays
   13318          66 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   13319             :         {
   13320             :             // fill up array with null values if given idx is outside range
   13321          66 :             if (idx >= m_value.array->size())
   13322             :             {
   13323          66 :                 m_value.array->insert(m_value.array->end(),
   13324          33 :                                       idx - m_value.array->size() + 1,
   13325             :                                       basic_json());
   13326             :             }
   13327             : 
   13328         132 :             return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
   13329             :         }
   13330             : 
   13331           0 :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with " +
   13332             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   13333             :     }
   13334             : 
   13335             :     /*!
   13336             :     @brief access specified array element
   13337             : 
   13338             :     Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
   13339             : 
   13340             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
   13341             : 
   13342             :     @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
   13343             : 
   13344             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an array; in that case,
   13345             :     using the [] operator with an index makes no sense.
   13346             : 
   13347             :     @complexity Constant.
   13348             : 
   13349             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
   13350             :     the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__size_type_const}
   13351             : 
   13352             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13353             :     */
   13354             :     const_reference operator[](size_type idx) const
   13355             :     {
   13356             :         // const operator[] only works for arrays
   13357             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   13358             :         {
   13359             :             return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
   13360             :         }
   13361             : 
   13362             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with " +
   13363             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   13364             :     }
   13365             : 
   13366             :     /*!
   13367             :     @brief access specified object element
   13368             : 
   13369             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
   13370             : 
   13371             :     @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
   13372             :     the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
   13373             :     In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
   13374             : 
   13375             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13376             : 
   13377             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
   13378             : 
   13379             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object or null; in that
   13380             :     cases, using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
   13381             : 
   13382             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13383             : 
   13384             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
   13385             :     written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
   13386             : 
   13387             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
   13388             :     with range checking
   13389             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
   13390             : 
   13391             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13392             :     */
   13393         418 :     reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key)
   13394             :     {
   13395             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
   13396         418 :         if (is_null())
   13397             :         {
   13398          77 :             m_type = value_t::object;
   13399          77 :             m_value.object = create<object_t>();
   13400          77 :             assert_invariant();
   13401             :         }
   13402             : 
   13403             :         // operator[] only works for objects
   13404         418 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   13405             :         {
   13406         836 :             return m_value.object->operator[](key);
   13407             :         }
   13408             : 
   13409           0 :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with " +
   13410             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   13411             :     }
   13412             : 
   13413             :     /*!
   13414             :     @brief read-only access specified object element
   13415             : 
   13416             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key. No
   13417             :     bounds checking is performed.
   13418             : 
   13419             :     @warning If the element with key @a key does not exist, the behavior is
   13420             :     undefined.
   13421             : 
   13422             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13423             : 
   13424             :     @return const reference to the element at key @a key
   13425             : 
   13426             :     @pre The element with key @a key must exist. **This precondition is
   13427             :          enforced with an assertion.**
   13428             : 
   13429             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
   13430             :     using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
   13431             : 
   13432             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13433             : 
   13434             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
   13435             :     the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type_const}

   13438             :     with range checking
   13439             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
   13440             : 
   13441             :     @since version 1.0.0

   13455             : 
   13456             :     /*!
   13457             :     @brief access specified object element
   13458             : 
   13459             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
   13460             : 
   13461             :     @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
   13462             :     the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
   13463             :     In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
   13464             : 
   13465             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13466             : 
   13467             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
   13468             : 
   13469             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object or null; in that
   13470             :     cases, using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
   13471             : 
   13472             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13473             : 
   13474             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
   13475             :     written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
   13476             :

   13478             :     with range checking
   13479             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
   13480             : 
   13481             :     @since version 1.1.0
   13482             :     */

   13484             :     reference operator[](T* key)

   13487             :         if (is_null())

   13491             :             assert_invariant();

   13496             :         {

   13509             :

   13511             :     undefined.

   13514             :

   13518             :          enforced with an assertion.**

   13521             :     using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.

   13547             : 
   13548             :     /*!
   13549             :     @brief access specified object element with default value
   13550             : 
   13551             :     Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
   13552             :     or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
   13553             : 
   13554             :     The function is basically equivalent to executing
   13555             :     @code {.cpp}
   13556             :     try {
   13557             :         return at(key);
   13558             :     } catch(out_of_range) {
   13559             :         return default_value;
   13560             :     }
   13561             :     @endcode
   13562             : 
   13563             :     @note Unlike @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&), this function
   13564             :     does not throw if the given key @a key was not found.
   13565             : 
   13566             :     @note Unlike @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key), this
   13567             :     function does not implicitly add an element to the position defined by @a
   13568             :     key. This function is furthermore also applicable to const objects.
   13569             : 
   13570             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13571             :     @param[in] default_value  the value to return if @a key is not found
   13572             : 
   13573             :     @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
   13574             :     JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
   13575             :     JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
   13576             :     value @a default_value must be compatible.
   13577             : 
   13578             :     @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
   13579             :     is not found
   13580             : 
   13581             :     @throw type_error.306 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
   13582             :     using `value()` with a key makes no sense.
   13583             : 
   13584             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13585             : 
   13586             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
   13587             :     with a default value.,basic_json__value}
   13588             : 
   13589             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
   13590             :     with range checking
   13591             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
   13592             :     access by reference
   13593             : 
   13594             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13595             :     */
   13596             :     template <
   13597             :         class ValueType,
   13598             :         typename std::enable_if<
   13599             :             std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>
   13600             :     ValueType value(const typename object_t::key_type& key,
   13601             :                     const ValueType& default_value) const
   13602             :     {
   13603             :         // at only works for objects
   13604             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   13605             :         {
   13606             :             // if key is found, return value and given default value otherwise
   13607             :             const auto it = find(key);
   13608             :             if (it != end())
   13609             :             {
   13610             :                 return *it;
   13611             :             }
   13612             : 
   13613             :             return default_value;
   13614             :         }
   13615             : 
   13616             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(306, "cannot use value() with " +
   13617             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   13618             :     }
   13619             : 
   13620             :     /*!
   13621             :     @brief overload for a default value of type const char*
   13622             :     @copydoc basic_json::value(const typename object_t::key_type&, ValueType)
   13623             :     const
   13624             :     */
   13625             :     string_t value(const typename object_t::key_type& key,
   13626             :                    const char* default_value) const
   13627             :     {
   13628             :         return value(key, string_t(default_value));
   13629             :     }
   13630             : 
   13631             :     /*!
   13632             :     @brief access specified object element via JSON Pointer with default value
   13633             : 
   13634             :     Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
   13635             :     or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
   13636             : 
   13637             :     The function is basically equivalent to executing
   13638             :     @code {.cpp}
   13639             :     try {
   13640             :         return at(ptr);
   13641             :     } catch(out_of_range) {
   13642             :         return default_value;
   13643             :     }
   13644             :     @endcode
   13645             : 
   13646             :     @note Unlike @ref at(const json_pointer&), this function does not throw
   13647             :     if the given key @a key was not found.
   13648             : 
   13649             :     @param[in] ptr  a JSON pointer to the element to access
   13650             :     @param[in] default_value  the value to return if @a ptr found no value
   13651             : 
   13652             :     @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
   13653             :     JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
   13654             :     JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
   13655             :     value @a default_value must be compatible.
   13656             : 
   13657             :     @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
   13658             :     is not found
   13659             : 
   13660             :     @throw type_error.306 if the JSON value is not an objec; in that case,
   13661             :     using `value()` with a key makes no sense.
   13662             : 
   13663             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13664             : 
   13665             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
   13666             :     with a default value.,basic_json__value_ptr}
   13667             : 
   13668             :     @sa @ref operator[](const json_pointer&) for unchecked access by reference
   13669             : 
   13670             :     @since version 2.0.2
   13671             :     */
   13672             :     template <
   13673             :         class ValueType,
   13674             :         typename std::enable_if<
   13675             :             std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>
   13676             :     ValueType value(const json_pointer& ptr,
   13677             :                     const ValueType& default_value) const
   13678             :     {
   13679             :         // at only works for objects
   13680             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   13681             :         {
   13682             :             // if pointer resolves a value, return it or use default value
   13683             :             JSON_TRY { return ptr.get_checked(this); }
   13684             :             JSON_CATCH(out_of_range&) { return default_value; }
   13685             :         }
   13686             : 
   13687             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(306, "cannot use value() with " +
   13688             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   13689             :     }
   13690             : 
   13691             :     /*!
   13692             :     @brief overload for a default value of type const char*
   13693             :     @copydoc basic_json::value(const json_pointer&, ValueType) const
   13694             :     */
   13695             :     string_t value(const json_pointer& ptr, const char* default_value) const
   13696             :     {
   13697             :         return value(ptr, string_t(default_value));
   13698             :     }
   13699             : 
   13700             :     /*!
   13701             :     @brief access the first element
   13702             : 
   13703             :     Returns a reference to the first element in the container. For a JSON
   13704             :     container `c`, the expression `c.front()` is equivalent to `*c.begin()`.
   13705             : 
   13706             :     @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
   13707             :     first element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
   13708             :     reference to the value is returned.
   13709             : 
   13710             :     @complexity Constant.
   13711             : 
   13712             :     @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
   13713             :     or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
   13714             :     assertions**).
   13715             :     @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
   13716             : 
   13717             :     @throw invalid_iterator.214 when called on `null` value
   13718             : 
   13719             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `front()`.,front}
   13720             : 
   13721             :     @sa @ref back() -- access the last element
   13722             : 
   13723             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13724             :     */
   13725             :     reference front() { return *begin(); }
   13726             :     /*!
   13727             :     @copydoc basic_json::front()
   13728             :     */
   13729             :     const_reference front() const { return *cbegin(); }
   13730             :     /*!
   13731             :     @brief access the last element
   13732             : 
   13733             :     Returns a reference to the last element in the container. For a JSON
   13734             :     container `c`, the expression `c.back()` is equivalent to
   13735             :     @code {.cpp}
   13736             :     auto tmp = c.end();
   13737             :     --tmp;
   13738             :     return *tmp;
   13739             :     @endcode
   13740             : 
   13741             :     @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
   13742             :     last element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
   13743             :     reference to the value is returned.
   13744             : 
   13745             :     @complexity Constant.
   13746             : 
   13747             :     @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
   13748             :     or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
   13749             :     assertions**).
   13750             :     @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
   13751             : 
   13752             :     @throw invalid_iterator.214 when called on a `null` value. See example
   13753             :     below.
   13754             : 
   13755             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `back()`.,back}
   13756             : 
   13757             :     @sa @ref front() -- access the first element
   13758             : 
   13759             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13760             :     */
   13761             :     reference back()
   13762             :     {
   13763             :         auto tmp = end();
   13764             :         --tmp;
   13765             :         return *tmp;
   13766             :     }
   13767             : 
   13768             :     /*!
   13769             :     @copydoc basic_json::back()
   13770             :     */
   13771             :     const_reference back() const
   13772             :     {
   13773             :         auto tmp = cend();
   13774             :         --tmp;
   13775             :         return *tmp;
   13776             :     }
   13777             : 
   13778             :     /*!
   13779             :     @brief remove element given an iterator
   13780             : 
   13781             :     Removes the element specified by iterator @a pos. The iterator @a pos must
   13782             :     be valid and dereferenceable. Thus the `end()` iterator (which is valid,
   13783             :     but is not dereferenceable) cannot be used as a value for @a pos.
   13784             : 
   13785             :     If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
   13786             :     will be `null`.
   13787             : 
   13788             :     @param[in] pos iterator to the element to remove
   13789             :     @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
   13790             :     pos refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
   13791             : 
   13792             :     @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
   13793             : 
   13794             :     @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
   13795             :     erase, including the `end()` iterator.
   13796             : 
   13797             :     @throw type_error.307 if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot use
   13798             :     erase() with null"`
   13799             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if called on an iterator which does not belong
   13800             :     to the current JSON value; example: `"iterator does not fit current
   13801             :     value"`
   13802             :     @throw invalid_iterator.205 if called on a primitive type with invalid
   13803             :     iterator (i.e., any iterator which is not `begin()`); example: `"iterator
   13804             :     out of range"`
   13805             : 
   13806             :     @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
   13807             :     - objects: amortized constant
   13808             :     - arrays: linear in distance between @a pos and the end of the container
   13809             :     - strings: linear in the length of the string
   13810             :     - other types: constant
   13811             : 
   13812             :     @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
   13813             :     types.,erase__IteratorType}
   13814             : 
   13815             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
   13816             :     the given range
   13817             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
   13818             :     from an object at the given key
   13819             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
   13820             :     the given index
   13821             : 
   13822             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13823             :     */
   13824             :     template <
   13825             :         class IteratorType,
   13826             :         typename std::enable_if<
   13827             :             std::is_same<IteratorType,
   13828             :                          typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
   13829             :                 std::is_same<IteratorType,
   13830             :                              typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value,
   13831             :             int>::type = 0>
   13832             :     IteratorType erase(IteratorType pos)
   13833             :     {
   13834             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
   13835             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(this != pos.m_object))
   13836             :         {
   13837             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   13838             :                 202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
   13839             :         }
   13840             : 
   13841             :         IteratorType result = end();
   13842             : 
   13843             :         switch (m_type)
   13844             :         {
   13845             :         case value_t::boolean:
   13846             :         case value_t::number_float:
   13847             :         case value_t::number_integer:
   13848             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
   13849             :         case value_t::string:
   13850             :         {
   13851             :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not pos.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin()))
   13852             :             {
   13853             :                 JSON_THROW(
   13854             :                     invalid_iterator::create(205, "iterator out of range"));
   13855             :             }
   13856             : 
   13857             :             if (is_string())
   13858             :             {
   13859             :                 AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
   13860             :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc,
   13861             :                                                                 m_value.string);
   13862             :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(
   13863             :                     alloc, m_value.string, 1);
   13864             :                 m_value.string = nullptr;
   13865             :             }
   13866             : 
   13867             :             m_type = value_t::null;
   13868             :             assert_invariant();
   13869             :             break;
   13870             :         }
   13871             : 
   13872             :         case value_t::object:
   13873             :         {
   13874             :             result.m_it.object_iterator =
   13875             :                 m_value.object->erase(pos.m_it.object_iterator);
   13876             :             break;
   13877             :         }
   13878             : 
   13879             :         case value_t::array:
   13880             :         {
   13881             :             result.m_it.array_iterator =
   13882             :                 m_value.array->erase(pos.m_it.array_iterator);
   13883             :             break;
   13884             :         }
   13885             : 
   13886             :         default:
   13887             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " +
   13888             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   13889             :         }
   13890             : 
   13891             :         return result;
   13892             :     }
   13893             : 
   13894             :     /*!
   13895             :     @brief remove elements given an iterator range
   13896             : 
   13897             :     Removes the element specified by the range `[first; last)`. The iterator
   13898             :     @a first does not need to be dereferenceable if `first == last`: erasing
   13899             :     an empty range is a no-op.
   13900             : 
   13901             :     If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
   13902             :     will be `null`.
   13903             : 
   13904             :     @param[in] first iterator to the beginning of the range to remove
   13905             :     @param[in] last iterator past the end of the range to remove
   13906             :     @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
   13907             :     second refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
   13908             : 
   13909             :     @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
   13910             : 
   13911             :     @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
   13912             :     erase, including the `end()` iterator.
   13913             : 
   13914             :     @throw type_error.307 if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot use
   13915             :     erase() with null"`
   13916             :     @throw invalid_iterator.203 if called on iterators which does not belong
   13917             :     to the current JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit current value"`
   13918             :     @throw invalid_iterator.204 if called on a primitive type with invalid
   13919             :     iterators (i.e., if `first != begin()` and `last != end()`); example:
   13920             :     `"iterators out of range"`
   13921             : 
   13922             :     @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
   13923             :     - objects: `log(size()) + std::distance(first, last)`
   13924             :     - arrays: linear in the distance between @a first and @a last, plus linear
   13925             :       in the distance between @a last and end of the container
   13926             :     - strings: linear in the length of the string
   13927             :     - other types: constant
   13928             : 
   13929             :     @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
   13930             :     types.,erase__IteratorType_IteratorType}
   13931             : 
   13932             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
   13933             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
   13934             :     from an object at the given key
   13935             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
   13936             :     the given index
   13937             :
