   13938             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13939             :     */
   13940             :     template <
   13941             :         class IteratorType,
   13942             :         typename std::enable_if<
   13943             :             std::is_same<IteratorType,
   13944             :                          typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
   13945             :                 std::is_same<IteratorType,
   13946             :                              typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value,
   13947             :             int>::type = 0>
   13948             :     IteratorType erase(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
   13949             :     {
   13950             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
   13951             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(this != first.m_object or this != last.m_object))
   13952             :         {
   13953             :             JSON_THROW(
   13954             :                 invalid_iterator::create(203,
   13955             :                                          "iterators do not fit current value"));
   13956             :         }
   13957             : 
   13958             :         IteratorType result = end();
   13959             : 
   13960             :         switch (m_type)
   13961             :         {
   13962             :         case value_t::boolean:
   13963             :         case value_t::number_float:
   13964             :         case value_t::number_integer:
   13965             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
   13966             :         case value_t::string:
   13967             :         {
   13968             :             if (JSON_LIKELY(not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin() or
   13969             :                             not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end()))
   13970             :             {
   13971             :                 JSON_THROW(
   13972             :                     invalid_iterator::create(204, "iterators out of range"));
   13973             :             }
   13974             : 
   13975             :             if (is_string())
   13976             :             {
   13977             :                 AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
   13978             :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc,
   13979             :                                                                 m_value.string);
   13980             :                 std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(
   13981             :                     alloc, m_value.string, 1);
   13982             :                 m_value.string = nullptr;
   13983             :             }
   13984             : 
   13985             :             m_type = value_t::null;
   13986             :             assert_invariant();
   13987             :             break;
   13988             :         }
   13989             : 
   13990             :         case value_t::object:
   13991             :         {
   13992             :             result.m_it.object_iterator =
   13993             :                 m_value.object->erase(first.m_it.object_iterator,
   13994             :                                       last.m_it.object_iterator);
   13995             :             break;
   13996             :         }
   13997             : 
   13998             :         case value_t::array:
   13999             :         {
   14000             :             result.m_it.array_iterator =
   14001             :                 m_value.array->erase(first.m_it.array_iterator,
   14002             :                                      last.m_it.array_iterator);
   14003             :             break;
   14004             :         }
   14005             : 
   14006             :         default:
   14007             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " +
   14008             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   14009             :         }
   14010             : 
   14011             :         return result;
   14012             :     }
   14013             : 
   14014             :     /*!
   14015             :     @brief remove element from a JSON object given a key
   14016             : 
   14017             :     Removes elements from a JSON object with the key value @a key.
   14018             : 
   14019             :     @param[in] key value of the elements to remove
   14020             : 
   14021             :     @return Number of elements removed. If @a ObjectType is the default
   14022             :     `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was not
   14023             :     found) or `1` (@a key was found).
   14024             : 
   14025             :     @post References and iterators to the erased elements are invalidated.
   14026             :     Other references and iterators are not affected.
   14027             : 
   14028             :     @throw type_error.307 when called on a type other than JSON object;
   14029             :     example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
   14030             : 
   14031             :     @complexity `log(size()) + count(key)`
   14032             : 
   14033             :     @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__key_type}
   14034             : 
   14035             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
   14036             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
   14037             :     the given range
   14038             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
   14039             :     the given index
   14040             : 
   14041             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14042             :     */
   14043             :     size_type erase(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
   14044             :     {
   14045             :         // this erase only works for objects
   14046             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   14047             :         {
   14048             :             return m_value.object->erase(key);
   14049             :         }
   14050             : 
   14051             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " +
   14052             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   14053             :     }
   14054             : 
   14055             :     /*!
   14056             :     @brief remove element from a JSON array given an index
   14057             : 
   14058             :     Removes element from a JSON array at the index @a idx.
   14059             : 
   14060             :     @param[in] idx index of the element to remove
   14061             : 
   14062             :     @throw type_error.307 when called on a type other than JSON object;
   14063             :     example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
   14064             :     @throw out_of_range.401 when `idx >= size()`; example: `"array index 17
   14065             :     is out of range"`
   14066             : 
   14067             :     @complexity Linear in distance between @a idx and the end of the container.
   14068             : 
   14069             :     @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__size_type}
   14070             : 
   14071             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
   14072             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
   14073             :     the given range
   14074             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
   14075             :     from an object at the given key
   14076             : 
   14077             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14078             :     */
   14079             :     void erase(const size_type idx)
   14080             :     {
   14081             :         // this erase only works for arrays
   14082             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   14083             :         {
   14084             :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(idx >= size()))
   14085             :             {
   14086             :                 JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " +
   14087             :                                                          std::to_string(idx) +
   14088             :                                                          " is out of range"));
   14089             :             }
   14090             : 
   14091             :             m_value.array->erase(m_value.array->begin() +
   14092             :                                  static_cast<difference_type>(idx));
   14093             :         }
   14094             :         else
   14095             :         {
   14096             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " +
   14097             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   14098             :         }
   14099             :     }
   14100             : 
   14101             :     /// @}
   14102             : 
   14103             :     ////////////
   14104             :     // lookup //
   14105             :     ////////////
   14106             : 
   14107             :     /// @name lookup
   14108             :     /// @{
   14109             : 
   14110             :     /*!
   14111             :     @brief find an element in a JSON object
   14112             : 
   14113             :     Finds an element in a JSON object with key equivalent to @a key. If the
   14114             :     element is not found or the JSON value is not an object, end() is
   14115             :     returned.
   14116             : 
   14117             :     @note This method always returns @ref end() when executed on a JSON type
   14118             :           that is not an object.
   14119             : 
   14120             :     @param[in] key key value of the element to search for.
   14121             : 
   14122             :     @return Iterator to an element with key equivalent to @a key. If no such
   14123             :     element is found or the JSON value is not an object, past-the-end (see
   14124             :     @ref end()) iterator is returned.
   14125             : 
   14126             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
   14127             : 
   14128             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `find()` is used.,find__key_type}
   14129             : 
   14130             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14131             :     */
   14132             :     template <typename KeyT>
   14133             :     iterator find(KeyT&& key)
   14134             :     {
   14135             :         auto result = end();
   14136             : 
   14137             :         if (is_object())
   14138             :         {
   14139             :             result.m_it.object_iterator =
   14140             :                 m_value.object->find(std::forward<KeyT>(key));
   14141             :         }
   14142             : 
   14143             :         return result;
   14144             :     }
   14145             : 
   14146             :     /*!
   14147             :     @brief find an element in a JSON object
   14148             :     @copydoc find(KeyT&&)
   14149             :     */
   14150             :     template <typename KeyT>
   14151             :     const_iterator find(KeyT&& key) const
   14152             :     {
   14153             :         auto result = cend();
   14154             : 
   14155             :         if (is_object())
   14156             :         {
   14157             :             result.m_it.object_iterator =
   14158             :                 m_value.object->find(std::forward<KeyT>(key));
   14159             :         }
   14160             : 
   14161             :         return result;
   14162             :     }
   14163             : 
   14164             :     /*!
   14165             :     @brief returns the number of occurrences of a key in a JSON object
   14166             : 
   14167             :     Returns the number of elements with key @a key. If ObjectType is the
   14168             :     default `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was
   14169             :     not found) or `1` (@a key was found).
   14170             : 
   14171             :     @note This method always returns `0` when executed on a JSON type that is
   14172             :           not an object.
   14173             : 
   14174             :     @param[in] key key value of the element to count
   14175             : 
   14176             :     @return Number of elements with key @a key. If the JSON value is not an
   14177             :     object, the return value will be `0`.
   14178             : 
   14179             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
   14180             : 
   14181             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `count()` is used.,count}
   14182             : 
   14183             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14184             :     */
   14185             :     template <typename KeyT>
   14186             :     size_type count(KeyT&& key) const
   14187             :     {
   14188             :         // return 0 for all nonobject types
   14189             :         return is_object() ? m_value.object->count(std::forward<KeyT>(key)) : 0;
   14190             :     }
   14191             : 
   14192             :     /// @}
   14193             : 
   14194             :     ///////////////
   14195             :     // iterators //
   14196             :     ///////////////
   14197             : 
   14198             :     /// @name iterators
   14199             :     /// @{
   14200             : 
   14201             :     /*!
   14202             :     @brief returns an iterator to the first element
   14203             : 
   14204             :     Returns an iterator to the first element.
   14205             : 
   14206             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14207             : 
   14208             :     @return iterator to the first element
   14209             : 
   14210             :     @complexity Constant.
   14211             : 
   14212             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14213             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14214             :     requirements:
   14215             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14216             : 
   14217             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `begin()`.,begin}
   14218             : 
   14219             :     @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
   14220             :     @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
   14221             :     @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
   14222             : 
   14223             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14224             :     */
   14225          22 :     iterator begin() noexcept
   14226             :     {
   14227          22 :         iterator result(this);
   14228          22 :         result.set_begin();
   14229          22 :         return result;
   14230             :     }
   14231             : 
   14232             :     /*!
   14233             :     @copydoc basic_json::cbegin()
   14234             :     */
   14235          33 :     const_iterator begin() const noexcept { return cbegin(); }
   14236             :     /*!
   14237             :     @brief returns a const iterator to the first element
   14238             : 
   14239             :     Returns a const iterator to the first element.
   14240             : 
   14241             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14242             : 
   14243             :     @return const iterator to the first element
   14244             : 
   14245             :     @complexity Constant.
   14246             : 
   14247             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14248             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14249             :     requirements:
   14250             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14251             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).begin()`.
   14252             : 
   14253             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `cbegin()`.,cbegin}
   14254             : 
   14255             :     @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
   14256             :     @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
   14257             :     @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
   14258             : 
   14259             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14260             :     */
   14261          33 :     const_iterator cbegin() const noexcept
   14262             :     {
   14263          33 :         const_iterator result(this);
   14264          33 :         result.set_begin();
   14265          33 :         return result;
   14266             :     }
   14267             : 
   14268             :     /*!
   14269             :     @brief returns an iterator to one past the last element
   14270             : 
   14271             :     Returns an iterator to one past the last element.
   14272             : 
   14273             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14274             : 
   14275             :     @return iterator one past the last element
   14276             : 
   14277             :     @complexity Constant.
   14278             : 
   14279             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14280             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14281             :     requirements:
   14282             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14283             : 
   14284             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `end()`.,end}
   14285             : 
   14286             :     @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
   14287             :     @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
   14288             :     @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
   14289             : 
   14290             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14291             :     */
   14292         176 :     iterator end() noexcept
   14293             :     {
   14294         176 :         iterator result(this);
   14295         176 :         result.set_end();
   14296         176 :         return result;
   14297             :     }
   14298             : 
   14299             :     /*!
   14300             :     @copydoc basic_json::cend()
   14301             :     */
   14302          44 :     const_iterator end() const noexcept { return cend(); }
   14303             :     /*!
   14304             :     @brief returns a const iterator to one past the last element
   14305             : 
   14306             :     Returns a const iterator to one past the last element.
   14307             : 
   14308             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14309             : 
   14310             :     @return const iterator one past the last element
   14311             : 
   14312             :     @complexity Constant.
   14313             : 
   14314             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14315             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14316             :     requirements:
   14317             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14318             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).end()`.
   14319             : 
   14320             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `cend()`.,cend}
   14321             : 
   14322             :     @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
   14323             :     @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
   14324             :     @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
   14325             : 
   14326             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14327             :     */
   14328          44 :     const_iterator cend() const noexcept
   14329             :     {
   14330          44 :         const_iterator result(this);
   14331          44 :         result.set_end();
   14332          44 :         return result;
   14333             :     }
   14334             : 
   14335             :     /*!
   14336             :     @brief returns an iterator to the reverse-beginning
   14337             : 
   14338             :     Returns an iterator to the reverse-beginning; that is, the last element.
   14339             : 
   14340             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14341             : 
   14342             :     @complexity Constant.
   14343             : 
   14344             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14345             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
   14346             :     requirements:
   14347             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14348             :     - Has the semantics of `reverse_iterator(end())`.
   14349             : 
   14350             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `rbegin()`.,rbegin}
   14351             : 
   14352             :     @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
   14353             :     @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
   14354             :     @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
   14355             : 
   14356             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14357             :     */
   14358             :     reverse_iterator rbegin() noexcept { return reverse_iterator(end()); }
   14359             :     /*!
   14360             :     @copydoc basic_json::crbegin()
   14361             :     */
   14362             :     const_reverse_iterator rbegin() const noexcept { return crbegin(); }
   14363             :     /*!
   14364             :     @brief returns an iterator to the reverse-end
   14365             : 
   14366             :     Returns an iterator to the reverse-end; that is, one before the first
   14367             :     element.
   14368             : 
   14369             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14370             : 
   14371             :     @complexity Constant.
   14372             : 
   14373             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14374             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
   14375             :     requirements:
   14376             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14377             :     - Has the semantics of `reverse_iterator(begin())`.
   14378             : 
   14379             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `rend()`.,rend}
   14380             : 
   14381             :     @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
   14382             :     @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
   14383             :     @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
   14384             : 
   14385             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14386             :     */
   14387             :     reverse_iterator rend() noexcept { return reverse_iterator(begin()); }
   14388             :     /*!
   14389             :     @copydoc basic_json::crend()
   14390             :     */
   14391             :     const_reverse_iterator rend() const noexcept { return crend(); }
   14392             :     /*!
   14393             :     @brief returns a const reverse iterator to the last element
   14394             : 
   14395             :     Returns a const iterator to the reverse-beginning; that is, the last
   14396             :     element.
   14397             : 
   14398             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14399             : 
   14400             :     @complexity Constant.
   14401             : 
   14402             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14403             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
   14404             :     requirements:
   14405             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14406             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).rbegin()`.
   14407             : 
   14408             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `crbegin()`.,crbegin}
   14409             : 
   14410             :     @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
   14411             :     @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
   14412             :     @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
   14413             : 
   14414             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14415             :     */
   14416             :     const_reverse_iterator crbegin() const noexcept
   14417             :     {
   14418             :         return const_reverse_iterator(cend());
   14419             :     }
   14420             : 
   14421             :     /*!
   14422             :     @brief returns a const reverse iterator to one before the first
   14423             : 
   14424             :     Returns a const reverse iterator to the reverse-end; that is, one before
   14425             :     the first element.
   14426             : 
   14427             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14428             : 
   14429             :     @complexity Constant.
   14430             : 
   14431             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14432             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
   14433             :     requirements:
   14434             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14435             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).rend()`.
   14436             : 
   14437             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `crend()`.,crend}
   14438             : 
   14439             :     @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
   14440             :     @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
   14441             :     @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
   14442             : 
   14443             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14444             :     */
   14445             :     const_reverse_iterator crend() const noexcept
   14446             :     {
   14447             :         return const_reverse_iterator(cbegin());
   14448             :     }
   14449             : 
   14450             : public:
   14451             :     /*!
   14452             :     @brief wrapper to access iterator member functions in range-based for
   14453             : 
   14454             :     This function allows to access @ref iterator::key() and @ref
   14455             :     iterator::value() during range-based for loops. In these loops, a
   14456             :     reference to the JSON values is returned, so there is no access to the
   14457             :     underlying iterator.
   14458             : 
   14459             :     For loop without iterator_wrapper:
   14460             : 
   14461             :     @code{cpp}
   14462             :     for (auto it = j_object.begin(); it != j_object.end(); ++it)
   14463             :     {
   14464             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   14465             :     }
   14466             :     @endcode
   14467             : 
   14468             :     Range-based for loop without iterator proxy:
   14469             : 
   14470             :     @code{cpp}
   14471             :     for (auto it : j_object)
   14472             :     {
   14473             :         // "it" is of type json::reference and has no key() member
   14474             :         std::cout << "value: " << it << '\n';
   14475             :     }
   14476             :     @endcode
   14477             : 
   14478             :     Range-based for loop with iterator proxy:
   14479             : 
   14480             :     @code{cpp}
   14481             :     for (auto it : json::iterator_wrapper(j_object))
   14482             :     {
   14483             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   14484             :     }
   14485             :     @endcode
   14486             : 
   14487             :     @note When iterating over an array, `key()` will return the index of the
   14488             :           element as string (see example).
   14489             : 
   14490             :     @param[in] ref  reference to a JSON value
   14491             :     @return iteration proxy object wrapping @a ref with an interface to use in
   14492             :             range-based for loops
   14493             : 
   14494             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how the wrapper is
   14495             :     used,iterator_wrapper}
   14496             : 
   14497             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   14498             :     changes in the JSON value.
   14499             : 
   14500             :     @complexity Constant.
   14501             : 
   14502             :     @note The name of this function is not yet final and may change in the
   14503             :     future.
   14504             : 
   14505             :     @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
   14506             :                 future 4.0.0 of the library. Please use @ref items() instead;
   14507             :                 that is, replace `json::iterator_wrapper(j)` with `j.items()`.
   14508             :     */
   14509             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
   14510             :     static iteration_proxy<iterator> iterator_wrapper(reference ref) noexcept
   14511             :     {
   14512             :         return ref.items();
   14513             :     }
   14514             : 
   14515             :     /*!
   14516             :     @copydoc iterator_wrapper(reference)
   14517             :     */
   14518             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
   14519             :     static iteration_proxy<const_iterator> iterator_wrapper(
   14520             :         const_reference ref) noexcept
   14521             :     {
   14522             :         return ref.items();
   14523             :     }
   14524             : 
   14525             :     /*!
   14526             :     @brief helper to access iterator member functions in range-based for
   14527             : 
   14528             :     This function allows to access @ref iterator::key() and @ref
   14529             :     iterator::value() during range-based for loops. In these loops, a
   14530             :     reference to the JSON values is returned, so there is no access to the
   14531             :     underlying iterator.
   14532             : 
   14533             :     For loop without `items()` function:
   14534             : 
   14535             :     @code{cpp}
   14536             :     for (auto it = j_object.begin(); it != j_object.end(); ++it)
   14537             :     {
   14538             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   14539             :     }
   14540             :     @endcode
   14541             : 
   14542             :     Range-based for loop without `items()` function:
   14543             : 
   14544             :     @code{cpp}
   14545             :     for (auto it : j_object)
   14546             :     {
   14547             :         // "it" is of type json::reference and has no key() member
   14548             :         std::cout << "value: " << it << '\n';
   14549             :     }
   14550             :     @endcode
   14551             : 
   14552             :     Range-based for loop with `items()` function:
   14553             : 
   14554             :     @code{cpp}
   14555             :     for (auto it : j_object.items())
   14556             :     {
   14557             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   14558             :     }
   14559             :     @endcode
   14560             : 
   14561             :     @note When iterating over an array, `key()` will return the index of the
   14562             :           element as string (see example). For primitive types (e.g., numbers),
   14563             :           `key()` returns an empty string.
   14564             : 
   14565             :     @return iteration proxy object wrapping @a ref with an interface to use in
   14566             :             range-based for loops
   14567             : 
   14568             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how the function is used.,items}
   14569             : 
   14570             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   14571             :     changes in the JSON value.
   14572             : 
   14573             :     @complexity Constant.
   14574             : 
   14575             :     @since version 3.x.x.
   14576             :     */
   14577             :     iteration_proxy<iterator> items() noexcept
   14578             :     {
   14579             :         return iteration_proxy<iterator>(*this);
   14580             :     }
   14581             : 
   14582             :     /*!
   14583             :     @copydoc items()
   14584             :     */
   14585             :     iteration_proxy<const_iterator> items() const noexcept
   14586             :     {
   14587             :         return iteration_proxy<const_iterator>(*this);
   14588             :     }
   14589             : 
   14590             :     /// @}
   14591             : 
   14592             :     //////////////
   14593             :     // capacity //
   14594             :     //////////////
   14595             : 
   14596             :     /// @name capacity
   14597             :     /// @{
   14598             : 
   14599             :     /*!
   14600             :     @brief checks whether the container is empty.
   14601             : 
   14602             :     Checks if a JSON value has no elements (i.e. whether its @ref size is `0`).
   14603             : 
   14604             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
   14605             :             defined as follows:
   14606             :             Value type  | return value
   14607             :             ----------- | -------------
   14608             :             null        | `true`
   14609             :             boolean     | `false`
   14610             :             string      | `false`
   14611             :             number      | `false`
   14612             :             object      | result of function `object_t::empty()`
   14613             :             array       | result of function `array_t::empty()`
   14614             : 
   14615             :     @liveexample{The following code uses `empty()` to check if a JSON
   14616             :     object contains any elements.,empty}
   14617             : 
   14618             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
   14619             :     the Container concept; that is, their `empty()` functions have constant
   14620             :     complexity.
   14621             : 
   14622             :     @iterators No changes.
   14623             : 
   14624             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   14625             : 
   14626             :     @note This function does not return whether a string stored as JSON value
   14627             :     is empty - it returns whether the JSON container itself is empty which is
   14628             :     false in the case of a string.
   14629             : 
   14630             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14631             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14632             :     requirements:
   14633             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14634             :     - Has the semantics of `begin() == end()`.
   14635             : 
   14636             :     @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
   14637             : 
   14638             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14639             :     */
   14640             :     bool empty() const noexcept
   14641             :     {
   14642             :         switch (m_type)
   14643             :         {
   14644             :         case value_t::null:
   14645             :         {
   14646             :             // null values are empty
   14647             :             return true;
   14648             :         }
   14649             : 
   14650             :         case value_t::array:
   14651             :         {
   14652             :             // delegate call to array_t::empty()
   14653             :             return m_value.array->empty();
   14654             :         }
   14655             : 
   14656             :         case value_t::object:
   14657             :         {
   14658             :             // delegate call to object_t::empty()
   14659             :             return m_value.object->empty();
   14660             :         }
   14661             : 
   14662             :         default:
   14663             :         {
   14664             :             // all other types are nonempty
   14665             :             return false;
   14666             :         }
   14667             :         }
   14668             :     }
   14669             : 
   14670             :     /*!
   14671             :     @brief returns the number of elements
   14672             : 
   14673             :     Returns the number of elements in a JSON value.
   14674             : 
   14675             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
   14676             :             defined as follows:
   14677             :             Value type  | return value
   14678             :             ----------- | -------------
   14679             :             null        | `0`
   14680             :             boolean     | `1`
   14681             :             string      | `1`
   14682             :             number      | `1`
   14683             :             object      | result of function object_t::size()
   14684             :             array       | result of function array_t::size()
   14685             : 
   14686             :     @liveexample{The following code calls `size()` on the different value
   14687             :     types.,size}
   14688             : 
   14689             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
   14690             :     the Container concept; that is, their size() functions have constant
   14691             :     complexity.
   14692             : 
   14693             :     @iterators No changes.
   14694             : 
   14695             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   14696             : 
   14697             :     @note This function does not return the length of a string stored as JSON
   14698             :     value - it returns the number of elements in the JSON value which is 1 in
   14699             :     the case of a string.
   14700             : 
   14701             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14702             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14703             :     requirements:
   14704             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14705             :     - Has the semantics of `std::distance(begin(), end())`.
   14706             : 
   14707             :     @sa @ref empty() -- checks whether the container is empty
   14708             :     @sa @ref max_size() -- returns the maximal number of elements
   14709             : 
   14710             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14711             :     */
   14712             :     size_type size() const noexcept
   14713             :     {
   14714             :         switch (m_type)
   14715             :         {
   14716             :         case value_t::null:
   14717             :         {
   14718             :             // null values are empty
   14719             :             return 0;
   14720             :         }
   14721             : 
   14722             :         case value_t::array:
   14723             :         {
   14724             :             // delegate call to array_t::size()
   14725             :             return m_value.array->size();
   14726             :         }
   14727             : 
   14728             :         case value_t::object:
   14729             :         {
   14730             :             // delegate call to object_t::size()
   14731             :             return m_value.object->size();
   14732             :         }
   14733             : 
   14734             :         default:
   14735             :         {
   14736             :             // all other types have size 1
   14737             :             return 1;
   14738             :         }
   14739             :         }
   14740             :     }
   14741             : 
   14742             :     /*!
   14743             :     @brief returns the maximum possible number of elements
   14744             : 
   14745             :     Returns the maximum number of elements a JSON value is able to hold due to
   14746             :     system or library implementation limitations, i.e. `std::distance(begin(),
   14747             :     end())` for the JSON value.
   14748             : 
   14749             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
   14750             :             defined as follows:
   14751             :             Value type  | return value
   14752             :             ----------- | -------------
   14753             :             null        | `0` (same as `size()`)
   14754             :             boolean     | `1` (same as `size()`)
   14755             :             string      | `1` (same as `size()`)
   14756             :             number      | `1` (same as `size()`)
   14757             :             object      | result of function `object_t::max_size()`
   14758             :             array       | result of function `array_t::max_size()`
   14759             : 
   14760             :     @liveexample{The following code calls `max_size()` on the different value
   14761             :     types. Note the output is implementation specific.,max_size}
   14762             : 
   14763             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
   14764             :     the Container concept; that is, their `max_size()` functions have constant
   14765             :     complexity.
   14766             : 
   14767             :     @iterators No changes.
   14768             : 
   14769             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   14770             : 
   14771             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14772             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14773             :     requirements:
   14774             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14775             :     - Has the semantics of returning `b.size()` where `b` is the largest
   14776             :       possible JSON value.
   14777             : 
   14778             :     @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
   14779             : 
   14780             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14781             :     */
   14782             :     size_type max_size() const noexcept
   14783             :     {
   14784             :         switch (m_type)
   14785             :         {
   14786             :         case value_t::array:
   14787             :         {
   14788             :             // delegate call to array_t::max_size()
   14789             :             return m_value.array->max_size();
   14790             :         }
   14791             : 
   14792             :         case value_t::object:
   14793             :         {
   14794             :             // delegate call to object_t::max_size()
   14795             :             return m_value.object->max_size();
   14796             :         }
   14797             : 
   14798             :         default:
   14799             :         {
   14800             :             // all other types have max_size() == size()
   14801             :             return size();
   14802             :         }
   14803             :         }
   14804             :     }
   14805             : 
   14806             :     /// @}
   14807             : 
   14808             :     ///////////////
   14809             :     // modifiers //
   14810             :     ///////////////
   14811             : 
   14812             :     /// @name modifiers
   14813             :     /// @{
   14814             : 
   14815             :     /*!
   14816             :     @brief clears the contents
   14817             : 
   14818             :     Clears the content of a JSON value and resets it to the default value as
   14819             :     if @ref basic_json(value_t) would have been called with the current value
   14820             :     type from @ref type():
   14821             : 
   14822             :     Value type  | initial value
   14823             :     ----------- | -------------
   14824             :     null        | `null`
   14825             :     boolean     | `false`
   14826             :     string      | `""`
   14827             :     number      | `0`
   14828             :     object      | `{}`
   14829             :     array       | `[]`
   14830             : 
   14831             :     @post Has the same effect as calling
   14832             :     @code {.cpp}
   14833             :     *this = basic_json(type());
   14834             :     @endcode
   14835             : 
   14836             :     @liveexample{The example below shows the effect of `clear()` to different
   14837             :     JSON types.,clear}
   14838             : 
   14839             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
   14840             : 
   14841             :     @iterators All iterators, pointers and references related to this container
   14842             :                are invalidated.
   14843             : 
   14844             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   14845             : 
   14846             :     @sa @ref basic_json(value_t) -- constructor that creates an object with the
   14847             :         same value than calling `clear()`
   14848             : 
   14849             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14850             :     */
   14851             :     void clear() noexcept
   14852             :     {
   14853             :         switch (m_type)
   14854             :         {
   14855             :         case value_t::number_integer:
   14856             :         {
   14857             :             m_value.number_integer = 0;
   14858             :             break;
   14859             :         }
   14860             : 
   14861             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
   14862             :         {
   14863             :             m_value.number_unsigned = 0;
   14864             :             break;
   14865             :         }
   14866             : 
   14867             :         case value_t::number_float:
   14868             :         {
   14869             :             m_value.number_float = 0.0;
   14870             :             break;
   14871             :         }
   14872             : 
   14873             :         case value_t::boolean:
   14874             :         {
   14875             :             m_value.boolean = false;
   14876             :             break;
   14877             :         }
   14878             : 
   14879             :         case value_t::string:
   14880             :         {
   14881             :             m_value.string->clear();
   14882             :             break;
   14883             :         }
   14884             : 
   14885             :         case value_t::array:
   14886             :         {
   14887             :             m_value.array->clear();
   14888             :             break;
   14889             :         }
   14890             : 
   14891             :         case value_t::object:
   14892             :         {
   14893             :             m_value.object->clear();
   14894             :             break;
   14895             :         }
   14896             : 
   14897             :         default:
   14898             :             break;
   14899             :         }
   14900             :     }
   14901             : 
   14902             :     /*!
   14903             :     @brief add an object to an array
   14904             : 
   14905             :     Appends the given element @a val to the end of the JSON value. If the
   14906             :     function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array is created before
   14907             :     appending @a val.
   14908             : 
   14909             :     @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON array
   14910             : 
   14911             :     @throw type_error.308 when called on a type other than JSON array or
   14912             :     null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
   14913             : 
   14914             :     @complexity Amortized constant.
   14915             : 
   14916             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
   14917             :     add elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently
   14918             :     converted to a JSON array.,push_back}
   14919             : 
   14920             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14921             :     */
   14922             :     void push_back(basic_json&& val)
   14923             :     {
   14924             :         // push_back only works for null objects or arrays
   14925             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
   14926             :         {
   14927             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " +
   14928             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   14929             :         }
   14930             : 
   14931             :         // transform null object into an array
   14932             :         if (is_null())
   14933             :         {
   14934             :             m_type = value_t::array;
   14935             :             m_value = value_t::array;
   14936             :             assert_invariant();
   14937             :         }
   14938             : 
   14939             :         // add element to array (move semantics)
   14940             :         m_value.array->push_back(std::move(val));
   14941             :         // invalidate object
   14942             :         val.m_type = value_t::null;
   14943             :     }
   14944             : 
   14945             :     /*!
   14946             :     @brief add an object to an array
   14947             :     @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
   14948             :     */
   14949             :     reference operator+=(basic_json&& val)
   14950             :     {
   14951             :         push_back(std::move(val));
   14952             :         return *this;
   14953             :     }
   14954             : 
   14955             :     /*!
   14956             :     @brief add an object to an array
   14957             :     @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
   14958             :     */
   14959             :     void push_back(const basic_json& val)
   14960             :     {
   14961             :         // push_back only works for null objects or arrays
   14962             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
   14963             :         {
   14964             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " +
   14965             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   14966             :         }
   14967             : 
   14968             :         // transform null object into an array
   14969             :         if (is_null())
   14970             :         {
   14971             :             m_type = value_t::array;
   14972             :             m_value = value_t::array;
   14973             :             assert_invariant();
   14974             :         }
   14975             : 
   14976             :         // add element to array
   14977             :         m_value.array->push_back(val);
   14978             :     }
   14979             : 
   14980             :     /*!
   14981             :     @brief add an object to an array
   14982             :     @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
   14983             :     */
   14984             :     reference operator+=(const basic_json& val)
   14985             :     {
   14986             :         push_back(val);
   14987             :         return *this;
   14988             :     }
   14989             : 
   14990             :     /*!
   14991             :     @brief add an object to an object
   14992             : 
   14993             :     Inserts the given element @a val to the JSON object. If the function is
   14994             :     called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before inserting
   14995             :     @a val.
   14996             : 
   14997             :     @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON object
   14998             : 
   14999             :     @throw type_error.308 when called on a type other than JSON object or
   15000             :     null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
   15001             : 
   15002             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
   15003             : 
   15004             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
   15005             :     add elements to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently
   15006             :     converted to a JSON object.,push_back__object_t__value}
   15007             : 
   15008             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15009             :     */
   15010             :     void push_back(const typename object_t::value_type& val)
   15011             :     {
   15012             :         // push_back only works for null objects or objects
   15013             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_object())))
   15014             :         {
   15015             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " +
   15016             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15017             :         }
   15018             : 
   15019             :         // transform null object into an object
   15020             :         if (is_null())
   15021             :         {
   15022             :             m_type = value_t::object;
   15023             :             m_value = value_t::object;
   15024             :             assert_invariant();
   15025             :         }
   15026             : 
   15027             :         // add element to array
   15028             :         m_value.object->insert(val);
   15029             :     }
   15030             : 
   15031             :     /*!
   15032             :     @brief add an object to an object
   15033             :     @copydoc push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&)
   15034             :     */
   15035             :     reference operator+=(const typename object_t::value_type& val)
   15036             :     {
   15037             :         push_back(val);
   15038             :         return *this;
   15039             :     }
   15040             : 
   15041             :     /*!
   15042             :     @brief add an object to an object
   15043             : 
   15044             :     This function allows to use `push_back` with an initializer list. In case
   15045             : 
   15046             :     1. the current value is an object,
   15047             :     2. the initializer list @a init contains only two elements, and
   15048             :     3. the first element of @a init is a string,
   15049             : 
   15050             :     @a init is converted into an object element and added using
   15051             :     @ref push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&). Otherwise, @a init
   15052             :     is converted to a JSON value and added using @ref push_back(basic_json&&).
   15053             : 
   15054             :     @param[in] init  an initializer list
   15055             : 
   15056             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
   15057             : 
   15058             :     @note This function is required to resolve an ambiguous overload error,
   15059             :           because pairs like `{"key", "value"}` can be both interpreted as
   15060             :           `object_t::value_type` or `std::initializer_list<basic_json>`, see
   15061             :           https://github.com/nlohmann/json/issues/235 for more information.
   15062             : 
   15063             :     @liveexample{The example shows how initializer lists are treated as
   15064             :     objects when possible.,push_back__initializer_list}
   15065             :     */
   15066             :     void push_back(initializer_list_t init)
   15067             :     {
   15068             :         if (is_object() and init.size() == 2 and (*init.begin())->is_string())
   15069             :         {
   15070             :             basic_json&& key = init.begin()->moved_or_copied();
   15071             :             push_back(typename object_t::value_type(
   15072             :                 std::move(key.get_ref<string_t&>()),
   15073             :                 (init.begin() + 1)->moved_or_copied()));
   15074             :         }
   15075             :         else
   15076             :         {
   15077             :             push_back(basic_json(init));
   15078             :         }
   15079             :     }
   15080             : 
   15081             :     /*!
   15082             :     @brief add an object to an object
   15083             :     @copydoc push_back(initializer_list_t)
   15084             :     */
   15085             :     reference operator+=(initializer_list_t init)
   15086             :     {
   15087             :         push_back(init);
   15088             :         return *this;
   15089             :     }
   15090             : 
   15091             :     /*!
   15092             :     @brief add an object to an array
   15093             : 
   15094             :     Creates a JSON value from the passed parameters @a args to the end of the
   15095             :     JSON value. If the function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array
   15096             :     is created before appending the value created from @a args.
   15097             : 
   15098             :     @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
   15099             :     @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
   15100             : 
   15101             :     @throw type_error.311 when called on a type other than JSON array or
   15102             :     null; example: `"cannot use emplace_back() with number"`
   15103             : 
   15104             :     @complexity Amortized constant.
   15105             : 
   15106             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` can be used to add
   15107             :     elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently converted
   15108             :     to a JSON array.,emplace_back}
   15109             : 
   15110             :     @since version 2.0.8
   15111             :     */
   15112             :     template <class... Args>
   15113             :     void emplace_back(Args&&... args)
   15114             :     {
   15115             :         // emplace_back only works for null objects or arrays
   15116             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
   15117             :         {
   15118             :             JSON_THROW(
   15119             :                 type_error::create(311, "cannot use emplace_back() with " +
   15120             :                                             std::string(type_name())));
   15121             :         }
   15122             : 
   15123             :         // transform null object into an array
   15124             :         if (is_null())
   15125             :         {
   15126             :             m_type = value_t::array;
   15127             :             m_value = value_t::array;
   15128             :             assert_invariant();
   15129             :         }
   15130             : 
   15131             :         // add element to array (perfect forwarding)
   15132             :         m_value.array->emplace_back(std::forward<Args>(args)...);
   15133             :     }
   15134             : 
   15135             :     /*!
   15136             :     @brief add an object to an object if key does not exist
   15137             : 
   15138             :     Inserts a new element into a JSON object constructed in-place with the
   15139             :     given @a args if there is no element with the key in the container. If the
   15140             :     function is called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before
   15141             :     appending the value created from @a args.
   15142             : 
   15143             :     @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
   15144             :     @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
   15145             : 
   15146             :     @return a pair consisting of an iterator to the inserted element, or the
   15147             :             already-existing element if no insertion happened, and a bool
   15148             :             denoting whether the insertion took place.
   15149             : 
   15150             :     @throw type_error.311 when called on a type other than JSON object or
   15151             :     null; example: `"cannot use emplace() with number"`
   15152             : 
   15153             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
   15154             : 
   15155             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `emplace()` can be used to add elements
   15156             :     to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently converted to a
   15157             :     JSON object. Further note how no value is added if there was already one
   15158             :     value stored with the same key.,emplace}
   15159             : 
   15160             :     @since version 2.0.8
   15161             :     */
   15162             :     template <class... Args>
   15163             :     std::pair<iterator, bool> emplace(Args&&... args)
   15164             :     {
   15165             :         // emplace only works for null objects or arrays
   15166             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_object())))
   15167             :         {
   15168             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(311, "cannot use emplace() with " +
   15169             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15170             :         }
   15171             : 
   15172             :         // transform null object into an object
   15173             :         if (is_null())
   15174             :         {
   15175             :             m_type = value_t::object;
   15176             :             m_value = value_t::object;
   15177             :             assert_invariant();
   15178             :         }
   15179             : 
   15180             :         // add element to array (perfect forwarding)
   15181             :         auto res = m_value.object->emplace(std::forward<Args>(args)...);
   15182             :         // create result iterator and set iterator to the result of emplace
   15183             :         auto it = begin();
   15184             :         it.m_it.object_iterator = res.first;
   15185             : 
   15186             :         // return pair of iterator and boolean
   15187             :         return {it, res.second};
   15188             :     }
   15189             : 
   15190             :     /*!
   15191             :     @brief inserts element
   15192             : 
   15193             :     Inserts element @a val before iterator @a pos.
   15194             : 
   15195             :     @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
   15196             :     the end() iterator
   15197             :     @param[in] val element to insert
   15198             :     @return iterator pointing to the inserted @a val.
   15199             : 
   15200             :     @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays;
   15201             :     example: `"cannot use insert() with string"`
   15202             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
   15203             :     example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
   15204             : 
   15205             :     @complexity Constant plus linear in the distance between @a pos and end of
   15206             :     the container.
   15207             : 
   15208             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert}
   15209             : 
   15210             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15211             :     */
   15212             :     iterator insert(const_iterator pos, const basic_json& val)
   15213             :     {
   15214             :         // insert only works for arrays
   15215             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   15216             :         {
   15217             :             // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
   15218             :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
   15219             :             {
   15220             :                 JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   15221             :                     202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
   15222             :             }
   15223             : 
   15224             :             // insert to array and return iterator
   15225             :             return insert_iterator(pos, val);
   15226             :         }
   15227             : 
   15228             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " +
   15229             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   15230             :     }
   15231             : 
   15232             :     /*!
   15233             :     @brief inserts element
   15234             :     @copydoc insert(const_iterator, const basic_json&)
   15235             :     */
   15236             :     iterator insert(const_iterator pos, basic_json&& val)
   15237             :     {
   15238             :         return insert(pos, val);
   15239             :     }
   15240             : 
   15241             :     /*!
   15242             :     @brief inserts elements
   15243             : 
   15244             :     Inserts @a cnt copies of @a val before iterator @a pos.
   15245             : 
   15246             :     @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
   15247             :     the end() iterator
   15248             :     @param[in] cnt number of copies of @a val to insert
   15249             :     @param[in] val element to insert
   15250             :     @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
   15251             :     `cnt==0`
   15252             : 
   15253             :     @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays; example:
   15254             :     `"cannot use insert() with string"`
   15255             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
   15256             :     example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
   15257             : 
   15258             :     @complexity Linear in @a cnt plus linear in the distance between @a pos
   15259             :     and end of the container.
   15260             : 
   15261             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__count}
   15262             : 
   15263             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15264             :     */
   15265             :     iterator insert(const_iterator pos, size_type cnt, const basic_json& val)
   15266             :     {
   15267             :         // insert only works for arrays
   15268             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   15269             :         {
   15270             :             // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
   15271             :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
   15272             :             {
   15273             :                 JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   15274             :                     202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
   15275             :             }
   15276             : 
   15277             :             // insert to array and return iterator
   15278             :             return insert_iterator(pos, cnt, val);
   15279             :         }
   15280             : 
   15281             :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " +
   15282             :                                                std::string(type_name())));
   15283             :     }
   15284             : 
   15285             :     /*!
   15286             :     @brief inserts elements
   15287             : 
   15288             :     Inserts elements from range `[first, last)` before iterator @a pos.
   15289             : 
   15290             :     @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
   15291             :     the end() iterator
   15292             :     @param[in] first begin of the range of elements to insert
   15293             :     @param[in] last end of the range of elements to insert
   15294             : 
   15295             :     @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays; example:
   15296             :     `"cannot use insert() with string"`
   15297             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
   15298             :     example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
   15299             :     @throw invalid_iterator.210 if @a first and @a last do not belong to the
   15300             :     same JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit"`
   15301             :     @throw invalid_iterator.211 if @a first or @a last are iterators into
   15302             :     container for which insert is called; example: `"passed iterators may not
   15303             :     belong to container"`
   15304             : 
   15305             :     @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
   15306             :     `first==last`
   15307             : 
   15308             :     @complexity Linear in `std::distance(first, last)` plus linear in the
   15309             :     distance between @a pos and end of the container.
   15310             : 
   15311             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__range}
   15312             : 
   15313             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15314             :     */
   15315             :     iterator insert(const_iterator pos, const_iterator first,
   15316             :                     const_iterator last)
   15317             :     {
   15318             :         // insert only works for arrays
   15319             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_array()))
   15320             :         {
   15321             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " +
   15322             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15323             :         }
   15324             : 
   15325             :         // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
   15326             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
   15327             :         {
   15328             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   15329             :                 202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
   15330             :         }
   15331             : 
   15332             :         // check if range iterators belong to the same JSON object
   15333             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
   15334             :         {
   15335             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(210, "iterators do not fit"));
   15336             :         }
   15337             : 
   15338             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object == this))
   15339             :         {
   15340             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   15341             :                 211, "passed iterators may not belong to container"));
   15342             :         }
   15343             : 
   15344             :         // insert to array and return iterator
   15345             :         return insert_iterator(
   15346             :                                pos,
   15347             :                                first.m_it.array_iterator,
   15348             :                                last.m_it.array_iterator);
   15349             :     }
   15350             : 
   15351             :     /*!
   15352             :     @brief inserts elements
   15353             : 
   15354             :     Inserts elements from initializer list @a ilist before iterator @a pos.
   15355             : 
   15356             :     @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
   15357             :     the end() iterator
   15358             :     @param[in] ilist initializer list to insert the values from
   15359             : 
   15360             :     @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays; example:
   15361             :     `"cannot use insert() with string"`
   15362             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
   15363             :     example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
   15364             : 
   15365             :     @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
   15366             :     `ilist` is empty
   15367             : 
   15368             :     @complexity Linear in `ilist.size()` plus linear in the distance between
   15369             :     @a pos and end of the container.
   15370             : 
   15371             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__ilist}
   15372             : 
   15373             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15374             :     */
   15375             :     iterator insert(const_iterator pos, initializer_list_t ilist)
   15376             :     {
   15377             :         // insert only works for arrays
   15378             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_array()))
   15379             :         {
   15380             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " +
   15381             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15382             :         }
   15383             : 
   15384             :         // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
   15385             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
   15386             :         {
   15387             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   15388             :                 202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
   15389             :         }
   15390             : 
   15391             :         // insert to array and return iterator
   15392             :         return insert_iterator(pos, ilist.begin(), ilist.end());
   15393             :     }
   15394             : 
   15395             :     /*!
   15396             :     @brief inserts elements
   15397             : 
   15398             :     Inserts elements from range `[first, last)`.
   15399             : 
   15400             :     @param[in] first begin of the range of elements to insert
   15401             :     @param[in] last end of the range of elements to insert
   15402             : 
   15403             :     @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than objects; example:
   15404             :     `"cannot use insert() with string"`
   15405             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if iterator @a first or @a last does does not
   15406             :     point to an object; example: `"iterators first and last must point to
   15407             :     objects"`
   15408             :     @throw invalid_iterator.210 if @a first and @a last do not belong to the
   15409             :     same JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit"`
   15410             : 
   15411             :     @complexity Logarithmic: `O(N*log(size() + N))`, where `N` is the number
   15412             :     of elements to insert.
   15413             : 
   15414             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__range_object}
   15415             : 
   15416             :     @since version 3.0.0
   15417             :     */
   15418             :     void insert(const_iterator first, const_iterator last)
   15419             :     {
