   15420             :         // insert only works for objects
   15421             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_object()))
   15422             :         {
   15423             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " +
   15424             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15425             :         }
   15426             : 
   15427             :         // check if range iterators belong to the same JSON object
   15428             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
   15429             :         {
   15430             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(210, "iterators do not fit"));
   15431             :         }
   15432             : 
   15433             :         // passed iterators must belong to objects
   15434             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_object->is_object()))
   15435             :         {
   15436             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   15437             :                 202, "iterators first and last must point to objects"));
   15438             :         }
   15439             : 
   15440             :         m_value.object->insert(first.m_it.object_iterator,
   15441             :                                last.m_it.object_iterator);
   15442             :     }
   15443             : 
   15444             :     /*!
   15445             :     @brief updates a JSON object from another object, overwriting existing keys
   15446             : 
   15447             :     Inserts all values from JSON object @a j and overwrites existing keys.
   15448             : 
   15449             :     @param[in] j  JSON object to read values from
   15450             : 
   15451             :     @throw type_error.312 if called on JSON values other than objects; example:
   15452             :     `"cannot use update() with string"`
   15453             : 
   15454             :     @complexity O(N*log(size() + N)), where N is the number of elements to
   15455             :                 insert.
   15456             : 
   15457             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `update()` is used.,update}
   15458             : 
   15459             :     @sa https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/stdtypes.html#dict.update
   15460             : 
   15461             :     @since version 3.0.0
   15462             :     */
   15463             :     void update(const_reference j)
   15464             :     {
   15465             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
   15466             :         if (is_null())
   15467             :         {
   15468             :             m_type = value_t::object;
   15469             :             m_value.object = create<object_t>();
   15470             :             assert_invariant();
   15471             :         }
   15472             : 
   15473             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_object()))
   15474             :         {
   15475             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(312, "cannot use update() with " +
   15476             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15477             :         }
   15478             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not j.is_object()))
   15479             :         {
   15480             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(312, "cannot use update() with " +
   15481             :                                                    std::string(j.type_name())));
   15482             :         }
   15483             : 
   15484             :         for (auto it = j.cbegin(); it != j.cend(); ++it)
   15485             :         {
   15486             :             m_value.object->operator[](it.key()) = it.value();
   15487             :         }
   15488             :     }
   15489             : 
   15490             :     /*!
   15491             :     @brief updates a JSON object from another object, overwriting existing keys
   15492             : 
   15493             :     Inserts all values from from range `[first, last)` and overwrites existing
   15494             :     keys.
   15495             : 
   15496             :     @param[in] first begin of the range of elements to insert
   15497             :     @param[in] last end of the range of elements to insert
   15498             : 
   15499             :     @throw type_error.312 if called on JSON values other than objects; example:
   15500             :     `"cannot use update() with string"`
   15501             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if iterator @a first or @a last does does not
   15502             :     point to an object; example: `"iterators first and last must point to
   15503             :     objects"`
   15504             :     @throw invalid_iterator.210 if @a first and @a last do not belong to the
   15505             :     same JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit"`
   15506             : 
   15507             :     @complexity O(N*log(size() + N)), where N is the number of elements to
   15508             :                 insert.
   15509             : 
   15510             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `update()` is used__range.,update}
   15511             : 
   15512             :     @sa https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/stdtypes.html#dict.update
   15513             : 
   15514             :     @since version 3.0.0
   15515             :     */
   15516             :     void update(const_iterator first, const_iterator last)
   15517             :     {
   15518             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
   15519             :         if (is_null())
   15520             :         {
   15521             :             m_type = value_t::object;
   15522             :             m_value.object = create<object_t>();
   15523             :             assert_invariant();
   15524             :         }
   15525             : 
   15526             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_object()))
   15527             :         {
   15528             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(312, "cannot use update() with " +
   15529             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15530             :         }
   15531             : 
   15532             :         // check if range iterators belong to the same JSON object
   15533             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
   15534             :         {
   15535             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(210, "iterators do not fit"));
   15536             :         }
   15537             : 
   15538             :         // passed iterators must belong to objects
   15539             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_object->is_object() or
   15540             :                           not last.m_object->is_object()))
   15541             :         {
   15542             :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(
   15543             :                 202, "iterators first and last must point to objects"));
   15544             :         }
   15545             : 
   15546             :         for (auto it = first; it != last; ++it)
   15547             :         {
   15548             :             m_value.object->operator[](it.key()) = it.value();
   15549             :         }
   15550             :     }
   15551             : 
   15552             :     /*!
   15553             :     @brief exchanges the values
   15554             : 
   15555             :     Exchanges the contents of the JSON value with those of @a other. Does not
   15556             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
   15557             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
   15558             :     invalidated.
   15559             : 
   15560             :     @param[in,out] other JSON value to exchange the contents with
   15561             : 
   15562             :     @complexity Constant.
   15563             : 
   15564             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values can be swapped with
   15565             :     `swap()`.,swap__reference}
   15566             : 
   15567             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15568             :     */
   15569             :     void swap(reference other) noexcept(
   15570             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
   15571             :             std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
   15572             :                 std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
   15573             :                     std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value)
   15574             :     {
   15575             :         std::swap(m_type, other.m_type);
   15576             :         std::swap(m_value, other.m_value);
   15577             :         assert_invariant();
   15578             :     }
   15579             : 
   15580             :     /*!
   15581             :     @brief exchanges the values
   15582             : 
   15583             :     Exchanges the contents of a JSON array with those of @a other. Does not
   15584             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
   15585             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
   15586             :     invalidated.
   15587             : 
   15588             :     @param[in,out] other array to exchange the contents with
   15589             : 
   15590             :     @throw type_error.310 when JSON value is not an array; example: `"cannot
   15591             :     use swap() with string"`
   15592             : 
   15593             :     @complexity Constant.
   15594             : 
   15595             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how arrays can be swapped with
   15596             :     `swap()`.,swap__array_t}
   15597             : 
   15598             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15599             :     */
   15600             :     void swap(array_t& other)
   15601             :     {
   15602             :         // swap only works for arrays
   15603             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   15604             :         {
   15605             :             std::swap(*(m_value.array), other);
   15606             :         }
   15607             :         else
   15608             :         {
   15609             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(310, "cannot use swap() with " +
   15610             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15611             :         }
   15612             :     }
   15613             : 
   15614             :     /*!
   15615             :     @brief exchanges the values
   15616             : 
   15617             :     Exchanges the contents of a JSON object with those of @a other. Does not
   15618             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
   15619             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
   15620             :     invalidated.
   15621             : 
   15622             :     @param[in,out] other object to exchange the contents with
   15623             : 
   15624             :     @throw type_error.310 when JSON value is not an object; example:
   15625             :     `"cannot use swap() with string"`
   15626             : 
   15627             :     @complexity Constant.
   15628             : 
   15629             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how objects can be swapped with
   15630             :     `swap()`.,swap__object_t}
   15631             : 
   15632             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15633             :     */
   15634             :     void swap(object_t& other)
   15635             :     {
   15636             :         // swap only works for objects
   15637             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   15638             :         {
   15639             :             std::swap(*(m_value.object), other);
   15640             :         }
   15641             :         else
   15642             :         {
   15643             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(310, "cannot use swap() with " +
   15644             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15645             :         }
   15646             :     }
   15647             : 
   15648             :     /*!
   15649             :     @brief exchanges the values
   15650             : 
   15651             :     Exchanges the contents of a JSON string with those of @a other. Does not
   15652             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
   15653             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
   15654             :     invalidated.
   15655             : 
   15656             :     @param[in,out] other string to exchange the contents with
   15657             : 
   15658             :     @throw type_error.310 when JSON value is not a string; example: `"cannot
   15659             :     use swap() with boolean"`
   15660             : 
   15661             :     @complexity Constant.
   15662             : 
   15663             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how strings can be swapped with
   15664             :     `swap()`.,swap__string_t}
   15665             : 
   15666             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15667             :     */
   15668             :     void swap(string_t& other)
   15669             :     {
   15670             :         // swap only works for strings
   15671             :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_string()))
   15672             :         {
   15673             :             std::swap(*(m_value.string), other);
   15674             :         }
   15675             :         else
   15676             :         {
   15677             :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(310, "cannot use swap() with " +
   15678             :                                                    std::string(type_name())));
   15679             :         }
   15680             :     }
   15681             : 
   15682             :     /// @}
   15683             : 
   15684             : public:
   15685             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   15686             :     // lexicographical comparison operators //
   15687             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   15688             : 
   15689             :     /// @name lexicographical comparison operators
   15690             :     /// @{
   15691             : 
   15692             :     /*!
   15693             :     @brief comparison: equal
   15694             : 
   15695             :     Compares two JSON values for equality according to the following rules:
   15696             :     - Two JSON values are equal if (1) they are from the same type and (2)
   15697             :       their stored values are the same according to their respective
   15698             :       `operator==`.
   15699             :     - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
   15700             :       comparison. Note than two NaN values are always treated as unequal.
   15701             :     - Two JSON null values are equal.
   15702             : 
   15703             :     @note Floating-point inside JSON values numbers are compared with
   15704             :     `json::number_float_t::operator==` which is `double::operator==` by
   15705             :     default. To compare floating-point while respecting an epsilon, an
   15706             :     alternative
   15707             :     [comparison
   15708             :     function](https://github.com/mariokonrad/marnav/blob/master/src/marnav/math/floatingpoint.hpp#L34-#L39)
   15709             :     could be used, for instance
   15710             :     @code {.cpp}
   15711             :     template<typename T, typename = typename
   15712             :     std::enable_if<std::is_floating_point<T>::value, T>::type>
   15713             :     inline bool is_same(T a, T b, T epsilon = std::numeric_limits<T>::epsilon())
   15714             :     noexcept
   15715             :     {
   15716             :         return std::abs(a - b) <= epsilon;
   15717             :     }
   15718             :     @endcode
   15719             : 
   15720             :     @note NaN values never compare equal to themselves or to other NaN values.
   15721             : 
   15722             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   15723             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   15724             :     @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are equal
   15725             : 
   15726             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   15727             : 
   15728             :     @complexity Linear.
   15729             : 
   15730             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   15731             :     types.,operator__equal}
   15732             : 
   15733             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15734             :     */
   15735             :     friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   15736             :     {
   15737             :         const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
   15738             :         const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
   15739             : 
   15740             :         if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
   15741             :         {
   15742             :             switch (lhs_type)
   15743             :             {
   15744             :             case value_t::array:
   15745             :                 return (*lhs.m_value.array == *rhs.m_value.array);
   15746             : 
   15747             :             case value_t::object:
   15748             :                 return (*lhs.m_value.object == *rhs.m_value.object);
   15749             : 
   15750             :             case value_t::null:
   15751             :                 return true;
   15752             : 
   15753             :             case value_t::string:
   15754             :                 return (*lhs.m_value.string == *rhs.m_value.string);
   15755             : 
   15756             :             case value_t::boolean:
   15757             :                 return (lhs.m_value.boolean == rhs.m_value.boolean);
   15758             : 
   15759             :             case value_t::number_integer:
   15760             :                 return (lhs.m_value.number_integer ==
   15761             :                         rhs.m_value.number_integer);
   15762             : 
   15763             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   15764             :                 return (lhs.m_value.number_unsigned ==
   15765             :                         rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
   15766             : 
   15767             :             case value_t::number_float:
   15768             :                 return (lhs.m_value.number_float == rhs.m_value.number_float);
   15769             : 
   15770             :             default:
   15771             :                 return false;
   15772             :             }
   15773             :         }
   15774             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and
   15775             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
   15776             :         {
   15777             :             return (static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer) ==
   15778             :                     rhs.m_value.number_float);
   15779             :         }
   15780             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and
   15781             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
   15782             :         {
   15783             :             return (lhs.m_value.number_float ==
   15784             :                     static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_integer));
   15785             :         }
   15786             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and
   15787             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
   15788             :         {
   15789             :             return (static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) ==
   15790             :                     rhs.m_value.number_float);
   15791             :         }
   15792             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and
   15793             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
   15794             :         {
   15795             :             return (lhs.m_value.number_float ==
   15796             :                     static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned));
   15797             :         }
   15798             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and
   15799             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
   15800             :         {
   15801             :             return (
   15802             :                 static_cast<number_integer_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) ==
   15803             :                 rhs.m_value.number_integer);
   15804             :         }
   15805             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and
   15806             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
   15807             :         {
   15808             :             return (lhs.m_value.number_integer ==
   15809             :                     static_cast<number_integer_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned));
   15810             :         }
   15811             : 
   15812             :         return false;
   15813             :     }
   15814             : 
   15815             :     /*!
   15816             :     @brief comparison: equal
   15817             :     @copydoc operator==(const_reference, const_reference)
   15818             :     */
   15819             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   15820             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   15821             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   15822             :     friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
   15823             :     {
   15824             :         return (lhs == basic_json(rhs));
   15825             :     }
   15826             : 
   15827             :     /*!
   15828             :     @brief comparison: equal
   15829             :     @copydoc operator==(const_reference, const_reference)
   15830             :     */
   15831             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   15832             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   15833             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   15834             :     friend bool operator==(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   15835             :     {
   15836             :         return (basic_json(lhs) == rhs);
   15837             :     }
   15838             : 
   15839             :     /*!
   15840             :     @brief comparison: not equal
   15841             : 
   15842             :     Compares two JSON values for inequality by calculating `not (lhs == rhs)`.
   15843             : 
   15844             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   15845             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   15846             :     @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are not equal
   15847             : 
   15848             :     @complexity Linear.
   15849             : 
   15850             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   15851             : 
   15852             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   15853             :     types.,operator__notequal}
   15854             : 
   15855             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15856             :     */
   15857             :     friend bool operator!=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   15858             :     {
   15859             :         return not(lhs == rhs);
   15860             :     }
   15861             : 
   15862             :     /*!
   15863             :     @brief comparison: not equal
   15864             :     @copydoc operator!=(const_reference, const_reference)
   15865             :     */
   15866             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   15867             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   15868             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   15869             :     friend bool operator!=(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
   15870             :     {
   15871             :         return (lhs != basic_json(rhs));
   15872             :     }
   15873             : 
   15874             :     /*!
   15875             :     @brief comparison: not equal
   15876             :     @copydoc operator!=(const_reference, const_reference)
   15877             :     */
   15878             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   15879             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   15880             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   15881             :     friend bool operator!=(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   15882             :     {
   15883             :         return (basic_json(lhs) != rhs);
   15884             :     }
   15885             : 
   15886             :     /*!
   15887             :     @brief comparison: less than
   15888             : 
   15889             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than another JSON value @a
   15890             :     rhs according to the following rules:
   15891             :     - If @a lhs and @a rhs have the same type, the values are compared using
   15892             :       the default `<` operator.
   15893             :     - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
   15894             :       comparison
   15895             :     - In case @a lhs and @a rhs have different types, the values are ignored
   15896             :       and the order of the types is considered, see
   15897             :       @ref operator<(const value_t, const value_t).
   15898             : 
   15899             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   15900             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   15901             :     @return whether @a lhs is less than @a rhs
   15902             : 
   15903             :     @complexity Linear.
   15904             : 
   15905             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   15906             : 
   15907             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   15908             :     types.,operator__less}
   15909             : 
   15910             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15911             :     */
   15912             :     friend bool operator<(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   15913             :     {
   15914             :         const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
   15915             :         const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
   15916             : 
   15917             :         if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
   15918             :         {
   15919             :             switch (lhs_type)
   15920             :             {
   15921             :             case value_t::array:
   15922             :                 return (*lhs.m_value.array) < (*rhs.m_value.array);
   15923             : 
   15924             :             case value_t::object:
   15925             :                 return *lhs.m_value.object < *rhs.m_value.object;
   15926             : 
   15927             :             case value_t::null:
   15928             :                 return false;
   15929             : 
   15930             :             case value_t::string:
   15931             :                 return *lhs.m_value.string < *rhs.m_value.string;
   15932             : 
   15933             :             case value_t::boolean:
   15934             :                 return lhs.m_value.boolean < rhs.m_value.boolean;
   15935             : 
   15936             :             case value_t::number_integer:
   15937             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_integer < rhs.m_value.number_integer;
   15938             : 
   15939             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   15940             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_unsigned <
   15941             :                        rhs.m_value.number_unsigned;
   15942             : 
   15943             :             case value_t::number_float:
   15944             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_float < rhs.m_value.number_float;
   15945             : 
   15946             :             default:
   15947             :                 return false;
   15948             :             }
   15949             :         }
   15950             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and
   15951             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
   15952             :         {
   15953             :             return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer) <
   15954             :                    rhs.m_value.number_float;
   15955             :         }
   15956             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and
   15957             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
   15958             :         {
   15959             :             return lhs.m_value.number_float <
   15960             :                    static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_integer);
   15961             :         }
   15962             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and
   15963             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
   15964             :         {
   15965             :             return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) <
   15966             :                    rhs.m_value.number_float;
   15967             :         }
   15968             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and
   15969             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
   15970             :         {
   15971             :             return lhs.m_value.number_float <
   15972             :                    static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
   15973             :         }
   15974             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and
   15975             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
   15976             :         {
   15977             :             return lhs.m_value.number_integer <
   15978             :                    static_cast<number_integer_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
   15979             :         }
   15980             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and
   15981             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
   15982             :         {
   15983             :             return static_cast<number_integer_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) <
   15984             :                    rhs.m_value.number_integer;
   15985             :         }
   15986             : 
   15987             :         // We only reach this line if we cannot compare values. In that case,
   15988             :         // we compare types. Note we have to call the operator explicitly,
   15989             :         // because MSVC has problems otherwise.
   15990             :         return operator<(lhs_type, rhs_type);
   15991             :     }
   15992             : 
   15993             :     /*!
   15994             :     @brief comparison: less than
   15995             :     @copydoc operator<(const_reference, const_reference)
   15996             :     */
   15997             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   15998             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   15999             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16000             :     friend bool operator<(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
   16001             :     {
   16002             :         return (lhs < basic_json(rhs));
   16003             :     }
   16004             : 
   16005             :     /*!
   16006             :     @brief comparison: less than
   16007             :     @copydoc operator<(const_reference, const_reference)
   16008             :     */
   16009             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   16010             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   16011             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16012             :     friend bool operator<(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16013             :     {
   16014             :         return (basic_json(lhs) < rhs);
   16015             :     }
   16016             : 
   16017             :     /*!
   16018             :     @brief comparison: less than or equal
   16019             : 
   16020             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than or equal to another
   16021             :     JSON value by calculating `not (rhs < lhs)`.
   16022             : 
   16023             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   16024             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   16025             :     @return whether @a lhs is less than or equal to @a rhs
   16026             : 
   16027             :     @complexity Linear.
   16028             : 
   16029             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16030             : 
   16031             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   16032             :     types.,operator__greater}
   16033             : 
   16034             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16035             :     */
   16036             :     friend bool operator<=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16037             :     {
   16038             :         return not(rhs < lhs);
   16039             :     }
   16040             : 
   16041             :     /*!
   16042             :     @brief comparison: less than or equal
   16043             :     @copydoc operator<=(const_reference, const_reference)
   16044             :     */
   16045             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   16046             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   16047             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16048             :     friend bool operator<=(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
   16049             :     {
   16050             :         return (lhs <= basic_json(rhs));
   16051             :     }
   16052             : 
   16053             :     /*!
   16054             :     @brief comparison: less than or equal
   16055             :     @copydoc operator<=(const_reference, const_reference)
   16056             :     */
   16057             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   16058             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   16059             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16060             :     friend bool operator<=(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16061             :     {
   16062             :         return (basic_json(lhs) <= rhs);
   16063             :     }
   16064             : 
   16065             :     /*!
   16066             :     @brief comparison: greater than
   16067             : 
   16068             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is greater than another
   16069             :     JSON value by calculating `not (lhs <= rhs)`.
   16070             : 
   16071             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   16072             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   16073             :     @return whether @a lhs is greater than to @a rhs
   16074             : 
   16075             :     @complexity Linear.
   16076             : 
   16077             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16078             : 
   16079             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   16080             :     types.,operator__lessequal}
   16081             : 
   16082             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16083             :     */
   16084             :     friend bool operator>(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16085             :     {
   16086             :         return not(lhs <= rhs);
   16087             :     }
   16088             : 
   16089             :     /*!
   16090             :     @brief comparison: greater than
   16091             :     @copydoc operator>(const_reference, const_reference)
   16092             :     */
   16093             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   16094             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   16095             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16096             :     friend bool operator>(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
   16097             :     {
   16098             :         return (lhs > basic_json(rhs));
   16099             :     }
   16100             : 
   16101             :     /*!
   16102             :     @brief comparison: greater than
   16103             :     @copydoc operator>(const_reference, const_reference)
   16104             :     */
   16105             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   16106             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   16107             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16108             :     friend bool operator>(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16109             :     {
   16110             :         return (basic_json(lhs) > rhs);
   16111             :     }
   16112             : 
   16113             :     /*!
   16114             :     @brief comparison: greater than or equal
   16115             : 
   16116             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is greater than or equal to another
   16117             :     JSON value by calculating `not (lhs < rhs)`.
   16118             : 
   16119             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   16120             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   16121             :     @return whether @a lhs is greater than or equal to @a rhs
   16122             : 
   16123             :     @complexity Linear.
   16124             : 
   16125             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16126             : 
   16127             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   16128             :     types.,operator__greaterequal}
   16129             : 
   16130             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16131             :     */
   16132             :     friend bool operator>=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16133             :     {
   16134             :         return not(lhs < rhs);
   16135             :     }
   16136             : 
   16137             :     /*!
   16138             :     @brief comparison: greater than or equal
   16139             :     @copydoc operator>=(const_reference, const_reference)
   16140             :     */
   16141             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   16142             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   16143             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16144             :     friend bool operator>=(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
   16145             :     {
   16146             :         return (lhs >= basic_json(rhs));
   16147             :     }
   16148             : 
   16149             :     /*!
   16150             :     @brief comparison: greater than or equal
   16151             :     @copydoc operator>=(const_reference, const_reference)
   16152             :     */
   16153             :     template <typename ScalarType,
   16154             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
   16155             :                                       int>::type = 0>
   16156             :     friend bool operator>=(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16157             :     {
   16158             :         return (basic_json(lhs) >= rhs);
   16159             :     }
   16160             : 
   16161             :     /// @}
   16162             : 
   16163             :     ///////////////////
   16164             :     // serialization //
   16165             :     ///////////////////
   16166             : 
   16167             :     /// @name serialization
   16168             :     /// @{
   16169             : 
   16170             :     /*!
   16171             :     @brief serialize to stream
   16172             : 
   16173             :     Serialize the given JSON value @a j to the output stream @a o. The JSON
   16174             :     value will be serialized using the @ref dump member function.
   16175             : 
   16176             :     - The indentation of the output can be controlled with the member variable
   16177             :       `width` of the output stream @a o. For instance, using the manipulator
   16178             :       `std::setw(4)` on @a o sets the indentation level to `4` and the
   16179             :       serialization result is the same as calling `dump(4)`.
   16180             : 
   16181             :     - The indentation character can be controlled with the member variable
   16182             :       `fill` of the output stream @a o. For instance, the manipulator
   16183             :       `std::setfill('\\t')` sets indentation to use a tab character rather than
   16184             :       the default space character.
   16185             : 
   16186             :     @param[in,out] o  stream to serialize to
   16187             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   16188             : 
   16189             :     @return the stream @a o
   16190             : 
   16191             :     @throw type_error.316 if a string stored inside the JSON value is not
   16192             :                           UTF-8 encoded
   16193             : 
   16194             :     @complexity Linear.
   16195             : 
   16196             :     @liveexample{The example below shows the serialization with different
   16197             :     parameters to `width` to adjust the indentation level.,operator_serialize}
   16198             : 
   16199             :     @since version 1.0.0; indentation character added in version 3.0.0
   16200             :     */
   16201             :     friend std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& o, const basic_json& j)
   16202             :     {
   16203             :         // read width member and use it as indentation parameter if nonzero
   16204             :         const bool pretty_print = (o.width() > 0);
   16205             :         const auto indentation = (pretty_print ? o.width() : 0);
   16206             : 
   16207             :         // reset width to 0 for subsequent calls to this stream
   16208             :         o.width(0);
   16209             : 
   16210             :         // do the actual serialization
   16211             :         serializer s(detail::output_adapter<char>(o), o.fill());
   16212             :         s.dump(j, pretty_print, false, static_cast<unsigned int>(indentation));
   16213             :         return o;
   16214             :     }
   16215             : 
   16216             :     /*!
   16217             :     @brief serialize to stream
   16218             :     @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
   16219             :                 future 4.0.0 of the library. Please use
   16220             :                 @ref operator<<(std::ostream&, const basic_json&)
   16221             :                 instead; that is, replace calls like `j >> o;` with `o << j;`.
   16222             :     @since version 1.0.0; deprecated since version 3.0.0
   16223             :     */
   16224             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
   16225             :     friend std::ostream& operator>>(const basic_json& j, std::ostream& o)
   16226             :     {
   16227             :         return o << j;
   16228             :     }
   16229             : 
   16230             :     /// @}
   16231             : 
   16232             :     /////////////////////
   16233             :     // deserialization //
   16234             :     /////////////////////
   16235             : 
   16236             :     /// @name deserialization
   16237             :     /// @{
   16238             : 
   16239             :     /*!
   16240             :     @brief deserialize from a compatible input
   16241             : 
   16242             :     This function reads from a compatible input. Examples are:
   16243             :     - an array of 1-byte values
   16244             :     - strings with character/literal type with size of 1 byte
   16245             :     - input streams
   16246             :     - container with contiguous storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container
   16247             :       types include `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`,
   16248             :       `std::valarray`, and `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style
   16249             :       arrays can be used with `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined
   16250             :       containers can be used as long as they implement random-access iterators
   16251             :       and a contiguous storage.
   16252             : 
   16253             :     @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
   16254             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
   16255             :     with a static assertion.**
   16256             : 
   16257             :     @pre The container storage is contiguous. Violating this precondition
   16258             :     yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an
   16259             :     assertion.**
   16260             :     @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
   16261             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
   16262             :     with a static assertion.**
   16263             : 
   16264             :     @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
   16265             :              the function is called with a noncompliant container and with
   16266             :              assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
   16267             :              likely yield segmentation violation.
   16268             : 
   16269             :     @param[in] i  input to read from
   16270             :     @param[in] cb  a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
   16271             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
   16272             :     (optional)
   16273             : 
   16274             :     @return result of the deserialization
   16275             : 
   16276             :     @throw parse_error.101 if a parse error occurs; example: `""unexpected end
   16277             :     of input; expected string literal""`
   16278             :     @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
   16279             :     @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
   16280             : 
   16281             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
   16282             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
   16283             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
   16284             : 
   16285             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
   16286             : 
   16287             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
   16288             :     from an array.,parse__array__parser_callback_t}
   16289             : 
   16290             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
   16291             :     and without callback function.,parse__string__parser_callback_t}
   16292             : 
   16293             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
   16294             :     and without callback function.,parse__istream__parser_callback_t}
   16295             : 
   16296             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
   16297             :     from a contiguous container.,parse__contiguouscontainer__parser_callback_t}
   16298             : 
   16299             :     @since version 2.0.3 (contiguous containers)
   16300             :     */
   16301          11 :     static basic_json parse(detail::input_adapter i,
   16302             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
   16303             :                             const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   16304             :     {
   16305          11 :         basic_json result;
   16306          11 :         parser(i, cb, allow_exceptions).parse(true, result);
   16307          11 :         return result;
   16308             :     }
   16309             : 
   16310             :     /*!
   16311             :     @copydoc basic_json parse(detail::input_adapter, const parser_callback_t)
   16312             :     */
   16313             :     static basic_json parse(detail::input_adapter& i,
   16314             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
   16315             :                             const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   16316             :     {
   16317             :         basic_json result;
   16318             :         parser(i, cb, allow_exceptions).parse(true, result);
   16319             :         return result;
   16320             :     }
   16321             : 
   16322             :     static bool accept(detail::input_adapter i)
   16323             :     {
   16324             :         return parser(i).accept(true);
   16325             :     }
   16326             : 
   16327             :     static bool accept(detail::input_adapter& i)
   16328             :     {
   16329             :         return parser(i).accept(true);
   16330             :     }
   16331             : 
   16332             :     /*!
   16333             :     @brief deserialize from an iterator range with contiguous storage
   16334             : 
   16335             :     This function reads from an iterator range of a container with contiguous
   16336             :     storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container types include
   16337             :     `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`, `std::valarray`, and
   16338             :     `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style arrays can be used with
   16339             :     `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined containers can be used as long
   16340             :     as they implement random-access iterators and a contiguous storage.
   16341             : 
   16342             :     @pre The iterator range is contiguous. Violating this precondition yields
   16343             :     undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an assertion.**
   16344             :     @pre Each element in the range has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
   16345             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
   16346             :     with a static assertion.**
   16347             : 
   16348             :     @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
   16349             :              the function is called with noncompliant iterators and with
   16350             :              assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
   16351             :              likely yield segmentation violation.
   16352             : 
   16353             :     @tparam IteratorType iterator of container with contiguous storage
   16354             :     @param[in] first  begin of the range to parse (included)
   16355             :     @param[in] last  end of the range to parse (excluded)
   16356             :     @param[in] cb  a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
   16357             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
   16358             :     (optional)
   16359             :     @param[in] allow_exceptions  whether to throw exceptions in case of a
   16360             :     parse error (optional, true by default)
   16361             : 
   16362             :     @return result of the deserialization
   16363             : 
   16364             :     @throw parse_error.101 in case of an unexpected token
   16365             :     @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
   16366             :     @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
   16367             : 
   16368             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
   16369             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
   16370             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
   16371             : 
   16372             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
   16373             : 
   16374             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
   16375             :     from an iterator range.,parse__iteratortype__parser_callback_t}
   16376             : 
   16377             :     @since version 2.0.3
   16378             :     */
   16379             :     template <class IteratorType,
   16380             :               typename std::enable_if<
   16381             :                   std::is_base_of<std::random_access_iterator_tag,
   16382             :                                   typename std::iterator_traits<
   16383             :                                       IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value,
   16384             :                   int>::type = 0>
   16385             :     static basic_json parse(IteratorType first, IteratorType last,
   16386             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
   16387             :                             const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   16388             :     {
   16389             :         basic_json result;
   16390             :         parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last), cb, allow_exceptions)
   16391             :             .parse(true, result);
   16392             :         return result;
   16393             :     }
   16394             : 
   16395             :     template <class IteratorType,
   16396             :               typename std::enable_if<
   16397             :                   std::is_base_of<std::random_access_iterator_tag,
   16398             :                                   typename std::iterator_traits<
   16399             :                                       IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value,
   16400             :                   int>::type = 0>
   16401             :     static bool accept(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
   16402             :     {
   16403             :         return parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last)).accept(true);
   16404             :     }
   16405             : 
   16406             :     /*!
   16407             :     @brief deserialize from stream
   16408             :     @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
   16409             :                 version 4.0.0 of the library. Please use
   16410             :                 @ref operator>>(std::istream&, basic_json&)
   16411             :                 instead; that is, replace calls like `j << i;` with `i >> j;`.
   16412             :     @since version 1.0.0; deprecated since version 3.0.0
   16413             :     */
   16414             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
   16415             :     friend std::istream& operator<<(basic_json& j, std::istream& i)
   16416             :     {
   16417             :         return operator>>(i, j);
   16418             :     }
   16419             : 
   16420             :     /*!
   16421             :     @brief deserialize from stream
   16422             : 
   16423             :     Deserializes an input stream to a JSON value.
   16424             : 
   16425             :     @param[in,out] i  input stream to read a serialized JSON value from
   16426             :     @param[in,out] j  JSON value to write the deserialized input to
   16427             : 
   16428             :     @throw parse_error.101 in case of an unexpected token
   16429             :     @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
   16430             :     @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
   16431             : 
   16432             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
   16433             :     LL(1) parser.
   16434             : 
   16435             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
   16436             : 
   16437             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how a JSON value is constructed by
   16438             :     reading a serialization from a stream.,operator_deserialize}
   16439             : 
   16440             :     @sa parse(std::istream&, const parser_callback_t) for a variant with a
   16441             :     parser callback function to filter values while parsing
   16442             : 
   16443             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16444             :     */
   16445             :     friend std::istream& operator>>(std::istream& i, basic_json& j)
   16446             :     {
   16447             :         parser(detail::input_adapter(i)).parse(false, j);
   16448             :         return i;
   16449             :     }
   16450             : 
   16451             :     /// @}
   16452             : 
   16453             :     ///////////////////////////
   16454             :     // convenience functions //
   16455             :     ///////////////////////////
   16456             : 
   16457             :     /*!
   16458             :     @brief return the type as string
   16459             : 
   16460             :     Returns the type name as string to be used in error messages - usually to
   16461             :     indicate that a function was called on a wrong JSON type.
   16462             : 
   16463             :     @return a string representation of a the @a m_type member:
   16464             :             Value type  | return value
   16465             :             ----------- | -------------
   16466             :             null        | `"null"`
   16467             :             boolean     | `"boolean"`
   16468             :             string      | `"string"`
   16469             :             number      | `"number"` (for all number types)
   16470             :             object      | `"object"`
   16471             :             array       | `"array"`
   16472             :             discarded   | `"discarded"`
   16473             : 
   16474             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16475             : 
   16476             :     @complexity Constant.
   16477             : 
   16478             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `type_name()` for all JSON
   16479             :     types.,type_name}
   16480             : 
   16481             :     @sa @ref type() -- return the type of the JSON value
   16482             :     @sa @ref operator value_t() -- return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
   16483             : 
   16484             :     @since version 1.0.0, public since 2.1.0, `const char*` and `noexcept`
   16485             :     since 3.0.0
   16486             :     */
   16487           0 :     const char* type_name() const noexcept
   16488             :     {
   16489             :         {
   16490           0 :             switch (m_type)
   16491             :             {
   16492             :             case value_t::null:
   16493           0 :                 return "null";
   16494             :             case value_t::object:
   16495           0 :                 return "object";
   16496             :             case value_t::array:
   16497           0 :                 return "array";
   16498             :             case value_t::string:
   16499           0 :                 return "string";
   16500             :             case value_t::boolean:
   16501           0 :                 return "boolean";
   16502             :             case value_t::discarded:
   16503           0 :                 return "discarded";
   16504             :             default:
   16505           0 :                 return "number";
   16506             :             }
   16507             :         }
   16508             :     }
   16509             : 
   16510             : private:
   16511             :     //////////////////////
   16512             :     // member variables //
   16513             :     //////////////////////
   16514             : 
   16515             :     /// the type of the current element
   16516             :     value_t m_type = value_t::null;
   16517             : 
   16518             :     /// the value of the current element
   16519             :     json_value m_value = {};
   16520             : 
   16521             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   16522             :     // binary serialization/deserialization //
   16523             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   16524             : 
   16525             :     /// @name binary serialization/deserialization support
   16526             :     /// @{
   16527             : 
   16528             : public:
   16529             :     /*!
   16530             :     @brief create a CBOR serialization of a given JSON value
   16531             : 
   16532             :     Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the CBOR (Concise
   16533             :     Binary Object Representation) serialization format. CBOR is a binary
   16534             :     serialization format which aims to be more compact than JSON itself, yet
   16535             :     more efficient to parse.
   16536             : 
   16537             :     The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
   16538             :     CBOR types according to the CBOR specification (RFC 7049):
   16539             : 
   16540             :     JSON value type | value/range                                | CBOR type
   16541             :     | first byte
   16542             :     --------------- | ------------------------------------------ |
   16543             :     ---------------------------------- | ---------------
   16544             :     null            | `null`                                     | Null | 0xF6
   16545             :     boolean         | `true`                                     | True | 0xF5
   16546             :     boolean         | `false`                                    | False | 0xF4
   16547             :     number_integer  | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649          | Negative
   16548             :     integer (8 bytes follow)  | 0x3B
   16549             :     number_integer  | -2147483648..-32769                        | Negative
   16550             :     integer (4 bytes follow)  | 0x3A
   16551             :     number_integer  | -32768..-129                               | Negative
   16552             :     integer (2 bytes follow)  | 0x39
   16553             :     number_integer  | -128..-25                                  | Negative
   16554             :     integer (1 byte follow)   | 0x38
   16555             :     number_integer  | -24..-1                                    | Negative
   16556             :     integer                   | 0x20..0x37
   16557             :     number_integer  | 0..23                                      | Integer
   16558             :     | 0x00..0x17
   16559             :     number_integer  | 24..255                                    | Unsigned
   16560             :     integer (1 byte follow)   | 0x18
   16561             :     number_integer  | 256..65535                                 | Unsigned
   16562             :     integer (2 bytes follow)  | 0x19
   16563             :     number_integer  | 65536..4294967295                          | Unsigned
   16564             :     integer (4 bytes follow)  | 0x1A
   16565             :     number_integer  | 4294967296..18446744073709551615           | Unsigned
   16566             :     integer (8 bytes follow)  | 0x1B
   16567             :     number_unsigned | 0..23                                      | Integer
   16568             :     | 0x00..0x17
   16569             :     number_unsigned | 24..255                                    | Unsigned
   16570             :     integer (1 byte follow)   | 0x18
   16571             :     number_unsigned | 256..65535                                 | Unsigned
   16572             :     integer (2 bytes follow)  | 0x19
   16573             :     number_unsigned | 65536..4294967295                          | Unsigned
   16574             :     integer (4 bytes follow)  | 0x1A
   16575             :     number_unsigned | 4294967296..18446744073709551615           | Unsigned
   16576             :     integer (8 bytes follow)  | 0x1B
   16577             :     number_float    | *any value*                                |
   16578             :     Double-Precision Float             | 0xFB
   16579             :     string          | *length*: 0..23                            | UTF-8 string
   16580             :     | 0x60..0x77
   16581             :     string          | *length*: 23..255                          | UTF-8 string
   16582             :     (1 byte follow)       | 0x78
   16583             :     string          | *length*: 256..65535                       | UTF-8 string
   16584             :     (2 bytes follow)      | 0x79
   16585             :     string          | *length*: 65536..4294967295                | UTF-8 string
   16586             :     (4 bytes follow)      | 0x7A
   16587             :     string          | *length*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | UTF-8 string
   16588             :     (8 bytes follow)      | 0x7B
   16589             :     array           | *size*: 0..23                              | array
   16590             :     | 0x80..0x97
   16591             :     array           | *size*: 23..255                            | array (1 byte
   16592             :     follow)              | 0x98
   16593             :     array           | *size*: 256..65535                         | array (2
   16594             :     bytes follow)             | 0x99
   16595             :     array           | *size*: 65536..4294967295                  | array (4
   16596             :     bytes follow)             | 0x9A
   16597             :     array           | *size*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615   | array (8
   16598             :     bytes follow)             | 0x9B
   16599             :     object          | *size*: 0..23                              | map
   16600             :     | 0xA0..0xB7
   16601             :     object          | *size*: 23..255                            | map (1 byte
   16602             :     follow)                | 0xB8
   16603             :     object          | *size*: 256..65535                         | map (2 bytes
   16604             :     follow)               | 0xB9
   16605             :     object          | *size*: 65536..4294967295                  | map (4 bytes
   16606             :     follow)               | 0xBA
   16607             :     object          | *size*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615   | map (8 bytes
   16608             :     follow)               | 0xBB
   16609             : 
   16610             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
   16611             :           can be converted to a CBOR value.
   16612             : 
   16613             :     @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
   16614             :           serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
   16615             :           function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
   16616             : 
   16617             :     @note The following CBOR types are not used in the conversion:
   16618             :           - byte strings (0x40..0x5F)
   16619             :           - UTF-8 strings terminated by "break" (0x7F)
   16620             :           - arrays terminated by "break" (0x9F)
   16621             :           - maps terminated by "break" (0xBF)
   16622             :           - date/time (0xC0..0xC1)
   16623             :           - bignum (0xC2..0xC3)
   16624             :           - decimal fraction (0xC4)
   16625             :           - bigfloat (0xC5)
   16626             :           - tagged items (0xC6..0xD4, 0xD8..0xDB)
   16627             :           - expected conversions (0xD5..0xD7)
   16628             :           - simple values (0xE0..0xF3, 0xF8)
   16629             :           - undefined (0xF7)
   16630             :           - half and single-precision floats (0xF9-0xFA)
   16631             :           - break (0xFF)
   16632             : 
   16633             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   16634             :     @return MessagePack serialization as byte vector
   16635             : 
   16636             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
   16637             : 
   16638             :     @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
   16639             :     vector in CBOR format.,to_cbor}
   16640             : 
   16641             :     @sa http://cbor.io
   16642             :     @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool strict) for the
   16643             :         analogous deserialization
   16644             :     @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the related MessagePack format
   16645             :     @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
   16646             :              related UBJSON format
   16647             : 
   16648             :     @since version 2.0.9
   16649             :     */
   16650             :     static std::vector<uint8_t> to_cbor(const basic_json& j)
   16651             :     {
   16652             :         std::vector<uint8_t> result;
   16653             :         to_cbor(j, result);
   16654             :         return result;
   16655             :     }
   16656             : 
   16657             :     static void to_cbor(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o)
   16658             :     {
   16659             :         binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_cbor(j);
   16660             :     }
   16661             : 
   16662             :     static void to_cbor(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o)
   16663             :     {
   16664             :         binary_writer<char>(o).write_cbor(j);
   16665             :     }
   16666             : 
   16667             :     /*!
   16668             :     @brief create a MessagePack serialization of a given JSON value
   16669             : 
   16670             :     Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the MessagePack
   16671             :     serialization format. MessagePack is a binary serialization format which
   16672             :     aims to be more compact than JSON itself, yet more efficient to parse.
   16673             : 
   16674             :     The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
   16675             :     MessagePack types according to the MessagePack specification:
   16676             : 
   16677             :     JSON value type | value/range                       | MessagePack type |
   16678             :     first byte
   16679             :     --------------- | --------------------------------- | ---------------- |
   16680             :     ----------
   16681             :     null            | `null`                            | nil              |
   16682             :     0xC0
   16683             :     boolean         | `true`                            | true             |
   16684             :     0xC3
   16685             :     boolean         | `false`                           | false            |
   16686             :     0xC2
   16687             :     number_integer  | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | int64            |
   16688             :     0xD3
   16689             :     number_integer  | -2147483648..-32769               | int32            |
   16690             :     0xD2
   16691             :     number_integer  | -32768..-129                      | int16            |
   16692             :     0xD1
   16693             :     number_integer  | -128..-33                         | int8             |
   16694             :     0xD0
   16695             :     number_integer  | -32..-1                           | negative fixint  |
   16696             :     0xE0..0xFF
   16697             :     number_integer  | 0..127                            | positive fixint  |
   16698             :     0x00..0x7F
   16699             :     number_integer  | 128..255                          | uint 8           |
   16700             :     0xCC
   16701             :     number_integer  | 256..65535                        | uint 16          |
   16702             :     0xCD
   16703             :     number_integer  | 65536..4294967295                 | uint 32          |
   16704             :     0xCE
   16705             :     number_integer  | 4294967296..18446744073709551615  | uint 64          |
   16706             :     0xCF
   16707             :     number_unsigned | 0..127                            | positive fixint  |
   16708             :     0x00..0x7F
   16709             :     number_unsigned | 128..255                          | uint 8           |
   16710             :     0xCC
   16711             :     number_unsigned | 256..65535                        | uint 16          |
   16712             :     0xCD
   16713             :     number_unsigned | 65536..4294967295                 | uint 32          |
   16714             :     0xCE
   16715             :     number_unsigned | 4294967296..18446744073709551615  | uint 64          |
   16716             :     0xCF
   16717             :     number_float    | *any value*                       | float 64         |
   16718             :     0xCB
   16719             :     string          | *length*: 0..31                   | fixstr           |
   16720             :     0xA0..0xBF
   16721             :     string          | *length*: 32..255                 | str 8            |
   16722             :     0xD9
   16723             :     string          | *length*: 256..65535              | str 16           |
   16724             :     0xDA
   16725             :     string          | *length*: 65536..4294967295       | str 32           |
   16726             :     0xDB
   16727             :     array           | *size*: 0..15                     | fixarray         |
   16728             :     0x90..0x9F
   16729             :     array           | *size*: 16..65535                 | array 16         |
   16730             :     0xDC
   16731             :     array           | *size*: 65536..4294967295         | array 32         |
   16732             :     0xDD
   16733             :     object          | *size*: 0..15                     | fix map          |
   16734             :     0x80..0x8F
   16735             :     object          | *size*: 16..65535                 | map 16           |
   16736             :     0xDE
   16737             :     object          | *size*: 65536..4294967295         | map 32           |
   16738             :     0xDF
   16739             : 
   16740             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
   16741             :           can be converted to a MessagePack value.
   16742             : 
   16743             :     @note The following values can **not** be converted to a MessagePack value:
   16744             :           - strings with more than 4294967295 bytes
   16745             :           - arrays with more than 4294967295 elements
   16746             :           - objects with more than 4294967295 elements
   16747             : 
   16748             :     @note The following MessagePack types are not used in the conversion:
   16749             :           - bin 8 - bin 32 (0xC4..0xC6)
   16750             :           - ext 8 - ext 32 (0xC7..0xC9)
   16751             :           - float 32 (0xCA)
   16752             :           - fixext 1 - fixext 16 (0xD4..0xD8)
   16753             : 
   16754             :     @note Any MessagePack output created @ref to_msgpack can be successfully
   16755             :           parsed by @ref from_msgpack.
   16756             : 
   16757             :     @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
   16758             :           serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
   16759             :           function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
   16760             : 
   16761             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   16762             :     @return MessagePack serialization as byte vector
   16763             : 
   16764             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
   16765             : 
   16766             :     @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
   16767             :     vector in MessagePack format.,to_msgpack}
   16768             : 
   16769             :     @sa http://msgpack.org
   16770             :     @sa @ref from_msgpack(const std::vector<uint8_t>&, const size_t) for the
   16771             :         analogous deserialization
