   16772             :     @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json& for the related CBOR format
   16773             :     @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
   16774             :              related UBJSON format
   16775             : 
   16776             :     @since version 2.0.9
   16777             :     */
   16778             :     static std::vector<uint8_t> to_msgpack(const basic_json& j)
   16779             :     {
   16780             :         std::vector<uint8_t> result;
   16781             :         to_msgpack(j, result);
   16782             :         return result;
   16783             :     }
   16784             : 
   16785             :     static void to_msgpack(const basic_json& j,
   16786             :                            detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o)
   16787             :     {
   16788             :         binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_msgpack(j);
   16789             :     }
   16790             : 
   16791             :     static void to_msgpack(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o)
   16792             :     {
   16793             :         binary_writer<char>(o).write_msgpack(j);
   16794             :     }
   16795             : 
   16796             :     /*!
   16797             :     @brief create a UBJSON serialization of a given JSON value
   16798             : 
   16799             :     Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the UBJSON
   16800             :     (Universal Binary JSON) serialization format. UBJSON aims to be more compact
   16801             :     than JSON itself, yet more efficient to parse.
   16802             : 
   16803             :     The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
   16804             :     UBJSON types according to the UBJSON specification:
   16805             : 
   16806             :     JSON value type | value/range                       | UBJSON type | marker
   16807             :     --------------- | --------------------------------- | ----------- | ------
   16808             :     null            | `null`                            | null        | `Z`
   16809             :     boolean         | `true`                            | true        | `T`
   16810             :     boolean         | `false`                           | false       | `F`
   16811             :     number_integer  | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | int64       | `L`
   16812             :     number_integer  | -2147483648..-32769               | int32       | `l`
   16813             :     number_integer  | -32768..-129                      | int16       | `I`
   16814             :     number_integer  | -128..127                         | int8        | `i`
   16815             :     number_integer  | 128..255                          | uint8       | `U`
   16816             :     number_integer  | 256..32767                        | int16       | `I`
   16817             :     number_integer  | 32768..2147483647                 | int32       | `l`
   16818             :     number_integer  | 2147483648..9223372036854775807   | int64       | `L`
   16819             :     number_unsigned | 0..127                            | int8        | `i`
   16820             :     number_unsigned | 128..255                          | uint8       | `U`
   16821             :     number_unsigned | 256..32767                        | int16       | `I`
   16822             :     number_unsigned | 32768..2147483647                 | int32       | `l`
   16823             :     number_unsigned | 2147483648..9223372036854775807   | int64       | `L`
   16824             :     number_float    | *any value*                       | float64     | `D`
   16825             :     string          | *with shortest length indicator*  | string      | `S`
   16826             :     array           | *see notes on optimized format*   | array       | `[`
   16827             :     object          | *see notes on optimized format*   | map         | `{`
   16828             : 
   16829             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
   16830             :           can be converted to a UBJSON value.
   16831             : 
   16832             :     @note The following values can **not** be converted to a UBJSON value:
   16833             :           - strings with more than 9223372036854775807 bytes (theoretical)
   16834             :           - unsigned integer numbers above 9223372036854775807
   16835             : 
   16836             :     @note The following markers are not used in the conversion:
   16837             :           - `Z`: no-op values are not created.
   16838             :           - `C`: single-byte strings are serialized with `S` markers.
   16839             : 
   16840             :     @note Any UBJSON output created @ref to_ubjson can be successfully parsed
   16841             :           by @ref from_ubjson.
   16842             : 
   16843             :     @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
   16844             :           serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
   16845             :           function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
   16846             : 
   16847             :     @note The optimized formats for containers are supported: Parameter
   16848             :           @a use_size adds size information to the beginning of a container and
   16849             :           removes the closing marker. Parameter @a use_type further checks
   16850             :           whether all elements of a container have the same type and adds the
   16851             :           type marker to the beginning of the container. The @a use_type
   16852             :           parameter must only be used together with @a use_size = true. Note
   16853             :           that @a use_size = true alone may result in larger representations -
   16854             :           the benefit of this parameter is that the receiving side is
   16855             :           immediately informed on the number of elements of the container.
   16856             : 
   16857             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   16858             :     @param[in] use_size  whether to add size annotations to container types
   16859             :     @param[in] use_type  whether to add type annotations to container types
   16860             :                          (must be combined with @a use_size = true)
   16861             :     @return UBJSON serialization as byte vector
   16862             : 
   16863             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
   16864             : 
   16865             :     @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
   16866             :     vector in UBJSON format.,to_ubjson}
   16867             : 
   16868             :     @sa http://ubjson.org
   16869             :     @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter, const bool strict) for the
   16870             :         analogous deserialization
   16871             :     @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json& for the related CBOR format
   16872             :     @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the related MessagePack format
   16873             : 
   16874             :     @since version 3.1.0
   16875             :     */
   16876             :     static std::vector<uint8_t> to_ubjson(const basic_json& j,
   16877             :                                           const bool use_size = false,
   16878             :                                           const bool use_type = false)
   16879             :     {
   16880             :         std::vector<uint8_t> result;
   16881             :         to_ubjson(j, result, use_size, use_type);
   16882             :         return result;
   16883             :     }
   16884             : 
   16885             :     static void to_ubjson(const basic_json& j,
   16886             :                           detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o,
   16887             :                           const bool use_size = false,
   16888             :                           const bool use_type = false)
   16889             :     {
   16890             :         binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_ubjson(j, use_size, use_type);
   16891             :     }
   16892             : 
   16893             :     static void to_ubjson(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o,
   16894             :                           const bool use_size = false,
   16895             :                           const bool use_type = false)
   16896             :     {
   16897             :         binary_writer<char>(o).write_ubjson(j, use_size, use_type);
   16898             :     }
   16899             : 
   16900             :     /*!
   16901             :     @brief create a JSON value from an input in CBOR format
   16902             : 
   16903             :     Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the CBOR (Concise
   16904             :     Binary Object Representation) serialization format.
   16905             : 
   16906             :     The library maps CBOR types to JSON value types as follows:
   16907             : 
   16908             :     CBOR type              | JSON value type | first byte
   16909             :     ---------------------- | --------------- | ----------
   16910             :     Integer                | number_unsigned | 0x00..0x17
   16911             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x18
   16912             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x19
   16913             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x1A
   16914             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x1B
   16915             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x20..0x37
   16916             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x38
   16917             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x39
   16918             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x3A
   16919             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x3B
   16920             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x40..0x57
   16921             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x60..0x77
   16922             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x78
   16923             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x79
   16924             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x7A
   16925             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x7B
   16926             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x7F
   16927             :     array                  | array           | 0x80..0x97
   16928             :     array                  | array           | 0x98
   16929             :     array                  | array           | 0x99
   16930             :     array                  | array           | 0x9A
   16931             :     array                  | array           | 0x9B
   16932             :     array                  | array           | 0x9F
   16933             :     map                    | object          | 0xA0..0xB7
   16934             :     map                    | object          | 0xB8
   16935             :     map                    | object          | 0xB9
   16936             :     map                    | object          | 0xBA
   16937             :     map                    | object          | 0xBB
   16938             :     map                    | object          | 0xBF
   16939             :     False                  | `false`         | 0xF4
   16940             :     True                   | `true`          | 0xF5
   16941             :     Nill                   | `null`          | 0xF6
   16942             :     Half-Precision Float   | number_float    | 0xF9
   16943             :     Single-Precision Float | number_float    | 0xFA
   16944             :     Double-Precision Float | number_float    | 0xFB
   16945             : 
   16946             :     @warning The mapping is **incomplete** in the sense that not all CBOR
   16947             :              types can be converted to a JSON value. The following CBOR types
   16948             :              are not supported and will yield parse errors (parse_error.112):
   16949             :              - byte strings (0x40..0x5F)
   16950             :              - date/time (0xC0..0xC1)
   16951             :              - bignum (0xC2..0xC3)
   16952             :              - decimal fraction (0xC4)
   16953             :              - bigfloat (0xC5)
   16954             :              - tagged items (0xC6..0xD4, 0xD8..0xDB)
   16955             :              - expected conversions (0xD5..0xD7)
   16956             :              - simple values (0xE0..0xF3, 0xF8)
   16957             :              - undefined (0xF7)
   16958             : 
   16959             :     @warning CBOR allows map keys of any type, whereas JSON only allows
   16960             :              strings as keys in object values. Therefore, CBOR maps with keys
   16961             :              other than UTF-8 strings are rejected (parse_error.113).
   16962             : 
   16963             :     @note Any CBOR output created @ref to_cbor can be successfully parsed by
   16964             :           @ref from_cbor.
   16965             : 
   16966             :     @param[in] i  an input in CBOR format convertible to an input adapter
   16967             :     @param[in] strict  whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
   16968             :                        (true by default)
   16969             :     @return deserialized JSON value
   16970             : 
   16971             :     @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
   16972             :     file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
   16973             :     @throw parse_error.112 if unsupported features from CBOR were
   16974             :     used in the given input @a v or if the input is not valid CBOR
   16975             :     @throw parse_error.113 if a string was expected as map key, but not found
   16976             : 
   16977             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
   16978             : 
   16979             :     @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in CBOR
   16980             :     format to a JSON value.,from_cbor}
   16981             : 
   16982             :     @sa http://cbor.io
   16983             :     @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json&) for the analogous serialization
   16984             :     @sa @ref from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter, const bool) for the
   16985             :         related MessagePack format
   16986             :     @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter, const bool) for the related
   16987             :         UBJSON format
   16988             : 
   16989             :     @since version 2.0.9; parameter @a start_index since 2.1.1; changed to
   16990             :            consume input adapters, removed start_index parameter, and added
   16991             :            @a strict parameter since 3.0.0
   16992             :     */
   16993             :     static basic_json from_cbor(detail::input_adapter i,
   16994             :                                 const bool strict = true)
   16995             :     {
   16996             :         return binary_reader(i).parse_cbor(strict);
   16997             :     }
   16998             : 
   16999             :     /*!
   17000             :     @copydoc from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool)
   17001             :     */
   17002             :     template <typename A1, typename A2,
   17003             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   17004             :                   std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value,
   17005             :                   int> = 0>
   17006             :     static basic_json from_cbor(A1&& a1, A2&& a2, const bool strict = true)
   17007             :     {
   17008             :         return binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1),
   17009             :                                                    std::forward<A2>(a2)))
   17010             :             .parse_cbor(strict);
   17011             :     }
   17012             : 
   17013             :     /*!
   17014             :     @brief create a JSON value from an input in MessagePack format
   17015             : 
   17016             :     Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the MessagePack
   17017             :     serialization format.
   17018             : 
   17019             :     The library maps MessagePack types to JSON value types as follows:
   17020             : 
   17021             :     MessagePack type | JSON value type | first byte
   17022             :     ---------------- | --------------- | ----------
   17023             :     positive fixint  | number_unsigned | 0x00..0x7F
   17024             :     fixmap           | object          | 0x80..0x8F
   17025             :     fixarray         | array           | 0x90..0x9F
   17026             :     fixstr           | string          | 0xA0..0xBF
   17027             :     nil              | `null`          | 0xC0
   17028             :     false            | `false`         | 0xC2
   17029             :     true             | `true`          | 0xC3
   17030             :     float 32         | number_float    | 0xCA
   17031             :     float 64         | number_float    | 0xCB
   17032             :     uint 8           | number_unsigned | 0xCC
   17033             :     uint 16          | number_unsigned | 0xCD
   17034             :     uint 32          | number_unsigned | 0xCE
   17035             :     uint 64          | number_unsigned | 0xCF
   17036             :     int 8            | number_integer  | 0xD0
   17037             :     int 16           | number_integer  | 0xD1
   17038             :     int 32           | number_integer  | 0xD2
   17039             :     int 64           | number_integer  | 0xD3
   17040             :     str 8            | string          | 0xD9
   17041             :     str 16           | string          | 0xDA
   17042             :     str 32           | string          | 0xDB
   17043             :     array 16         | array           | 0xDC
   17044             :     array 32         | array           | 0xDD
   17045             :     map 16           | object          | 0xDE
   17046             :     map 32           | object          | 0xDF
   17047             :     negative fixint  | number_integer  | 0xE0-0xFF
   17048             : 
   17049             :     @warning The mapping is **incomplete** in the sense that not all
   17050             :              MessagePack types can be converted to a JSON value. The following
   17051             :              MessagePack types are not supported and will yield parse errors:
   17052             :               - bin 8 - bin 32 (0xC4..0xC6)
   17053             :               - ext 8 - ext 32 (0xC7..0xC9)
   17054             :               - fixext 1 - fixext 16 (0xD4..0xD8)
   17055             : 
   17056             :     @note Any MessagePack output created @ref to_msgpack can be successfully
   17057             :           parsed by @ref from_msgpack.
   17058             : 
   17059             :     @param[in] i  an input in MessagePack format convertible to an input
   17060             :                   adapter
   17061             :     @param[in] strict  whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
   17062             :                        (true by default)
   17063             : 
   17064             :     @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
   17065             :     file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
   17066             :     @throw parse_error.112 if unsupported features from MessagePack were
   17067             :     used in the given input @a i or if the input is not valid MessagePack
   17068             :     @throw parse_error.113 if a string was expected as map key, but not found
   17069             : 
   17070             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
   17071             : 
   17072             :     @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in
   17073             :     MessagePack format to a JSON value.,from_msgpack}
   17074             : 
   17075             :     @sa http://msgpack.org
   17076             :     @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the analogous serialization
   17077             :     @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool) for the related CBOR
   17078             :         format
   17079             :     @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter, const bool) for the related
   17080             :         UBJSON format
   17081             : 
   17082             :     @since version 2.0.9; parameter @a start_index since 2.1.1; changed to
   17083             :            consume input adapters, removed start_index parameter, and added
   17084             :            @a strict parameter since 3.0.0
   17085             :     */
   17086             :     static basic_json from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter i,
   17087             :                                    const bool strict = true)
   17088             :     {
   17089             :         return binary_reader(i).parse_msgpack(strict);
   17090             :     }
   17091             : 
   17092             :     /*!
   17093             :     @copydoc from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter, const bool)
   17094             :     */
   17095             :     template <typename A1, typename A2,
   17096             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   17097             :                   std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value,
   17098             :                   int> = 0>
   17099             :     static basic_json from_msgpack(A1&& a1, A2&& a2, const bool strict = true)
   17100             :     {
   17101             :         return binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1),
   17102             :                                                    std::forward<A2>(a2)))
   17103             :             .parse_msgpack(strict);
   17104             :     }
   17105             : 
   17106             :     /*!
   17107             :     @brief create a JSON value from an input in UBJSON format
   17108             : 
   17109             :     Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the UBJSON (Universal
   17110             :     Binary JSON) serialization format.
   17111             : 
   17112             :     The library maps UBJSON types to JSON value types as follows:
   17113             : 
   17114             :     UBJSON type | JSON value type                         | marker
   17115             :     ----------- | --------------------------------------- | ------
   17116             :     no-op       | *no value, next value is read*          | `N`
   17117             :     null        | `null`                                  | `Z`
   17118             :     false       | `false`                                 | `F`
   17119             :     true        | `true`                                  | `T`
   17120             :     float32     | number_float                            | `d`
   17121             :     float64     | number_float                            | `D`
   17122             :     uint8       | number_unsigned                         | `U`
   17123             :     int8        | number_integer                          | `i`
   17124             :     int16       | number_integer                          | `I`
   17125             :     int32       | number_integer                          | `l`
   17126             :     int64       | number_integer                          | `L`
   17127             :     string      | string                                  | `S`
   17128             :     char        | string                                  | `C`
   17129             :     array       | array (optimized values are supported)  | `[`
   17130             :     object      | object (optimized values are supported) | `{`
   17131             : 
   17132             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any UBJSON value can
   17133             :           be converted to a JSON value.
   17134             : 
   17135             :     @param[in] i  an input in UBJSON format convertible to an input adapter
   17136             :     @param[in] strict  whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
   17137             :                        (true by default)
   17138             : 
   17139             :     @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
   17140             :     file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
   17141             :     @throw parse_error.112 if a parse error occurs
   17142             :     @throw parse_error.113 if a string could not be parsed successfully
   17143             : 
   17144             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
   17145             : 
   17146             :     @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in
   17147             :     UBJSON format to a JSON value.,from_ubjson}
   17148             : 
   17149             :     @sa http://ubjson.org
   17150             :     @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
   17151             :              analogous serialization
   17152             :     @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool) for the related CBOR
   17153             :         format
   17154             :     @sa @ref from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter, const bool) for the related
   17155             :         MessagePack format
   17156             : 
   17157             :     @since version 3.1.0
   17158             :     */
   17159             :     static basic_json from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter i,
   17160             :                                   const bool strict = true)
   17161             :     {
   17162             :         return binary_reader(i).parse_ubjson(strict);
   17163             :     }
   17164             : 
   17165             :     template <typename A1, typename A2,
   17166             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   17167             :                   std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value,
   17168             :                   int> = 0>
   17169             :     static basic_json from_ubjson(A1&& a1, A2&& a2, const bool strict = true)
   17170             :     {
   17171             :         return binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1),
   17172             :                                                    std::forward<A2>(a2)))
   17173             :             .parse_ubjson(strict);
   17174             :     }
   17175             : 
   17176             :     /// @}
   17177             : 
   17178             :     //////////////////////////
   17179             :     // JSON Pointer support //
   17180             :     //////////////////////////
   17181             : 
   17182             :     /// @name JSON Pointer functions
   17183             :     /// @{
   17184             : 
   17185             :     /*!
   17186             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17187             : 
   17188             :     Uses a JSON pointer to retrieve a reference to the respective JSON value.
   17189             :     No bound checking is performed. Similar to @ref operator[](const typename
   17190             :     object_t::key_type&), `null` values are created in arrays and objects if
   17191             :     necessary.
   17192             : 
   17193             :     In particular:
   17194             :     - If the JSON pointer points to an object key that does not exist, it
   17195             :       is created an filled with a `null` value before a reference to it
   17196             :       is returned.
   17197             :     - If the JSON pointer points to an array index that does not exist, it
   17198             :       is created an filled with a `null` value before a reference to it
   17199             :       is returned. All indices between the current maximum and the given
   17200             :       index are also filled with `null`.
   17201             :     - The special value `-` is treated as a synonym for the index past the
   17202             :       end.
   17203             : 
   17204             :     @param[in] ptr  a JSON pointer
   17205             : 
   17206             :     @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
   17207             : 
   17208             :     @complexity Constant.
   17209             : 
   17210             :     @throw parse_error.106   if an array index begins with '0'
   17211             :     @throw parse_error.109   if an array index was not a number
   17212             :     @throw out_of_range.404  if the JSON pointer can not be resolved
   17213             : 
   17214             :     @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,operatorjson_pointer}
   17215             : 
   17216             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17217             :     */
   17218             :     reference operator[](const json_pointer& ptr)
   17219             :     {
   17220             :         return ptr.get_unchecked(this);
   17221             :     }
   17222             : 
   17223             :     /*!
   17224             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17225             : 
   17226             :     Uses a JSON pointer to retrieve a reference to the respective JSON value.
   17227             :     No bound checking is performed. The function does not change the JSON
   17228             :     value; no `null` values are created. In particular, the the special value
   17229             :     `-` yields an exception.
   17230             : 
   17231             :     @param[in] ptr  JSON pointer to the desired element
   17232             : 
   17233             :     @return const reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
   17234             : 
   17235             :     @complexity Constant.
   17236             : 
   17237             :     @throw parse_error.106   if an array index begins with '0'
   17238             :     @throw parse_error.109   if an array index was not a number
   17239             :     @throw out_of_range.402  if the array index '-' is used
   17240             :     @throw out_of_range.404  if the JSON pointer can not be resolved
   17241             : 
   17242             :     @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the
   17243             :     example.,operatorjson_pointer_const}
   17244             : 
   17245             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17246             :     */
   17247             :     const_reference operator[](const json_pointer& ptr) const
   17248             :     {
   17249             :         return ptr.get_unchecked(this);
   17250             :     }
   17251             : 
   17252             :     /*!
   17253             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17254             : 
   17255             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified JSON pointer @a ptr,
   17256             :     with bounds checking.
   17257             : 
   17258             :     @param[in] ptr  JSON pointer to the desired element
   17259             : 
   17260             :     @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
   17261             : 
   17262             :     @throw parse_error.106 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17263             :     begins with '0'. See example below.
   17264             : 
   17265             :     @throw parse_error.109 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17266             :     is not a number. See example below.
   17267             : 
   17268             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17269             :     is out of range. See example below.
   17270             : 
   17271             :     @throw out_of_range.402 if the array index '-' is used in the passed JSON
   17272             :     pointer @a ptr. As `at` provides checked access (and no elements are
   17273             :     implicitly inserted), the index '-' is always invalid. See example below.
   17274             : 
   17275             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the JSON pointer describes a key of an object
   17276             :     which cannot be found. See example below.
   17277             : 
   17278             :     @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer @a ptr can not be resolved.
   17279             :     See example below.
   17280             : 
   17281             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   17282             :     changes in the JSON value.
   17283             : 
   17284             :     @complexity Constant.
   17285             : 
   17286             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17287             : 
   17288             :     @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,at_json_pointer}
   17289             :     */
   17290             :     reference at(const json_pointer& ptr) { return ptr.get_checked(this); }
   17291             :     /*!
   17292             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17293             : 
   17294             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified JSON pointer @a
   17295             :     ptr, with bounds checking.
   17296             : 
   17297             :     @param[in] ptr  JSON pointer to the desired element
   17298             : 
   17299             :     @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
   17300             : 
   17301             :     @throw parse_error.106 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17302             :     begins with '0'. See example below.
   17303             : 
   17304             :     @throw parse_error.109 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17305             :     is not a number. See example below.
   17306             : 
   17307             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17308             :     is out of range. See example below.
   17309             : 
   17310             :     @throw out_of_range.402 if the array index '-' is used in the passed JSON
   17311             :     pointer @a ptr. As `at` provides checked access (and no elements are
   17312             :     implicitly inserted), the index '-' is always invalid. See example below.
   17313             : 
   17314             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the JSON pointer describes a key of an object
   17315             :     which cannot be found. See example below.
   17316             : 
   17317             :     @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer @a ptr can not be resolved.
   17318             :     See example below.
   17319             : 
   17320             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   17321             :     changes in the JSON value.
   17322             : 
   17323             :     @complexity Constant.
   17324             : 
   17325             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17326             : 
   17327             :     @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,at_json_pointer_const}
   17328             :     */
   17329             :     const_reference at(const json_pointer& ptr) const
   17330             :     {
   17331             :         return ptr.get_checked(this);
   17332             :     }
   17333             : 
   17334             :     /*!
   17335             :     @brief return flattened JSON value
   17336             : 
   17337             :     The function creates a JSON object whose keys are JSON pointers (see [RFC
   17338             :     6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901)) and whose values are all
   17339             :     primitive. The original JSON value can be restored using the @ref
   17340             :     unflatten() function.
   17341             : 
   17342             :     @return an object that maps JSON pointers to primitive values
   17343             : 
   17344             :     @note Empty objects and arrays are flattened to `null` and will not be
   17345             :           reconstructed correctly by the @ref unflatten() function.
   17346             : 
   17347             :     @complexity Linear in the size the JSON value.
   17348             : 
   17349             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON object is flattened to an
   17350             :     object whose keys consist of JSON pointers.,flatten}
   17351             : 
   17352             :     @sa @ref unflatten() for the reverse function
   17353             : 
   17354             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17355             :     */
   17356          11 :     basic_json flatten() const
   17357             :     {
   17358          11 :         basic_json result(value_t::object);
   17359          11 :         json_pointer::flatten("", *this, result);
   17360          11 :         return result;
   17361             :     }
   17362             : 
   17363             :     /*!
   17364             :     @brief unflatten a previously flattened JSON value
   17365             : 
   17366             :     The function restores the arbitrary nesting of a JSON value that has been
   17367             :     flattened before using the @ref flatten() function. The JSON value must
   17368             :     meet certain constraints:
   17369             :     1. The value must be an object.
   17370             :     2. The keys must be JSON pointers (see
   17371             :        [RFC 6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901))
   17372             :     3. The mapped values must be primitive JSON types.
   17373             : 
   17374             :     @return the original JSON from a flattened version
   17375             : 
   17376             :     @note Empty objects and arrays are flattened by @ref flatten() to `null`
   17377             :           values and can not unflattened to their original type. Apart from
   17378             :           this example, for a JSON value `j`, the following is always true:
   17379             :           `j == j.flatten().unflatten()`.
   17380             : 
   17381             :     @complexity Linear in the size the JSON value.
   17382             : 
   17383             :     @throw type_error.314  if value is not an object
   17384             :     @throw type_error.315  if object values are not primitive
   17385             : 
   17386             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how a flattened JSON object is
   17387             :     unflattened into the original nested JSON object.,unflatten}
   17388             : 
   17389             :     @sa @ref flatten() for the reverse function
   17390             : 
   17391             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17392             :     */
   17393          11 :     basic_json unflatten() const { return json_pointer::unflatten(*this); }
   17394             :     /// @}
   17395             : 
   17396             :     //////////////////////////
   17397             :     // JSON Patch functions //
   17398             :     //////////////////////////
   17399             : 
   17400             :     /// @name JSON Patch functions
   17401             :     /// @{
   17402             : 
   17403             :     /*!
   17404             :     @brief applies a JSON patch
   17405             : 
   17406             :     [JSON Patch](http://jsonpatch.com) defines a JSON document structure for
   17407             :     expressing a sequence of operations to apply to a JSON) document. With
   17408             :     this function, a JSON Patch is applied to the current JSON value by
   17409             :     executing all operations from the patch.
   17410             : 
   17411             :     @param[in] json_patch  JSON patch document
   17412             :     @return patched document
   17413             : 
   17414             :     @note The application of a patch is atomic: Either all operations succeed
   17415             :           and the patched document is returned or an exception is thrown. In
   17416             :           any case, the original value is not changed: the patch is applied
   17417             :           to a copy of the value.
   17418             : 
   17419             :     @throw parse_error.104 if the JSON patch does not consist of an array of
   17420             :     objects
   17421             : 
   17422             :     @throw parse_error.105 if the JSON patch is malformed (e.g., mandatory
   17423             :     attributes are missing); example: `"operation add must have member path"`
   17424             : 
   17425             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index is out of range.
   17426             : 
   17427             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if a JSON pointer inside the patch could not be
   17428             :     resolved successfully in the current JSON value; example: `"key baz not
   17429             :     found"`
   17430             : 
   17431             :     @throw out_of_range.405 if JSON pointer has no parent ("add", "remove",
   17432             :     "move")
   17433             : 
   17434             :     @throw other_error.501 if "test" operation was unsuccessful
   17435             : 
   17436             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value and the length of the
   17437             :     JSON patch. As usually only a fraction of the JSON value is affected by
   17438             :     the patch, the complexity can usually be neglected.
   17439             : 
   17440             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON patch is applied to a
   17441             :     value.,patch}
   17442             : 
   17443             :     @sa @ref diff -- create a JSON patch by comparing two JSON values
   17444             : 
   17445             :     @sa [RFC 6902 (JSON Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6902)
   17446             :     @sa [RFC 6901 (JSON Pointer)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901)
   17447             : 
   17448             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17449             :     */
   17450             :     basic_json patch(const basic_json& json_patch) const
   17451             :     {
   17452             :         // make a working copy to apply the patch to
   17453             :         basic_json result = *this;
   17454             : 
   17455             :         // the valid JSON Patch operations
   17456             :         enum class patch_operations
   17457             :         {
   17458             :             add,
   17459             :             remove,
   17460             :             replace,
   17461             :             move,
   17462             :             copy,
   17463             :             test,
   17464             :             invalid
   17465             :         };
   17466             : 
   17467             :         const auto get_op = [](const std::string& op) {
   17468             :             if (op == "add")
   17469             :             {
   17470             :                 return patch_operations::add;
   17471             :             }
   17472             :             if (op == "remove")
   17473             :             {
   17474             :                 return patch_operations::remove;
   17475             :             }
   17476             :             if (op == "replace")
   17477             :             {
   17478             :                 return patch_operations::replace;
   17479             :             }
   17480             :             if (op == "move")
   17481             :             {
   17482             :                 return patch_operations::move;
   17483             :             }
   17484             :             if (op == "copy")
   17485             :             {
   17486             :                 return patch_operations::copy;
   17487             :             }
   17488             :             if (op == "test")
   17489             :             {
   17490             :                 return patch_operations::test;
   17491             :             }
   17492             : 
   17493             :             return patch_operations::invalid;
   17494             :         };
   17495             : 
   17496             :         // wrapper for "add" operation; add value at ptr
   17497             :         const auto operation_add = [&result](json_pointer& ptr,
   17498             :                                              basic_json val) {
   17499             :             // adding to the root of the target document means replacing it
   17500             :             if (ptr.is_root())
   17501             :             {
   17502             :                 result = val;
   17503             :             }
   17504             :             else
   17505             :             {
   17506             :                 // make sure the top element of the pointer exists
   17507             :                 json_pointer top_pointer = ptr.top();
   17508             :                 if (top_pointer != ptr)
   17509             :                 {
   17510             :                     result.at(top_pointer);
   17511             :                 }
   17512             : 
   17513             :                 // get reference to parent of JSON pointer ptr
   17514             :                 const auto last_path = ptr.pop_back();
   17515             :                 basic_json& parent = result[ptr];
   17516             : 
   17517             :                 switch (parent.m_type)
   17518             :                 {
   17519             :                 case value_t::null:
   17520             :                 case value_t::object:
   17521             :                 {
   17522             :                     // use operator[] to add value
   17523             :                     parent[last_path] = val;
   17524             :                     break;
   17525             :                 }
   17526             : 
   17527             :                 case value_t::array:
   17528             :                 {
   17529             :                     if (last_path == "-")
   17530             :                     {
   17531             :                         // special case: append to back
   17532             :                         parent.push_back(val);
   17533             :                     }
   17534             :                     else
   17535             :                     {
   17536             :                         const auto idx = json_pointer::array_index(last_path);
   17537             :                         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(static_cast<size_type>(idx) >
   17538             :                                           parent.size()))
   17539             :                         {
   17540             :                             // avoid undefined behavior
   17541             :                             JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(
   17542             :                                 401, "array index " + std::to_string(idx) +
   17543             :                                          " is out of range"));
   17544             :                         }
   17545             :                         else
   17546             :                         {
   17547             :                             // default case: insert add offset
   17548             :                             parent.insert(parent.begin() +
   17549             :                                               static_cast<difference_type>(idx),
   17550             :                                           val);
   17551             :                         }
   17552             :                     }
   17553             :                     break;
   17554             :                 }
   17555             : 
   17556             :                 default:
   17557             :                 {
   17558             :                     // if there exists a parent it cannot be primitive
   17559             :                     assert(false); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
   17560             :                 }
   17561             :                 }
   17562             :             }
   17563             :         };
   17564             : 
   17565             :         // wrapper for "remove" operation; remove value at ptr
   17566             :         const auto operation_remove = [&result](json_pointer& ptr) {
   17567             :             // get reference to parent of JSON pointer ptr
   17568             :             const auto last_path = ptr.pop_back();
   17569             :             basic_json& parent = result.at(ptr);
   17570             : 
   17571             :             // remove child
   17572             :             if (parent.is_object())
   17573             :             {
   17574             :                 // perform range check
   17575             :                 auto it = parent.find(last_path);
   17576             :                 if (JSON_LIKELY(it != parent.end()))
   17577             :                 {
   17578             :                     parent.erase(it);
   17579             :                 }
   17580             :                 else
   17581             :                 {
   17582             :                     JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + last_path +
   17583             :                                                              "' not found"));
   17584             :                 }
   17585             :             }
   17586             :             else if (parent.is_array())
   17587             :             {
   17588             :                 // note erase performs range check
   17589             :                 parent.erase(static_cast<size_type>(
   17590             :                     json_pointer::array_index(last_path)));
   17591             :             }
   17592             :         };
   17593             : 
   17594             :         // type check: top level value must be an array
   17595             :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not json_patch.is_array()))
   17596             :         {
   17597             :             JSON_THROW(
   17598             :                 parse_error::create(104, 0,
   17599             :                                     "JSON patch must be an array of objects"));
   17600             :         }
   17601             : 
   17602             :         // iterate and apply the operations
   17603             :         for (const auto& val : json_patch)
   17604             :         {
   17605             :             // wrapper to get a value for an operation
   17606             :             const auto get_value = [&val](const std::string& op,
   17607             :                                           const std::string& member,
   17608             :                                           bool string_type) -> basic_json& {
   17609             :                 // find value
   17610             :                 auto it = val.m_value.object->find(member);
   17611             : 
   17612             :                 // context-sensitive error message
   17613             :                 const auto error_msg =
   17614             :                     (op == "op") ? "operation" : "operation '" + op + "'";
   17615             : 
   17616             :                 // check if desired value is present
   17617             :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(it == val.m_value.object->end()))
   17618             :                 {
   17619             :                     JSON_THROW(
   17620             :                         parse_error::create(105, 0, error_msg +
   17621             :                                                         " must have member '" +
   17622             :                                                         member + "'"));
   17623             :                 }
   17624             : 
   17625             :                 // check if result is of type string
   17626             :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(string_type and not it->second.is_string()))
   17627             :                 {
   17628             :                     JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(
   17629             :                         105, 0, error_msg + " must have string member '" +
   17630             :                                     member + "'"));
   17631             :                 }
   17632             : 
   17633             :                 // no error: return value
   17634             :                 return it->second;
   17635             :             };
   17636             : 
   17637             :             // type check: every element of the array must be an object
   17638             :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not val.is_object()))
   17639             :             {
   17640             :                 JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(
   17641             :                     104, 0, "JSON patch must be an array of objects"));
   17642             :             }
   17643             : 
   17644             :             // collect mandatory members
   17645             :             const std::string op = get_value("op", "op", true);
   17646             :             const std::string path = get_value(op, "path", true);
   17647             :             json_pointer ptr(path);
   17648             : 
   17649             :             switch (get_op(op))
   17650             :             {
   17651             :             case patch_operations::add:
   17652             :             {
   17653             :                 operation_add(ptr, get_value("add", "value", false));
   17654             :                 break;
   17655             :             }
   17656             : 
   17657             :             case patch_operations::remove:
   17658             :             {
   17659             :                 operation_remove(ptr);
   17660             :                 break;
   17661             :             }
   17662             : 
   17663             :             case patch_operations::replace:
   17664             :             {
   17665             :                 // the "path" location must exist - use at()
   17666             :                 result.at(ptr) = get_value("replace", "value", false);
   17667             :                 break;
   17668             :             }
   17669             : 
   17670             :             case patch_operations::move:
   17671             :             {
   17672             :                 const std::string from_path = get_value("move", "from", true);
   17673             :                 json_pointer from_ptr(from_path);
   17674             : 
   17675             :                 // the "from" location must exist - use at()
   17676             :                 basic_json v = result.at(from_ptr);
   17677             : 
   17678             :                 // The move operation is functionally identical to a
   17679             :                 // "remove" operation on the "from" location, followed
   17680             :                 // immediately by an "add" operation at the target
   17681             :                 // location with the value that was just removed.
   17682             :                 operation_remove(from_ptr);
   17683             :                 operation_add(ptr, v);
   17684             :                 break;
   17685             :             }
   17686             : 
   17687             :             case patch_operations::copy:
   17688             :             {
   17689             :                 const std::string from_path = get_value("copy", "from", true);
   17690             :                 const json_pointer from_ptr(from_path);
   17691             : 
   17692             :                 // the "from" location must exist - use at()
   17693             :                 basic_json v = result.at(from_ptr);
   17694             : 
   17695             :                 // The copy is functionally identical to an "add"
   17696             :                 // operation at the target location using the value
   17697             :                 // specified in the "from" member.
   17698             :                 operation_add(ptr, v);
   17699             :                 break;
   17700             :             }
   17701             : 
   17702             :             case patch_operations::test:
   17703             :             {
   17704             :                 bool success = false;
   17705             :                 JSON_TRY
   17706             :                 {
   17707             :                     // check if "value" matches the one at "path"
   17708             :                     // the "path" location must exist - use at()
   17709             :                     success =
   17710             :                         (result.at(ptr) == get_value("test", "value", false));
   17711             :                 }
   17712             :                 JSON_CATCH(out_of_range&)
   17713             :                 {
   17714             :                     // ignore out of range errors: success remains false
   17715             :                 }
   17716             : 
   17717             :                 // throw an exception if test fails
   17718             :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not success))
   17719             :                 {
   17720             :                     JSON_THROW(other_error::create(501, "unsuccessful: " +
   17721             :                                                             val.dump()));
   17722             :                 }
   17723             : 
   17724             :                 break;
   17725             :             }
   17726             : 
   17727             :             case patch_operations::invalid:
   17728             :             {
   17729             :                 // op must be "add", "remove", "replace", "move", "copy", or
   17730             :                 // "test"
   17731             :                 JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(105, 0, "operation value '" +
   17732             :                                                            op +
   17733             :                                                            "' is invalid"));
   17734             :             }
   17735             :             }
   17736             :         }
   17737             : 
   17738             :         return result;
   17739             :     }
   17740             : 
   17741             :     /*!
   17742             :     @brief creates a diff as a JSON patch
   17743             : 
   17744             :     Creates a [JSON Patch](http://jsonpatch.com) so that value @a source can
   17745             :     be changed into the value @a target by calling @ref patch function.
   17746             : 
   17747             :     @invariant For two JSON values @a source and @a target, the following code
   17748             :     yields always `true`:
   17749             :     @code {.cpp}
   17750             :     source.patch(diff(source, target)) == target;
   17751             :     @endcode
   17752             : 
   17753             :     @note Currently, only `remove`, `add`, and `replace` operations are
   17754             :           generated.
   17755             : 
   17756             :     @param[in] source  JSON value to compare from
   17757             :     @param[in] target  JSON value to compare against
   17758             :     @param[in] path    helper value to create JSON pointers
   17759             : 
   17760             :     @return a JSON patch to convert the @a source to @a target
   17761             : 
   17762             :     @complexity Linear in the lengths of @a source and @a target.
   17763             : 
   17764             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON patch is created as a
   17765             :     diff for two JSON values.,diff}
   17766             : 
   17767             :     @sa @ref patch -- apply a JSON patch
   17768             :     @sa @ref merge_patch -- apply a JSON Merge Patch
   17769             : 
   17770             :     @sa [RFC 6902 (JSON Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6902)
   17771             : 
   17772             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17773             :     */
   17774             :     static basic_json diff(const basic_json& source, const basic_json& target,
   17775             :                            const std::string& path = "")
   17776             :     {
   17777             :         // the patch
   17778             :         basic_json result(value_t::array);
   17779             : 
   17780             :         // if the values are the same, return empty patch
   17781             :         if (source == target)
   17782             :         {
   17783             :             return result;
   17784             :         }
   17785             : 
   17786             :         if (source.type() != target.type())
   17787             :         {
   17788             :             // different types: replace value
   17789             :             result.push_back(
   17790             :                 {{"op", "replace"}, {"path", path}, {"value", target}});
   17791             :         }
   17792             :         else
   17793             :         {
   17794             :             switch (source.type())
   17795             :             {
   17796             :             case value_t::array:
   17797             :             {
   17798             :                 // first pass: traverse common elements
   17799             :                 std::size_t i = 0;
   17800             :                 while (i < source.size() and i < target.size())
   17801             :                 {
   17802             :                     // recursive call to compare array values at index i
   17803             :                     auto temp_diff = diff(source[i], target[i],
   17804             :                                           path + "/" + std::to_string(i));
   17805             :                     result.insert(result.end(), temp_diff.begin(),
   17806             :                                   temp_diff.end());
   17807             :                     ++i;
   17808             :                 }
   17809             : 
   17810             :                 // i now reached the end of at least one array
   17811             :                 // in a second pass, traverse the remaining elements
   17812             : 
   17813             :                 // remove my remaining elements
   17814             :                 const auto end_index =
   17815             :                     static_cast<difference_type>(result.size());
   17816             :                 while (i < source.size())
   17817             :                 {
   17818             :                     // add operations in reverse order to avoid invalid
   17819             :                     // indices
   17820             :                     result.insert(result.begin() + end_index,
   17821             :                                   object({{"op", "remove"},
   17822             :                                           {"path",
   17823             :                                            path + "/" + std::to_string(i)}}));
   17824             :                     ++i;
   17825             :                 }
   17826             : 
   17827             :                 // add other remaining elements
   17828             :                 while (i < target.size())
   17829             :                 {
   17830             :                     result.push_back({{"op", "add"},
   17831             :                                       {"path", path + "/" + std::to_string(i)},
   17832             :                                       {"value", target[i]}});
   17833             :                     ++i;
   17834             :                 }
   17835             : 
   17836             :                 break;
   17837             :             }
   17838             : 
   17839             :             case value_t::object:
   17840             :             {
   17841             :                 // first pass: traverse this object's elements
   17842             :                 for (auto it = source.cbegin(); it != source.cend(); ++it)
   17843             :                 {
   17844             :                     // escape the key name to be used in a JSON patch
   17845             :                     const auto key = json_pointer::escape(it.key());
   17846             : 
   17847             :                     if (target.find(it.key()) != target.end())
   17848             :                     {
   17849             :                         // recursive call to compare object values at key it
   17850             :                         auto temp_diff = diff(it.value(), target[it.key()],
   17851             :                                               path + "/" + key);
   17852             :                         result.insert(result.end(), temp_diff.begin(),
   17853             :                                       temp_diff.end());
   17854             :                     }
   17855             :                     else
   17856             :                     {
   17857             :                         // found a key that is not in o -> remove it
   17858             :                         result.push_back(object(
   17859             :                             {{"op", "remove"}, {"path", path + "/" + key}}));
   17860             :                     }
   17861             :                 }
   17862             : 
   17863             :                 // second pass: traverse other object's elements
   17864             :                 for (auto it = target.cbegin(); it != target.cend(); ++it)
   17865             :                 {
   17866             :                     if (source.find(it.key()) == source.end())
   17867             :                     {
   17868             :                         // found a key that is not in this -> add it
   17869             :                         const auto key = json_pointer::escape(it.key());
   17870             :                         result.push_back({{"op", "add"},
   17871             :                                           {"path", path + "/" + key},
   17872             :                                           {"value", it.value()}});
   17873             :                     }
   17874             :                 }
   17875             : 
   17876             :                 break;
   17877             :             }
   17878             : 
   17879             :             default:
   17880             :             {
   17881             :                 // both primitive type: replace value
   17882             :                 result.push_back(
   17883             :                     {{"op", "replace"}, {"path", path}, {"value", target}});
   17884             :                 break;
   17885             :             }
   17886             :             }
   17887             :         }
   17888             : 
   17889             :         return result;
   17890             :     }
   17891             : 
   17892             :     /// @}
   17893             : 
   17894             :     ////////////////////////////////
   17895             :     // JSON Merge Patch functions //
   17896             :     ////////////////////////////////
   17897             : 
   17898             :     /// @name JSON Merge Patch functions
   17899             :     /// @{
   17900             : 
   17901             :     /*!
   17902             :     @brief applies a JSON Merge Patch
   17903             : 
   17904             :     The merge patch format is primarily intended for use with the HTTP PATCH
   17905             :     method as a means of describing a set of modifications to a target
   17906             :     resource's content. This function applies a merge patch to the current
   17907             :     JSON value.
   17908             : 
   17909             :     The function implements the following algorithm from Section 2 of
   17910             :     [RFC 7396 (JSON Merge Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396):
   17911             : 
   17912             :     ```
   17913             :     define MergePatch(Target, Patch):
   17914             :       if Patch is an Object:
   17915             :         if Target is not an Object:
   17916             :           Target = {} // Ignore the contents and set it to an empty Object
   17917             :         for each Name/Value pair in Patch:
   17918             :           if Value is null:
   17919             :             if Name exists in Target:
   17920             :               remove the Name/Value pair from Target
   17921             :           else:
   17922             :             Target[Name] = MergePatch(Target[Name], Value)
   17923             :         return Target
   17924             :       else:
   17925             :         return Patch
   17926             :     ```
   17927             : 
   17928             :     Thereby, `Target` is the current object; that is, the patch is applied to
   17929             :     the current value.
   17930             : 
   17931             :     @param[in] patch  the patch to apply
   17932             : 
   17933             :     @complexity Linear in the lengths of @a patch.
   17934             : 
   17935             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON Merge Patch is applied to
   17936             :     a JSON document.,merge_patch}
   17937             : 
   17938             :     @sa @ref patch -- apply a JSON patch
   17939             :     @sa [RFC 7396 (JSON Merge Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396)
   17940             : 
   17941             :     @since version 3.0.0
   17942             :     */
   17943             :     void merge_patch(const basic_json& jspatch)
   17944             :     {
   17945             :         if (jspatch.is_object())
   17946             :         {
   17947             :             if (not is_object())
   17948             :             {
   17949             :                 *this = object();
   17950             :             }
   17951             :             for (auto it = jspatch.begin(); it != jspatch.end(); ++it)
   17952             :             {
   17953             :                 if (it.value().is_null())
   17954             :                 {
   17955             :                     erase(it.key());
   17956             :                 }
   17957             :                 else
   17958             :                 {
   17959             :                     operator[](it.key()).merge_patch(it.value());
   17960             :                 }
   17961             :             }
   17962             :         }
   17963             :         else
   17964             :         {
   17965             :             *this = jspatch;
   17966             :         }
   17967             :     }
   17968             : 
   17969             :     /// @}
   17970             : };
   17971             : } // namespace nlohmann
   17972             : 
   17973             : ///////////////////////
   17974             : // nonmember support //
   17975             : ///////////////////////
   17976             : 
   17977             : // specialization of std::swap, and std::hash
   17978             : namespace std
   17979             : {
   17980             : /*!
   17981             : @brief exchanges the values of two JSON objects
   17982             : 
   17983             : @since version 1.0.0
   17984             : */
   17985             : template <>
   17986             : inline void swap(brion_nlohmann::json& j1, brion_nlohmann::json& j2) noexcept(
   17987             :     is_nothrow_move_constructible<brion_nlohmann::json>::value and
   17988             :         is_nothrow_move_assignable<brion_nlohmann::json>::value)
   17989             : {
   17990             :     j1.swap(j2);
   17991             : }
   17992             : 
   17993             : /// hash value for JSON objects
   17994             : template <>
   17995             : struct hash<brion_nlohmann::json>
   17996             : {
   17997             :     /*!
   17998             :     @brief return a hash value for a JSON object
   17999             : 
   18000             :     @since version 1.0.0
   18001             :     */
   18002             :     std::size_t operator()(const brion_nlohmann::json& j) const
   18003             :     {
   18004             :         // a naive hashing via the string representation
   18005             :         const auto& h = hash<brion_nlohmann::json::string_t>();
   18006             :         return h(j.dump());
   18007             :     }
   18008             : };
   18009             : 
   18010             : /// specialization for std::less<value_t>
   18011             : /// @note: do not remove the space after '<',
   18012             : ///        see https://github.com/nlohmann/json/pull/679
   18013             : template <>
   18014             : struct less<::brion_nlohmann::detail::value_t>
   18015             : {
   18016             :     /*!
   18017             :     @brief compare two value_t enum values
   18018             :     @since version 3.0.0
   18019             :     */
   18020             :     bool operator()(brion_nlohmann::detail::value_t lhs,
   18021             :                     brion_nlohmann::detail::value_t rhs) const noexcept
   18022             :     {
   18023             :         return brion_nlohmann::detail::operator<(lhs, rhs);
   18024             :     }
   18025             : };
   18026             : 
   18027             : } // namespace std
   18028             : 
   18029             : /*!
   18030             : @brief user-defined string literal for JSON values
   18031             : 
   18032             : This operator implements a user-defined string literal for JSON objects. It
   18033             : can be used by adding `"_json"` to a string literal and returns a JSON object
   18034             : if no parse error occurred.
   18035             : 
   18036             : @param[in] s  a string representation of a JSON object
   18037             : @param[in] n  the length of string @a s
   18038             : @return a JSON object
   18039             : 
   18040             : @since version 1.0.0
   18041             : */
   18042             : inline brion_nlohmann::json operator"" _json(const char* s, std::size_t n)
   18043             : {
   18044             :     return brion_nlohmann::json::parse(s, s + n);
   18045             : }
   18046             : 
   18047             : /*!
   18048             : @brief user-defined string literal for JSON pointer
   18049             : 
   18050             : This operator implements a user-defined string literal for JSON Pointers. It
   18051             : can be used by adding `"_json_pointer"` to a string literal and returns a JSON
   18052             : pointer
   18053             : object if no parse error occurred.
   18054             : 
   18055             : @param[in] s  a string representation of a JSON Pointer
   18056             : @param[in] n  the length of string @a s
   18057             : @return a JSON pointer object
   18058             : 
   18059             : @since version 2.0.0
   18060             : */
   18061             : inline brion_nlohmann::json::json_pointer operator"" _json_pointer(
   18062             :     const char* s, std::size_t n)
   18063             : {
   18064             :     return brion_nlohmann::json::json_pointer(std::string(s, n));
   18065             : }
   18066             : 
   18067             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/macro_unscope.hpp>
   18068             : 
   18069             : // restore GCC/clang diagnostic settings
   18070             : #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
   18071             : #pragma GCC diagnostic pop
   18072             : #endif
   18073             : #if defined(__clang__)
   18074             : #pragma GCC diagnostic pop
   18075             : #endif
   18076             : 
   18077             : // clean up
   18078             : #undef JSON_CATCH
   18079             : #undef JSON_THROW
   18080             : #undef JSON_TRY
   18081             : #undef JSON_LIKELY
   18082             : #undef JSON_UNLIKELY
   18083             : #undef JSON_DEPRECATED
   18084             : #undef JSON_HAS_CPP_14
   18085             : #undef JSON_HAS_CPP_17
   18086             : #undef NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL_DECLARATION
   18087             : #undef NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL
   18088             : #undef NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER

   18091             : namespace nlohmann
   18092             : {
   18093             : using namespace brion_nlohmann;
   18094             : }
